author: KarenZee  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Wed Feb 01, 2006 10:50 am Location: CT
title: Still have Epstein-Barr?
content: Hello Maja:  It's been a while since you posted. I just located this website today but I noticed that a lot of posts are not replied to.  I had/have active EBV as well. In answer to your question about doctors and getting help, have you been to a naturopathic doctor? I went to a ND who prescribed a variety of supplements to address building up my immune system. It took several months, but slowly I felt a little better.  The interesting thing with EBV is that you seem to have peaks and valleys in how well you feel. That is the way it has been for me. It's 3 years since my EBV activated and I still don't feel like my normal self. I've actually forgotten what feeling normal/well feels like!  The ND I was seeing was very helpful in identifying (from simple blood work) a number of things that were going on with me. It wasn't just the EBV that was making me sick. I also had Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (an autoimmune condition that causes a low functioning thyroid), Iron deficiency anemia with a low ferritin level, Vitamin D deficiency, Psoriasis, and my adrenals were not functioning too well. My immune system wasn't working very well.  When you find another doctor hopefully they will do  more labwork to see if anything else may be goin on with your body's chemistry. There are lots of reasons for why people feel chronic, unrelenting fatigue.  I hope you are able to feel better soon.
posted_time: Post  by KarenZee » Wed Feb 01, 2006 11:43 am

author: maja_sp  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Jan 30, 2006 7:45 pm Location: Ohio, USA
title: Going to a naturopathic is a good idea
content: Hallo Karen,  Thanks a lot for taking your time and writing an answer! I really appreciate that!!  It is always good – in a way – to hear that other people have almost the same experience as I have. It makes one feel lonely a lot of times with what one has to deal with. I guess you know what I’m talking about if people tell you that they wouldn’t have guessed that you are feeling really sick by the way you look like, right? What I mean is, one can be even lucky, to look pale enough so that they have a little bit of a clue, what is going on. Who can “see” fatigue? Or maybe headaches? Sometimes it is really hard to explain what is going on with me. Sometimes I’m tired of even talking about it and explaining myself.   I am really really sorry to hear that you suffer from EBV as well. Three years is a long time and I know sooooo well when you say you barely can remember how it is to feel well. Do you feel sometimes too, IF you have a moment of feeling well, that you would like to do 20 things at the same time to use the situation of feeling healthy? By the way, right now, right here, I’m feeling like this, after having had a super bad migraine almost the whole day.  This is another thing as well: I don’t suffer just from EBV, no….I have migraines for now almost 20 years as well (over one third of my life…I’m turning 37 in two days). Of course a lot of headaches come with the EBV so I have triple times migraine.    Thank you for your suggestions. Yes, I have thought about going to a naturopathic doctor but I haven’t gone so far. Guess what? Just two days ago I was (finally) shopping for many many supplements (special vitamins and herb stuff). As you can imagine I read already a lot about how to go different ways than a “normal” doctor suggests. You know, in Germany many people suffer from EBV as well and there a many doctors as well who ignore this sickness, have no knowledge about it or do everything but treating you right. I am in a German forum as well and at least those people over there have some (as far as I know three doctors) who treat EBV. Those docs do a lot of blood work and each patient gets an individual treatment plan including different herbs.   Maybe it is a general problem of mine that I don’t trust those kinds of docs over here yet. Maybe it is just in my head that they have more knowledge in Germany. I am sorry, thinking like that. Unfortunately I can’t just jump over there and get some treatment and then come back. It would be really too expensive!   You know, I live in the states for two years now and since I am here I am sick. You can imagine, that I almost can get the idea if all this makes me sick, too……It is triple difficult to settle down in a different country with a different language and what is even harder: a DIFFERENT culture!!! Gosh, I can’t tell you how!!   It was interesting to hear what your symptoms are with the EBV. Last September a specialist (doctor for infection diseases) tested my immune system. He did a lot of blood work and he said my immune system isn’t too bad. In other words, there was no gap so that I would need for example extra Vit. D, or E, or what ever. Well, I trusted him. Shouldn’t I? :-o  Two weeks ago I was in a sleep lap. Diagnose: Hypersomnia. (Well, yes guys! I told you before!!) That doc proscribed the medication “Provigil”. Ever heard of it? It is supposed to give you more energy. Yesterday my family do proscribed some steroids again for two weeks. Oh my gosh, there must be going on a lot right now in my body with those energy makers and those supplements.  In one week I will be Arnold Schwarzenegger.   You described it so well: having EBV means having peaks and valleys. I really hope I will have a “peak” again soon to finally start working in this country and start an at least normal live again. It seems my life is on hold since I left Germany. Well, about a year ago I finally started to feel “home” here in the states (I’m mentioning that because a lot of people think of course that the one and only reason of having EBV is “being here in the states”. Well, I think it is not THAT easy…) and I thought that I could finally do all those things again that I did in Germany. I have always been sick a lot with colds and flues and such (and of course headaches) but this is too much.   Anyway, I could go on and go on but I guess I should better stop and rest so that my headaches don’t come back.  Thanks for reading and once again for responding.  Alles Gute und gute Besserung für dich – as we Germans would say! (translation: all the best and stay healthy/get well soon).   Maja

author: KarenZee  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Wed Feb 01, 2006 10:50 am Location: CT
title: EBV needs to be studied closely.
content: Hi Maja:   I agree, it is refreshing to chat with someone who understands what you are going through. I can relate to all of what you talked about, except my headaches feel like they are on the verge of a migraine, but they aren't migraine.  EBV is the perfect example of a "hidden illness". Outwardly you look fine, but how you feel is a completely different story. When I was my sickest I got so frustrated with people telling me, "You look great....I'm so glad you're feeling better". Infact, I wasn't feeling better. I know this sounds silly but sometimes I wished my hair would fall out or something so people could see and that EBV is a real illness that makes people very sick.  When you look like nothing is wrong with you and you feel sick for a long time, people begin to think you are looking for sympathy, or aren't telling the truth about how you feel. You just want your illness validated and better understood. Most regular docs don't know much about EBV, let alone how to help you get well. The advice about getting rest is of course helpful, but it isn't everything. I really do believe that there are things you can do to build yourself back up so you can recover from this terrible virus.  EBV changed my life. I had to resign my job which I could no longer perform. This was a financial burden to my family because I was paying the tuition for my son's schooling at a special needs school. I was falling asleep at meetings at work, I drove off the road twice so I wasn't safe driving, and no matter how much I slept I never felt refreshed. Chronic unrelenting fatigue!!! My sleep cycle was way off kilter and it changed constantly, terrible headaches, feeling like I was coming down with the flu, cryptic tonsils, muscle weakness in my arms and thighs and legs (I was dragging myself around), memory loss, and a mental fog that made me think I was going crazy. I'm probably not telling you about anything you haven't personally experienced yourself.  When I am feeling better I do feel like I can do all the things that I used to be able to so without a problem. And I made that mistake many times. When I overdo, I fall backwards....hence the peaks and valleys. Sometimes I'm feeling pretty good and suddenly I have a set back and I don't have a clue why? It can be very depressing. After a while people don't want to hear that you don't feel well when they ask "How are you doing?, you LOOK great." Then you just respond, "Fine, how are you?"...even when you feel like you can't take feeling sick anymore. You understand, right?   Why are you being prescribed steroids? I'd be warry about using steriods. I don't know anything about Provigil other than it stimulates the central nervous system. Why did the doc say he felt steroids were necessary? When your Vit D was tested, did they do Vit D - 25 Hydroxy? The result should be higher than 32 ng/mL. Also was your iron and ferritin level tested? Thyroid tests? Free T3, Free T4, and Antibodies?. DHEA Sulfate, Cortisol throughout the day? My labs came back positive for all of these. It is a good idea to ask for copies of all your labs so you can keep a file of your medical history, also reports for any tests you have done like the sleep study. Then when you have to visit another doctor you have everything they need in addition to being able to track things yourself.  Most insurance plans do not pay for naturopathic care, but if you can afford it find yourself a thorough ND to consult with.  I'm sorry that your illness has prevented you from transitioning to the US. What brought you to Ohio in the first place?   Let me know how you make out. I'll be thinking about you Maja. Wishing you patience and better health.

author: maja_sp  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Jan 30, 2006 7:45 pm Location: Ohio, USA
title: I had lots of examinations (ultrasound, MRI, gastrascopy)
content: Hallo Karen! I am so sorry it took me sooooo long to finally right back again. I had some awful days/weeks with being tired a lot, having a lot of pain and being frustrated a lot. I had "tones" of examinations (ultrasound of my heart, MRI of my head, gastrascopy of my stomach). In a way I am a little bit disappointed because the only thing they found was a little irritation of the bottom of my stomach. Of course I am glad, they did not find anything serious but somehow the heavy pain does not fit with the results. Difficult to describe. Before the gastrascopy I was already taking Nexium and afterwards the Doc said to continue taking it. That's it. Guess what? It does not help. Anyway....this is too long of a story.  Still I have to find a doctor who is willing to start a long-term therapie. It doesn't make any sence only to treat things that a coming up at that moment. That is treatment at the surface.   Isn't it unbelievable? I know a treatment that is used by some  doctors in Germany to treat people with Epstein-Barr-Virus and guess what? It works. But please, it is no weared treatment with mirracle medication or what ever.  It is called "Microimmuntherapie". People over here don't know it. I haven't found anybody so far.  What is this therapie? Well, difficult to put into only a few words - especially in English. I'll give it a try: highly thinned substances (cytokine, specific nucleic acid) will be given sequentially to deliver concerted information to the immune system. Through this, a defected immuns systme learns to react naturally and effectively.  Karen, your posting really touched my heart and I felt being understood. As well I feel so sorry that your life has changed as well because of this ugly illness. some people have no idea what it means to turn your life up side down. It is more than just changing one or two (bad) habits of life style. It almost feels like starting at zero and everything that used to be a finger snip is more than a big project now. I am so sorry it effects your whole family. I hope you somehow get it managed - especially thinking about the money. I hope you will find a solution for paying for your son's education.   Yes, and this is what makes it even dobble difficult: it not only effects oneself, it effects one's close family and friends as well. They feel so helpless. They have a taff time to understand and except that there is barely something that they can do (thinking about medical help). I guess in the past you had to listen to the most exciting advice as well, hadn't you? Something like: why don't you try this supplement or that? Do you drink a lot of water? Do you sleep enough? Bla bla...  Next week I'll have an appointment with ANOTHER doctor (infectious diseases). It is said, he knows something about EBV. I hope it is more than I already know. :-)  Oh, to answer one of your questions real quick: my husband is the reason why I came to the U.S. We had to take a decision who goes where. Well, my husband does not speak any German so it was an "esay" (not literally!!) decision.   How are you doing today? If I could, I would send you bags of power and energy and health. Stay strong! Many greetings, Maja

content: Hi Maja:  You've been pretty busy. I'm sorry you've had to go through so much in such a short period of time. I hope your next doctor's visits prove to be more fruitful for you. There are some 'headache sites' with good forums out there in cyber space.   Yes Maja, I've had to listen to a lot of well meaning folks give a lot of well meaning advice over the past 3 years. title: Question about Mono
content: Hi, I am an 18 year old college student. On Jan. 6 (5 weeks ago from today) I was at a party and was kissing a girl who later that night told me she had just recovered from mono. Needless to say, I was very unhappy to hear that. In addition to that I'm the type of person who is extremely paranoid about my health. Because of that I've read as much as I could find about mono online and everything said that usually symptoms occur about 4-7 weeks after infection. Well, it's been 5 weeks and I feel fine, except for one thing that began occuring a little less than a week ago. I'm assuming, and hoping, that this is due to my nature of dwelling on things like this too much, but I've been getting little pains in the left side of my abdomen. If I were to actually contract mono I wouldn't be to devestated, I would just like to know for sure. However, this little pain is bothering me (mentally, physically it's just a little pain), because I don't want any problems with my spleen. In addition to this I broke my ankle last August (6 months ago), requiring surgery to repair bone and ligaments and have just recently been able to be normal again. This means that I've been swimming everyday and playing tennis as much as possible to get back in shape again. I wouldn't want my spleen to rupture if indeed it is enlarged... basically I'm just hoping for some answers that will put me at ease, or at least some advice to calm me down, haha. Thanks for reading.

author: Dr. N. Haider  Medical Doctor Posts: 57 Joined: Sun May 01, 2005 5:13 pm Location: Lahore, Pakistan
title: [no title]
content: hi  As you should have read almost everything about the disease, I am just assuring you that this pain is not splenic rupture.  In infectious mononucleosis, the first things to appear are: fever, sore throat, headaches, white patches on the back of your throat, swollen glands in your neck, feeling tired and not feeling hungry.  Splenic involvement is RARE.  If still in doubt, get a monospot test done, you'd be negative for mono.

author: MaryAnn N, RN  Nurse Posts: 47 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 7:53 am Location: USA
title: Re: Urinary Tract Infection
content: Symptoms of UTI or bladder infection are not easy to miss and include a strong urge to urinate that cannot be delayed which is followed by a sharp pain or burning sensation in the urethra when the urine is released. Most often very little urine is released and the urine that is released may be tinged with blood. The urge to urinate recurs quickly and soreness may occur in the lower abdomen, back, or sides.  This cycle may repeat itself frequently during the day or night--most people urinate about six times a day, when the need to urinate occurs more often a bladder infection should be suspected.  When bacteria enters the ureters and spread to the kidneys, symptoms such as back pain, chills, fever, nausea, and vomiting may occur, as well as the previous symptoms of lower urinary tract infection.  Proper diagnosis is vital since these symptoms can also be caused by other problems such as infections of the vagina or vulva. Only your physician can make the distinction and make a correct diagnosis.   A urinary tract infection is treated with antibiotics, however the right one needs to be taken as that many different kinds of bacteria can cause these infections.  Hope you feel better soon.  MaryAnnRN

posted_time: Post  by Guenco » Tue Feb 07, 2006 5:43 pm

author: MaryAnn N, RN  Nurse Posts: 47 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 7:53 am Location: USA
title: Re: Tetanus 21 m
content: The tetanus vaccine will prevent you from contracting tetanus.  A booster is required every ten years.  If you sustain a wound and it has been more than 5 years since you were last vaccinated, some doctors choose to readminister the vaccine.  I would ask your doctor what his protoccol may be.   All wounds should be washed immediately with soap and water.  Keep the wound  covered during possible exposure to dirt or other contaminants.  Tetanus is not the only consequence of a contaminated wound.  If the area surrounding the wound becomes red, warm to touch, and swollen, see your doctor as soon as possible.  I hope I was helpful in answering your question.  MaryAnnRN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi AndreaIrwin, Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician.  Location: Since I am unclear of the exact location here are two views. The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx. The jugular lymph nodes lie both on top of and beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscles (SCM) on either side of the neck, from the angle of the jaw to the top of the clavicle. They drain the tongue, tonsil, pinna, parotid. Common causes of enlargement include pharyngitis organisms, rubella. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders). Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. So essentially I am saying that lymph nodes that decrease in size verses increasing in size over a 3-4 week  period of observation may more than likely be due to an infectious process. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, fatigue or night sweats could suggest disorders such as tuberculosis, lymphoma, collagen vascular diseases, unrecognized infection or malignancy so the presence of these symptoms would be more disconcerting. The presence of fever is commonly associated with infections. If you are experiencing a sore throat with white patches which includes a foul odor I would advise you to have an examination by your physician as untreated infections may result in complications. If finances are a concern such as inadequate health insurance etc. I will search for some available assistance in your area if you wish information regarding this matter. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi AndreaIrwin, Generally speaking lymph nodes 1 cm or less are considered normal except regarding the epitrochlear node (located near the elbow). Infection is a relatively common cause of lymph node enlargement and typically means that the body is functioning appropriately because the lymphatic system is the bodies defense in fighting infection, (viral/bacterial). Since you feel relatively healthy and are experiencing no constitutional symptoms, in my opinion, I would be more inclined to consider this to be of an infectious origin. I would however, advise you to have your physician examine you upon your next visit to have a more definitive opinion because nothing can replace an actual physical exam. I'm sure that your Obstetrician would be able to identify if there is a reason for concern. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: MaryAnn N, RN  Nurse Posts: 47 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 7:53 am Location: USA
title: Re: I believe I may be having signs/symptoms of HepC
content: If your swollen lymph nodes continue, I would have it checked out.  The other symptoms that you list are not necessarily symptoms of Hep C.  If you are concerned about having had contracted Hep C, you should be able to visit your local Health Department fro free or reduced cost testing.. Up to 75% of those with Hepatitis C do not have any symptoms.  Symptoms can however include, yellowing of the eyes or skin, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, pale colored stools, tea colored urine, upper abdominal pain, malaise (generalized achy feeling), fever.  There is no preventative vaccine for this disease, but it can be treated.  New research is ongoing with higher cure/ remission rates occuring.   MaryAnn RN

author: MaryAnn N, RN  Nurse Posts: 47 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 7:53 am Location: USA
title: Re: E Coli bacteria - Recurring Sore Throat
content: Hi Fairway, Yes e coli can be a very common infection.  Most people have heard of it in the news with tainted undercooked hamburger being the offending source.    E. coli is  short for the medical term Escherichia coli , which normally lives inside your intestines, where it helps your body break down and digest the food you eat.  Unfortunately, when the E. coli moves from your intestines, where it's needed, and finds its way into other parts of your body (where it is not supposed to be), you can become ill.  Not only can you get upper respiratory infections with e-coli, but they are responsible as well for urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal illnesses.  Now that you have found the offending bacteria responsible for your throat infection you should be starting to feel much better.  If the symptoms return, call your doctor again.  Sometime a longer course of anibiodics are needed to completly treat the infection.  MaryAnnRN
posted_time: Post  by MaryAnn N, RN » Sun Jan 29, 2006 7:11 am

He had very bad vascular problems in his lower legs and developed some form of pneumonia. I was  constantly in close contact with him and spent a lot of time in the hospital with him. author: MaryAnn N, RN  Nurse Posts: 47 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 7:53 am Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi Rick, You have a very wise conciensous doctor.  Doing a second culture after treatment is to ensure that treatment has been sucessful.  Especially in your case, with the difficulty you have had in clearing your infection.  In answer to your second question, no not all cultures are alike.  It depends on what they test for as that different bacteria need different mediums to grow in.  Your third question, could your spending so much time with your father in the hospital have anything to do with your infection. Perhaps, but you could have also caught this infection anywhere.  And besides it sounds like you have just been thrrough a very stressful time in your life with losing your father.  Stress can lower our resistence to infection and thereby make you more suseptilbe to illness. So can lack of sleep which I am sure you did lose alot of with your father being so sick.    Take it easy,  I sure hope you feel better soon.  MaryAnn RN

author: No Name Needed  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Jan 28, 2006 11:23 pm Location: Indiana
title: Recurring Puss or Stones on Tonsil
content: Note: If I was supposed to post this under ear nose and throat, I tried, but there was no "post new topic" button.  About two weeks ago, I went to the doctor because I had white stuff on my tonsils.  There was one large patch, then two smaller patches.  I had no other symptoms.  My throat wasn't even sore.  He did a throat culture.  It was negative for strep, but he told me that it wasn't always conclusive and decided to put me on amoxicilin for ten days.  I took it as instructed.  About five days into it, I developed a cold.  Whether this was part of the original condition, or not, I wasn't sure.  My throat got sore during this cold, and I had pretty bad congestion.  It was also around this time that I noticed that what I assumed was puss could be scraped off with a swab.  It was a relatively hard ball, about pea sized.  And I could fainly see a bit more up in the crypt of my tonsil.  I got through the 10 days of antibiotics and felt fine.  No white stuff on my throat.  Cold was gone also with the exception of a bit of post-nasal drip, but that was minor.  I've been off of antibiotics for 7 days now.  At work tonight, I noticed that I had the white thing again.  And once again, no other symptoms.  I am a diagnosed Anxiety Disorder/Panic Disorder, and thus I kind of freaked out.  I'm settled a bit down now, but I wonder if I need to go back to the doctor.  I have a tendency to overreact.  My thinking is, if it was strep, it should have been taken care of.  I know there's a thing called Tonsil stones, and that could be it.  But my worrisome thoughts dwell on the slight possibility of something majorly wrong.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi VivaUltra, Sexually transmitted diseases can essentially be ruled out as a causative factor if you have not had unprotected sexual intercourse. A condition, for example, Balanitis, is an inflammatory condition of the penis which may present with redness and rash, often occurs in uncircumcised males and may be caused by a fungal origin. I would strongly suggest that rather than attempting treatment without a diagnosis that you have your mom notify your physician for an evaluation so that a proper diagnsis and treatment can be initiated. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: Reactivated Brown Recluse Bite
content: 12 years ago I got bitten by a brown recluse spider on my lower left leg/calf.  The first Dr. didn't treat it properly and I had to go to another Dr. for wound debridement.  He informed me that I may need a skin graft if the wound doesn't heal.  With careful wound care I lucked out and the wound healed in 18 months.  No skin graft was needed, but I have scar tissue.   In August.... I had an allergic reaction to Soma at the bite location.  2 weeks later the wound reactivated with the tissue/skin necrosis.  All the dead tissue peeled away and I have a dollar size wound that is trying to heal.  Healing has gone so far and then stopped.  I've been to the Dr. for 4 months who gave me prophylatic Keflex.  He sent to me a vascular surgeon.  This Dr. insists that it is a varicose ulcer and is treating it as such.  He won't listen to me.  I told him I was allergic to Sulfa and he gave me Dyazide.  You can't take Dyazide if you are allergic to Sulfa!!  I don't have high blood pressure either.  It is usually low. My question is who do I see about this.  It is very, very painful and I believe that I may need a skin graft this time around.  I don't want to wait another 3-4 months with this wound and then find out that it is being improperly treated.  None of the Drs. here(ND) are familar with insect bites.  Thank you very much for your time and assistance!!

title: Update
content: Went to a new walk in clinic 5 days after the specialist put on the compression bandage.  The new Dr. said the bandage was on too tight and culture showed Staph Aureus. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tashamonster, The typical definition of a fever is a body temperature greater than 98.6 degrees F or 37 degrees C. A low body temperature would not be considered a fever. The other symptoms you describe headache, sinus pressure, etc. of course may indicate an infection which may be present without initially having an elevated temperature. You may want to contact your physicians office for an evaluation if symptoms persist. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

content: Lately I've noticed very small, tiny, white round things that look like tiny balls in my feces. I am on 3 different kinds of meds that are capsule form. posted_time: Post  by Minusnite » Fri Feb 25, 2005 8:37 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Minusnite, In regards to your other post: http://www.doctorslounge.com/forums/vie ... ight=#9961 Frequency, urgency, any burning sensation etc. all are symptoms of a urinary tract infection. Just because you had a clear urinalysis 2 months ago doesn't necessarily mean it cotinues to be clear. I would suggest another evaluation and if it is negative then a workup regarding the kidney stones and ovarian cysts should be completed. Now, regarding this post, the tiny white balls in your stool...is there any abdominal cramps, diarrhea etc. that accompany these symptoms? There is a condition called giardia which is a parasitic infection from drinking water and small cystlike objects are found in the stool. Although some people may have a parasitic infection and have no signs and symptoms, some symptoms when they do ocurr are diarrhea, foul smelling stool, and abdomial cramps and weight loss. A microscopic study is done on the stool to identify it. It takes 3 stool samples to diagnose this conditon. Giardia is treated with a course of antibiotics. In any case I would suggest a physicians evaluation. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Had the same situation and found the problem, which is really not a problem.  A med I take "Tegretol XR" had the same glaze look to it as the little white ball.  I looked up the info that comes with my med, and this is this info: "The tablet coating of the Tegretol XR formulation is not absorbed in the body and may be found in the stool".  WHAT a RELIEF!!!  The pill is formulated to release slowly in the body.  So it's very possible that other meds may do the same thing.  The Tegretol XR has a tiny, tiny hole in the middle so that explains how it is a little larger than the pill.  Hope this helps!

title: [no title]
content: Hi Jester, Adult forms of tapeworms may become quite large in length and are typically ribbon shaped. That's not to say that eggs aren't present from this parasite or another for that matter. A test used to identify if a parasitic infection is present is done on the stool (feces/bowel movements). This condition is certainly treatable and it would be in her best interest to call her physician. Encourage her to go in for an evaluation to identify if this is the causative factor.  Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi RichMan, Was the evaluation based over the telephone by the description you gave or was it based on actual examination? Generally speaking, occasionally medications will not be absorbed by the time the intestinal tract empties if there happens to be increased motility at that time for one reason or another but these are generally coated (enteric) medications. If the determination was made from a description you gave rather than an actual evaluation, I would suggest that if this occurs again, collect the specimen and take it into the physician's office for testing. Do not rely on information of what it "could" be based on solely a telephone call. That's my thoughts on the matter :) Have a Happy New Year! Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Concerned Parent  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Dec 29, 2005 6:18 pm Location: Philadelphia
title: Pink Eye
content: My 15 year old son awoke 4 days ago with a red right eye that was irritated and tearing.  Two days later, the left eye became red.  He went to see his primary care physician who told him he had an “infection in his eyes” and prescribed a topical antibiotic drop four times a day.  After two days, his eyelids were more swollen, red and irritated.  I went back to his PCP because he was not getting better.  He changed his antibiotic drops but wanted to make sure something more serious wasn’t going on.  My son was referred to a local ophthalmologist who suspected viral conjunctivitis but said it was a little unusual to see so much discharge.  He asked me if I wanted to have a new test performed on his tears that could help confirm the diagnosis.  I thought it was best to know.  The ophthalmologist lowered his eyelid and collected some tears on what looked like a pregnancy test.  About ten minutes later, the test was positive and confirmed the diagnosis of viral conjunctivitis.  It was nice to have a definitive answer but I wish it had been done sooner.  As it turns out, my son was probably allergic to the first antibiotic and this was likely making his condition worse.  He was kept out of school for a full week and we used over the counter artificial tears until the redness improved.  Unfortunately, my daughter and husband both caught the same virus but at least they did not waste time trying antibiotic drops and I didn’t bother returning to my PCP.  If so many family doctors use the rapid strep test why don't they also use an rapid eye test?
posted_time: Post  by Concerned Parent » Thu Dec 29, 2005 6:51 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Concerned Parent, There may be an issue with availability concerning the equipment and testing procedures from one office to another. The Ophthalmologist's  office would of course be first in line for availability since they specialize in eye disorders. A General Practioner may not have this option. It may however, be to the benefit of other patients, if you were to discuss this with your physician whenever possible as he/she may want to attempt obtaining this for their particular practice. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

posted_time: Post  by ann123 » Wed Dec 28, 2005 6:09 pm

author: gstep  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Wed Dec 28, 2005 7:20 pm Location: Butler Co., Ohio
title: strep throat
content: It is important to see your family doctor to diagnose your sore throat as "strep throat".  Antibiotics can be used for strep throat, a bacterial infection,  but not the typical "sore throat" because they are viral infections.  To answer your question; strep throat does not have to be treated with antibiotics.  If left untreated there is a chance that strep throat can turn in to rheumatic fever, or even kidney disease.  Typically strep throat goes away on its own in 3-7 days.  Your doctor should ultimately decide if treatment is necessary.
posted_time: Post  by gstep » Wed Dec 28, 2005 7:41 pm

author: ann123  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Dec 28, 2005 5:36 pm Location: kentucky
title: [no title]
content: Thank you for your reply. I went to the doctor today and I do have a very nasty case of strep throat. I didn't know a throat could hurt so much. She gave me the same advice you did.
posted_time: Post  by ann123 » Thu Dec 29, 2005 6:12 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ann123, I am certainly glad to hear that you went for an evaluation by your physician. A sore throat from a virus is completely different from a sore throat caused by the bacteria streptococcus (strep). A sore throat caused by the gram positive bacteria streptococcus always requires a course of antibiotic therapy. Untreated streptococcal illnesses can cause numerous complications, for example, acute rheumatic fever,  post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, etc. Rheumatic fever develops about two-three weeks after an untreated streptococcal infection and causes joint pain and heart disease. I certainly hope that a swab test was completed and if it was positive, antibiotic therapy was initiated. Get well soon! Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: TINY RED SPOTS ON PENIS
content: It is difficult to give an opinion without an examination.  However, if you have pinhead-sized raised spots of a flesh or faintly red colour on the glans of the penis which are asymptomatic, it is suggestive of a genital skin disorder known as lichen nitidus. Treatment is often ineffective and the patient is usually advised to ignore it after explanation. The condition usually resolves spontaneously within a few months.   You should however consult a dermatovenereologist for an opinion, because you had unprotected sex with a partner whose status is unknown. This becomes urgent and mandatory if the picture changes and you start to experience symptoms.  I hope this information is helpful.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ?? PAPULAR GENITAL WART
content: Please get it examined by a dermatologist or genitourinary physician. It could be a papular wart, which is caused by the human papilloma virus, but without physical examination, it is impossible to confirm the diagnosis. The finding of a wart in that area is suggestive of a genital wart, which is a sexually transmitted disease. Therefore, if confirmed, full STD screening is mandatory for you and your partners.   The other possibility is a mollusc, a single lesion of molluscum contagiosum, but this is usually a pearly-white, umbilicated   papular lesion which does not match your description.  Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mayo, A Bartholin's gland cyst may present as an enlarged area "lump" in one of the vaginal lips near the opening of the vagina. When an abcess occurs these become very tender and painful. Secondary infections of these particular cysts may include infections with the bacteria ecoli, (ecoli bacteria is normally present in the intestinal tract) Cysts are drained, oral antibiotics are generally prescribed, depending on the bacteria present. Warm soaks may be suggested to ensure drainage of the area is complete. Another factor to keep in mind, if after going to the bathroom, if she is wiping from back to front, tell her to wipe from front to back. This will prevent transfer of this bacteria into that area. A Gynecologist is the physician whom in which she should be being evaluated. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

Here is the situation I have had chronic otitis media going on since my surgery in 2002. I had a tympano plasty done to repair a perforated drum 3 all together but 2 were in 2002. None of them took still perforated which I thought was the reasons for the infections ongoing. Recently the primary care physcian cultured my ear and said it came back mrsa positive. That I contracted it through my surgery in 2002. She said the infection was very old and there was pus as far as the eye could see excuse the terminology. Also the could not rule out the possibility of a cholesteatoma from the infection.I recently got my records (chart) from them for the new Neuro-otolarynologist I am going to see. I read in there that near the time of my surgery they wrote down mastioditis in which they gave me amoxicillian for. I am SO confused. If I had mrsa in my ear how could I have had this so long? I have been very sick for a long time but I have never had any skin lesions like I have heard most with mrsa do. Just have ear infections. Well I guess I should not leave out all the other symptoms dizziness, fatigue, headache/migraine, nasuea, sinusitis, allergies, and asthma.Also any moisture in the air gives me headache I guess because of the infections in the ear and hole. Are there different kinds that can localize to one area? What should my next course of action be. Should I get retested somewhere else? Can you get mrsa from surgery and it just remain active in the one area?She put me on 2, 21 days of Bactrim- which means all in all I took this antibiotic for 42 days.  Are there diff. strains of this infection. I do not think this is CA-MRSA because I have no lesions and have not had any bed sores or infections at other surgical sites. Thanks so very much

title: Swollen lymph nodes - infection or something else?
content: I've had a few swollen lymph nodes on the left side of my neck for about 3 months now. They are not at all painful, and they seem to have been increasing (slightly) in size. About a week ago, I noticed another swollen node above my collar bone on the right side. This one feels very firm, but is still not painful. I haven't had any fevers or anything, but I have been extrememly tired all the time, and I have lost some weight.   I went to see my doctor for this about 2 1/2 months ago, and she gave me a pretty strong antibiotic, which did nothing. So I went back to see her a couple days ago, and she did some tests. She did a strep test and mono test, and both were negative. She also did a CBC, but I don't know the results of that yet (by the way, the last time I had a CBC, about 4 months ago, I had an elevated WBC). The doctor seemed very concerned, but couldn't make a diagnosis, though she did say she didn't think it was an infection. She sent me to a specialist that same day, and he just poked around on my neck and said it was nothing. I don't believe that, because my GP seemed very concerned - enough to ask this other doctor to stay at his office late in order to see me that day. Anyway, the specialist did order a CT scan, so I'm going in for that next week.  Needless to say, I am pretty confused - and a little nervous. This couldn't be anything serious, could it? I feel fine other than the tiredness, but I would really like to know what's going on.  Any help on this would be greatly appreciated.

title: Question regarding "mono spot" test
content: Hi, I was told a week and a half ago I am positive for mono using the monospt test. I was sick for a good two to almost 3 weeks before this diagnosis. I was also not feeling up to par for a week or two prior to developing the first "real" symptoms of mono. It felt almost as if I was kind of sick then felt ok for a week and then got worse. I have to add that I was on a work related trip to Alaska when this diagnosis was made. My sleep schedule and duration was turned upside down and I also wasn't eating like I normally do. My normal climate is a subtropical climate with high humidity, Alaska was an arctic desert. In addition I didn't really have the classic swollen lymph nodes and severe sore throat but I felt really out of it for a week or two. I was also tachycardic during that time, around 100 bpm. The doctors originally thought I was just dehydrated, which I probably was.  My question is will  the mono spot test will show positive if you have any antibodies in your blood (like from a past infection)?. I am a little confused because it seems to me like the monospot will show positive if you have ever had mono in the past.  I really want to follow up on this just to make sure it isn't anything more serious.   I still feel very tired but don't have any swelling and an only slightly irritated throat. I also have a chest pain that lasts for a few seconds and then goes away maybe once or twice a day. It's been a month now and I still can't work because of the fatigue. Luckily I'm not losing money because of it. Any help or encouragement would be greatly appreciated!

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ssublime1, I will try to give you some information about mono tests. A monospot is a test that identifies a current infection. The test that identifies a previous viral infection is called an Epstein-Barr viral antibody titer. This is how current and previous infections are distinguished. Lab findings for current infections often include elevated white blood cells, some of which may have an unusual appearance. An enlarged spleen and liver abnormalities may also be present. Swollen lymph nodes, enlarged spleen may resolve in about 4 weeks or so. Fatigue may resolve in a matter of weeks but may last for 2-3 months. Treatment for mono is usually directed at treating symptoms. Antibiotics are not effective. Acetaminophen or ibuprofen for discomfort and fever, warm salt water gargles for sore throats, plenty of rest and fluids, and if the spleen is enlarged, avoiding any activity that may cause abdominal injury to avoid spleenic ruptures. You certainly should have a follow up evaluation to check your health status and avoid any other complications. I hope this answers some of your questions and hopefully you will get well soon  Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: NON-INFECTIVE GENITAL ULCERATION
content: Genital ulceration may be due to infective  or non-infective causes. Infective causes are sexually transmitted and include syphilis, chancroid, genital herpes, LGV and granuloma inguinale. The last two conditions are more commonly seen in the tropics and subtropics.  As you have had no sexual exposure, it must be assumed that your recurrent genital ulceration is due to non-infective causes. However, a repeat test for HSV 1 and 2 at the next outbreak is advisable.  Trauma, Behcet's disease, Stevens-Johnson syndrome and carcinoma are  non-infective causes of genital ulceration. In your case, carcinoma is excluded because the ulcers are not persistent, not growing larger and tend to heal on their own but recur intermittently at the same site.   Traumatic genital ulcers may be caused by vigorous manipulation of the penile organ, such as in prolonged and  repetitive acts of masturbation, which is not admitted. A common site is the frenulum of the penis, which is the site you are attempting to describe. Behcet's disease is usually accompanied by mouth ulcers. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a hypersensitivity of acute onset, frequently caused by infection or certain drugs and may occasionally cause genital ulcers, mouth ulcers and a conjunctivitis.  At the next outbreak of these ulcers, please get examined by a genitourinary physician for diagnosis and reassurance.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM
content: Transmission of the molluscum contagiosum virus is by skin-to-skin contact. Children and sexually active adults are usually affected. Lesions in children occur on exposed skin sites, but in sexually active adults, the virus is transmitted during sexual activity and lesions occur in or around the genital region.   Sharing a bed may involve skin-to-skin contact if clothing is not worn, so transmission of the virus is possible but not definite.  Confirmation of the diagnosis by a dermatologist or genitourinary physician is advisable before breaking the news to your girlfriend. The presence of one STD should prompt a search for others; therefore, if the condition is confirmed, a full STD screen becomes mandatory for you and your partner.  In an immunocompetent host, mollusca usually persist for up to 6 months and then resolve spontaneously. If immediate treatment is required, the lesions can be removed in a doctor’s office with little discomfort. In HIV-infected individuals, mollusca often progress even with aggressive therapies, creating significant cosmetic disfigurement, especially by facial lesions.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: Does your cat have her rabies shot? All animals are required to get rabies shots. If she has rabies, you would need to take her to the vet immediatly, as animals with rabies will become very mean. As for the question, if your mother used a peroxide bottle to pour peroxide on the cat, then you used the same bottle, no, you cannot get rabies that way.  Rabies is spread through the saliva of a rabid animal, not through blood. You would need to get bitten by an animal infected by rabies, or exposed to that animals saliva.

title: High fevers and sharp, jabbing, unbearable head pains...
content: Hi folks:  I wonder if you could perhaps give me a few possible diagnoses for what this could be.  Here are the symptoms: 1.  High fevers (up to 103), temporarily relieved by ibuprofen but them comes back. 2.  Generalized mild  achiness and stiffness, most noticeable in the spine, but also armpits, etc. 3.  Excruciating jabbing pains on one side of the head when fever is highest.  These pains are intermittent, maybe 2 seconds on, 3 seconds off.  They are more intense than labor pains (to my memory; I had an unmedicated childbirth).  The headache is also relieved for the most part by 1600 mg of ibuprofen, though not completely. 4.  No URI symptoms other than stuffiness due to dry mucous membranes and very slight chest heaviness. 5.  No UTI symptoms. 6.  Mild anorexia and mild nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea, no abdominal pain other than generalized achiness mentioned above.  Thanks!

title: [no title]
content: It is very unlikely to get herpes from the fluid seeping through her jeans, because this fluid would need to seep though your jeans, through your boxers, and make it inside your penis.  It is possible to get herpes if you came in contact with any of her vaginal fluids, and then touched your penis.   You can get herpes even if you canot see any sores on the womans vagina. She can have sores inside the vagina which would not be visable, or she would not be having an outbreak at the time, but even if there is no outbreak, it is still possible to transmit herpes.   You are correct, the symptoms you describe are symptoms of herpes, but can also be symptoms of something else.  There is really no way to know for sure without an STD test, so I recommend that you get tested as soon as possible, to ease your mind, or get treatment.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: Your parents do not need to know, nor will the clinic tell them without your consent. They are not allowed to violate your patient confidentiality.  Symptoms of herpes are called outbreaks. The first outbreak appears within 2 weeks after you become infected and can last for several weeks. These symptoms might include tingling or sores near the area where the virus has entered the body, such as on the genital or rectal area, on buttocks or thighs, or occasionally on other parts of the body where the virus has entered through broken skin. They also can occur inside the vagina and on the cervix in women, or in the urinary passage of women and men. Small red bumps appear first, develop into small blisters, and then become itchy, painful sores that might develop a crust and will heal without leaving a scar.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: The chances of you having it are very unlikely. The way to diagnose herpes is by looking at the sores on the penis. Without looking at them, I cannot tell you if you have it or not. It does not sound like herpes. While some of the symptoms you describe are consistant with herpes, the main symptom is lesions on the penis, and the sores you describe do not sound like herpes.  It is possible to get herpes even if you cannot see sores on the woman. There are two reasons for this. She can have an outbreak, inside the vagina, which would not be visable on the outside, or she can not be having an outbreak at the moment. Although it is harder to contract herpes if there is no outbreak at the time, it is still possible that the virus can shed. In general, studies suggest that asymptomatic shedding with subsequent viral transmission to another person possibly accounts for one-third of all HSV-2 infections.  I do not think that you have it, as I have said, it is very unlikely to get it in the manner you have described, but I still think you should go to a doctor, if only to put your mind to rest.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: Yes, if she has a cold sore on her lip and gives you oral sex, it is possible to spread herpes that way. A cold sore on the lip would be HSV 1, and genitial herpes is HSV 2. You can get oral herpes from kissing someone with oral herpes, and it is possible to give oral sex and contract genitial herpes.   You will get skin lesions 2-12 days after exposure. The first sign of infection is fluid accumulation (edema) at the infection site, which is quickly followed by small, grouped blisters, the characteristic HSV lesions.  Primary herpes is often accompanied by fever rising to about 102°F, muscle aches, headache, and flu-like malaise. These general symptoms usually resolve within a week.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: If a girl has no cold sores present and gives oral sex, then the chances are low that she can spread herpes, but there is about a 5 % chance that she can still spread herpes through the saliva. Also be aware that if you have a cold sore on your mouth, and touch it, then touch other parts of your body, you can spread the herpes virus to other parts of your body.

title: Sudden Generalized Joint Pain in 28yr old
content: Since this is now looking to be possibly some type of infection, instead of an orthopedic problem....I'm going to post this here and see if anyone has any advice. Thanks!   Posted: Tue May 31, 2005 3:41 pm  About three weeks ago, I began having sorness and tingling in my left foot and calf. My big toe and across the top of my foot was very sore, and the outside edge and the two smallest toes on the same foot went from tingling (like when your foot falls asleep), to being numb. This went on for about a week. I thought I must have done something, and figured with some advil and a few days it would get better. But, instead of getting better..it started up in the right leg and foot as well. Then it got to be both feet, legs, and my lower back. Although I couldn't think of anything I had done...I still figured I must have hurt my back somehow, and it was probably just a pinched nerve or something, and that with taking it easy and some time it would get better. Then on Saturday I woke up and every joint in my body was sore and stiff. I felt like I had the flu x 10...but I haven't had any other flu like symptoms (no fever, head or chest congestion, etc.). The joint pain and stiffness seems worse in the morning, and gradually over the day will get a little better. I've had arthritis in my wrists from an old injury for years, but they usually only bother my in really cold weather, or when I've done something repetitive and over-used them. Then they will swell and be stiff and sore. All my joints feel like that right now, but there doens't seem to be any swelling, redness, and no previous injuries. So, I don't know what's going on. If I wake up tomorrow and it's as bad as it was this morning, I'm going to call and see if I can make an appointment with my doctor. I'm just wondering if anyone has any idea what this might be? I've had family/friends suggest lyme disease (haven't been near any woods or animals...haven't seen any ticks), flu (no other flu symptoms, and it's been going on for 3 weeks), rhematoid arthritis (don't know much about this...so couldn't say), and multiple sclerosis (only because my aunt was diagnosed 2 years ago, and hers began with numbess in her feet and legs). I thought maybe it was just a virus or infection...but it's been going on for 3 weeks now...and besides the joint pain and not sleeping well...I haven't had any other symptoms.  Thanks for your time and help! J

title: Lab Results
content: We got the lab results back. They did a "CBC with Differential / Platelet", "Comp. Metabolic Panel", "Rheumatiod Arthritis Factor", "Antinuclear Antibodies Direct", and "Sedimentation Rate". The doctor says that although there are some items elevated, there isn't anything that conclusively tells him what is causing the joint and muscle pain. So, he wants to refer me to a Rheumatologist. I called and can't get an appointment until July 25th. Sad So, for now I wait...and keep wondering. There were 4 things in my lab results that showed to be elevated.  White Blood Cell Count 11.3 H x10E3/uL Limits 4.0-10.5  RDW 16.0 H % Limits 11.7-15.0  Neutrophils (Absolute) 8.2 H x10E3/uL Limits 1.8-7.8  ALT (SGPT) 46 H IU/L Limits 0-40  None of these seem to be very high over the limits. But, in February, before all this started, I had a complete physical, and all these were within the normal range. So, it is quite a change in 4 months. Not sure if it means anything, or helps to figure out what's going on. The RA Factor, ANA, and sed-rate, all seem ok (see below).  Rhematiod Arthritis Factor - RA Latex Turbid. 6.6 IU/mL Limits 0.0-13.9  Antinuclear Antibodies Direct 33 U/mL Limits: Negative <100  Sedimentation Rate - Westergren 15 mm/hr Limits 0-20  Antistreptolysin O Antibodies 31.6 IU/mL Limits 0.0-200.0  Does any of this help to give a clue as to what's going on?  I also asked my doctor about "Cat Scratch" disease/fever. Several months ago my nephew (he's 7) began complaining of his leg hurting. At first his parents just thought he pulled something playing rough or jumping on the trampoline. But when he kept on talking about it, they got him down and realized the lymph nodes in his leg/groin area were very swollen and hard. They took him to the doctor, who did lots of tests, and an MRI. They could see that something had many of the lymph nodes in his leg swollen, and his WBC was elevated on his lab results, but they couldn't figure out what was causing it. They tried two rounds of anti-biotics, with no improvement. They finally sent him to a Children's Hospital to see an oncologist. The oncologist first wanted to take some blood and do a culture for "Cat Scratch" fever. It took 9 days to get it back, but it was positive. They gave him a different kind of anti-biotic and he recovered quickly and has been great since then. As I said, I asked my doctor about this, because I had also been around my nephew's new kitten, but the doctor doesn't seem to think this could be a possibility. Granted, I don't remember getting scratched...but neither did my nephew, and they could never find a scratch on him. I even called back to the doctors office Friday morning, and asked that since we have to wait a month for me to get in to see the Rheumotologist, could we go ahead and test for the "cat scratch" just to be sure. The nurse said she would ask the doctor, and someone would call me back. It's Tuesday night, and so far no one has called back.  I'm not sure what to do at this point......

author: psukittenz  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Apr 18, 2005 12:04 pm Location: Pennsylvania
title: Can you make sense of this?
content: Hi. I am a 23 year old female student with no previously diagnosed chronic medical problems.  In mid February I contracted infectious mononucleosis (which initially presented itself by a flat red rash on both forearms) confirmed by a monospot test, atypical lymphocytes etc.  The acute mono ran its course. It turned out that I got the gastrointestinal variant of IM, and the acute phase was actually not that bad.  I was still able to attend most classes.  When the acute phase was about up my doctor thought that she saw some swelling in my uvula, so as a "preventative measure" she prescribed a short course of corticosteroids.  I had bad nervous side effects (heat flashes, tingling in both forearms, dizziness, insomnia) so I discontinued the pills after a day and a half with my doctor's consent.  After that it seemed as though I just got weaker - even weaker than during the acute phase.  I was easily tired by ordinary activities.  I also began experiencing symptoms that could easily be attributed to anxiety and depression - such as tingling and numbness in my extremities, muscle spasms, headaches of a kind unlike I had ever experienced, mild insomnia, stomach pain, SEVERE gas, night sweats, breathlessness, etc.  It got so bad that I began having panic attacks (I'm not sure what else to call them).  After a horrifying episode where my body seemed to have limitless adrenaline, I didn't get any decent sleep for 3 days. I  actually had to be admitted to the hospital under the diagnosis of major depression (I also got a UTI at that point for which I took Cipro).  When I left my diagnosis had changed to a panic disorder with agoraphobia.  It has been 1 week since I was discharged, and I've been taking paxil for 3 weeks.  I had a whole slew of blood tests and cat scans of my head and stomach at the hospital - I gather to rule out some medical problems.  I am feeling a lot more energetic and happy, and I actually do vigorous exercise for 1/2 hour every other day and am not exhausted by it.  However, i still have mild aches in the front of my head, intermittant weakness in my legs and forearms, muscle twitching, brain fog, mild gas, some constipation, and weird pelvic symptoms.  I know it sounds weird but I have soreness in my bladder area, in my vaginal area, and in my anal area too!  I also have frequency.  Note that after my Cipro was gone I was retested for urinary tract bacteria with a midstream catch and a 72 hr. culture with no growth.  I also had a pelvic exam - everything looked ok but the result of the pap is not back yet.  What I am wondering is this: I know that anxiety and depression can cause seemingly unrelated and quite severe symptoms in some cases - which is probably why I have the diagnosis I do.  However, are there any underlying medical conditions (possibly triggered by mono) which may be causing my sumptoms?  What about neurological disorders or  Lyme Disease? Thank you!

content: Mononucleosis cannot be "given back" as the virus remains forever in the body, dormant in the cells.  Generally, a person does not redevelop mononucleosis, but there is a possibility.    Be sure to keep this in check with your physician as mono can cause liver damage.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: INFECTIOUS MONONUCLEOSIS
content: If you were exposed to the Epstein-Barr virus which causes infectious mononucleosis, you build up antibodies and are immune and will not contract the disease again.  If your friend's infection was accurately doctor-diagnosed 5 years ago, she cannot be having the disease again.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Akai  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Oct 19, 2005 7:12 pm Location: Los Angeles,CA  Contact:   Contact Akai       AOL
title: Began Chest Pressure/Headache. Now Headache/Upper Spine
content: Seven weeks ago I came down with the worst cold I've ever had while working in the Mountains under swinging weather extremes. That cold lasted three days, one of which saw me so fatigued I literally could not move.  Came back to LA, was totally fine for three weeks and then got a serious bout of chest pressure mixed with light-headedness and headache. Saw a doctor, began taking Ibuprofin. Condition then morphed into mild chest pressure/pain accompanied by occasional pressure behind my eyes and a "pressure feeling" in my head (not quite a headache, though similar) that made me feel—for lack of a better word—loopy or not quite there. This head pressure (which has the characteristics of a dull headache) is almost ALWAYS directly preceded by a mild headache that begins in the back of my head and travels from the base of my neck around to my forehead. The two strangest aspects of this phenomenon are the sudden plugging and/or ringing of my ears and a congestive wall of pressure at the front of my face. I’ll tell you, it’s quite strange to find yourself mid-sentence projecting a voice that’s suddenly not yours.  I saw the same doctor again and got an EKG, 2D-ECHO, and FULL PHYSICAL with blood work (the specific tests the blood was run through I can't say, but there were at least five different tubes of blood pulled from me). She told me all the tests came back "normal" and that she thought I had a chest inflammation and said to take Claritin and Motrin. On a whim I switched from Motrin to Aleve and that seemed to work MUCH better for the pain.  Now the chest pain/pressure is 95 percent gone but I still have at least twice daily the facial/head congestion and the weird headache (though less aggressive under the Claritan/Aleve combo).  The new development (AND WHAT WORRIES ME MOST, THUS THIS POST) is the feeling of being in a "fog" or "bubble" that's ALWAYS present, a thing that makes me feel like I'm moving in slow motion or walking in lead shoes, "loopy or not quite there", and a sharp tension/pain in my upper spine that’s been constant the past four days.  And lastly, the one wrench in all this is that in an office of 9 people, 7 have spent at least one sick day in the last five weeks. There’s a woman here who actually has complained of the same symptoms mentioned above; everyone else has cried flu.  I trust my doctor, but this is scaring the *bleep* out of me.  Has anyone heard of a bug or bacterial disorder that takes this course?
posted_time: Post  by Akai » Wed Oct 19, 2005 7:55 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: You have stated that you had a full physical examination and blood tests which were both reported as "normal".  Did you undergo an imaging procedure of any of the following regions of your body:  a) your sinuses b) your cervical spine  c) your chest ?  The history of a very bad cold under extreme weather conditions, lightheadedness, headache, facial and head pressure, pressure behind the eyes and ringing in your ears may be suggestive of a sinus problem. This will not be revealed in blood tests, so it is advisable to exclude that.  Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ACUTE TONSILLITIS
content: Your symptoms are indicative of acute tonsillitis - an upper respiratory tract infection.  This is a generalised inflammation of the tonsils (seen as red bumps in back of throat) usually accompanied by an inflammation of the pharynx (seen as very red and swollen throat). The infecting agent may be bacterial or viral. Bacterial infection may be caused by Streptococci, Pneumococci, Staphylococci and Haemphilus influenzae.  The most common complaints in acute tonsillitis are fever, a very sore throat, pain on swallowing, malaise and loss of appetite. In severe inflammation of the tonsils, pus may be seen on the surface of the tonsils and this is what you may have described as white patches.  An adequate intake of fluids is advised, as well as antipyretics to relieve the fever pending a doctor's examination. If the inflammation is of bacterial origin and severe as it seems to be in your case, the doctor will prescribe antibiotic treatment after a throat swab to identify the causative organism.    Keep the appointment with your doctor!  Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. L. Chu Go  Medical Doctor Posts: 41 Joined: Fri May 27, 2005 9:08 am Location: Philippines  Contact:   Contact Dr. L. Chu Go       Yahoo Messenger
title: Hi
content: Hello jj1994,  Basically, penicillin is the first line drug of choice for treatment against the microorganisms causing rheumatic fever which is streptococci (specifically group A-Beta hemolytic strep). If you frequently have attacks of sore throat and then have manifestations or symptoms similar to the one you are feeling right now, then it is advisable that you have booster doses of penicillin via intramuscular injection.   As for your other medications like prednisone - this is an anti-inflammatory drug which help lessen the swelling of your joints however the draw back is that your immune response may also be lowered hence the decrease in your WBC.   It is much better to consult with your cardiologist because if your rheumatic fever still continues or worsen, your heart valves may eventually be affected which in turn could lead to rheumatic heart disease <if your valve(s) is/are affected - most commonly the mitral valve which is situated between your left atrium and left ventricle of the heart>  I hope you are somehow enlightened with what you are feeling right now.  Sincerely, M.D.

author: dlugose  Guest Posts: 38 Joined: Tue Feb 22, 2005 6:08 pm Gender: Male Location: Boulder, CO, USA
title: [no title]
content: By now I hope your swelling and apparent infection are healed?  Don't ever use your fingernail on any scratch or break in the skin.  You could have tried to get out a splinter with a pin or needle, cleaned with alcohol or in a flame.  Don't squeeze pus out, use gentle pressure to get it to flow out through an opening that is already there.  Too much pressure can spread an infection into deeper healthy tissue.  By now the hydrogen peroxide has already helped if it was going to help.  Don't use it too many days on the same wound because it delays healing.  If the swelling has subsided and you have not been having fevers, you should be ok by now.

author: Michele P, RN  Nurse Posts: 59 Joined: Mon Jul 25, 2005 10:26 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I normally do not add an opinion to another mods advice, but in this case, I would like to give some advice. Sorry.   I personally have a navel ring, along w/a nose ring &would like to give you the DO's & don't'S of piercing care.   don't USE PEROXIDE or alcohol, or any astringent because not only can it damage the wound, it also can destroy the cells that form scar tissue.  don't use creams or ointments (neosporin). They keep the wound moist & delay the healing process. Also - & I did this once w/my nose - I had taken the ring out because there was some redness around my nose & applied neosporin after cleaning because that was all I had at home. That served as a coating that actually closes up thehole.   DON'T wear tight clothes because they can cause the piercing to grow out  DON'T remove the ring during the healing phase because you will lose the piercing.   DO'S: antibacterial soap (daily while bathing). Sea-salt, table-salt (both in warm water) or saline solution - rinse w/that then dry throroughly w/a clean towel after. It helps  promote healing.   Best of Luck

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: The HIV virus cannot be spread unless it gets into your system.  Contact with clothing or even having it on your intact (no open areas) skin would not infect you.  It has to have a way INSIDE you in order to infect you. As for other STD's the only types that can be passed by touching the clothing or bed linens used by the infected person is that of  Pubic Lice (Crabs) or Scabies. In those cases all clothing and linen needs to be washed in hot water and put through a hot dryer for 20 minutes.  I hope this helps. Regards, Carolyn

author: countrycutie  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Tue Oct 18, 2005 2:25 am Location: missouri
title: [no title]
content: I've battled poison ivy all my life, it gets very aggervating.  The rash you described does sound like poison ivy.  The poison ivy rash that you get is an allergic reaction to the oil on the plant.  You can get it by touching the plant itself,  or depending on how sensitive you are to it, you may get it from handling a jacket that came into contact with it.  The best way I've found to treat the rash is plantain.  This is a common plant that grows in your front yard.  It reminds me of lettuce.  The leaves are very round and grow in little clumps.  Shred the leaves by hand and and make sure they're a little moist.  After you've shredded the leaves apply them to the rash and make sure you rub them around on it very well.  Do this 3 times a day.  My poison ivy is gone in less than a week when I do this.  I wouldn't take the augmentin though.  Augmentin is an antibiotic.  You're seeking treatment for an allergic reaction, not necessarily an infection.  Over the counter allergy medications (Benadryl)  always worked for me. My grandmother taught me a saying to learn poison ivy, schumack, oak etc.  "Leaves of 3 let them be, leaves of 5 let them hide." Hopefully this info. will atleast make him more comfortable and keep him from getting the sander back out.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: A recurrent kidney infection requires an imaging procedure to exclude a cause, such as an underlying abnormality. It is better to avoid excessive military-style exercises until you are fully well and are sure that there is no sinister cause for a second kidney infection. IT can't hurt and it is possible you could find the answer to the infections you are haveing.  Good Luck, lilamae0204

author: R. Zein, Pharm D  Pharmacist Posts: 157 Joined: Tue Jul 12, 2005 9:16 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: The sedimentation rate (sed rate) blood test measures how quickly red blood cells (erythrocytes) settle in a test tube in one hour.  When inflammation is present in the body, certain proteins cause red blood cells to stick together and fall more quickly than normal to the bottom of the tube. The more red cells that fall to the bottom of a special test tube in one hour, the higher the sed rate. These proteins are produced by the liver and the immune system under many abnormal conditions, such as an infection.  i do not believe UTI would have triggered your low red blood cell counts, you might have anemia, meaning low red blood cell counts, and there are many types of that too. anemia could affect the sedimentation rate.  the fact that your doctor has asked you for pelvic ultrasound is a good idea,  i hope you always feel good.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: It doesn't sound like PID to me, but sometime you can have PID and have no symptoms at all. Many different organisms can cause PID, but many cases are associated with gonorrhea and chlamydia  PID is difficult to diagnose because the symptoms are often subtle and mild. Many episodes of PID go undetected because the woman or her health care provider fails to recognize the implications of mild or nonspecific symptoms. Because there are no precise tests for PID, a diagnosis is usually based on clinical findings. If symptoms such as lower abdominal pain are present, a health care provider should perform a physical examination to determine the nature and location of the pain and check for fever, abnormal vaginal or cervical discharge, and for evidence of gonorrheal or chlamydial infection. If the findings suggest PID, treatment is necessary  PID can be treated with antibiotics.   As for HIV....I can't say that it is harder to catch than people make it out to be. You are right, there are some very promiscious people who never get it, and some people who can catch it the very first time they have sex. It just depends on if you sleep with an infected partner or not.  Also, When someone has HIV, but is taking their medication, their viral load can be at zero, meaning, if they were tested for HIV, it would come up negative. This does not mean they are cured, as there is no cure for HIV, but peopel can live normal lives for 20+ years with no viral load.  If you have sex with someone who has HIV, but a low viral load, it is less common that you will contract HIV. THAT DOES NOT MEAN IT IS SAFE. It just means the chance can be smaller.  HIV is contracted throguh blood and body fliuds only. You can share a glass, a bite of food, and will not catch it. You can only get it through an opening in your body,  The reason you get HIV during sex, is that the HIV is present in a mans semen, and during sex, microscopic tears form inside the vagina due to sex, you do not know these tears are there, they just happen, btu when a man ejaculates, his semes come sin contact with these tears, and HIV can get into the blood stream.   The same goes for oral sex. You would catch that if you had any open sore in your mouth, and his semen came in contact with it. That does not mean you are safe if he doesn't ejaculate, because a man releases some pre ejaculate, that still contains the virus.  SO this was a very long post, but I hope I answered you questions.  It isn't that HIV is harder to catch, the risk is out there, and it is very real, its just that some people have been lucky enough not to sleep with an infected parter. The only safe way is ALWAYS use protection, each and every time.
