author: Nurse4you  Guest Posts: 22 Joined: Thu Oct 06, 2005 10:13 pm Location: USA
title: Seem to be Contagious! Please HELP!
content: Dear CaringHuman- It is possible that some of the people you come into contact with are very sensitive to cigarette smoke, which may cause some of their symptoms. And yes, smoking constricts (makes thinner) blood vessels in your body. This can lead to stroke, hypertension, as well as heart disease. I urge you to try to prepare yourself to quit. Many individuals have to "practice" quitting, and some use stop smoking aids such as lozenges, gum or even medication. Imagine how much money you could save ! You state that after you smoke marijuana you experience itching, Is this associated with hives (red welt like marks)? Do you have any other allergies?  Consider this-marijuana IS a WEED. You could be allergic! Try to stop smoking marijuana at LEAST for a few days.. a week at least, and see if you still experience the itching. If you do still have itching, you could have what is called idiopathic urticaria, meaning itching/hives for no known reason. Some people have been treated with a combination of over the counter medications that block the release of histamine, which causes the itching.  If you stop the marijuana and continue to have this problem, please reply back and I may have other suggestions for you. Thanks!

author: Nurse4you  Guest Posts: 22 Joined: Thu Oct 06, 2005 10:13 pm Location: USA
title: Quitting Smoking
content: Dear Caring- I am glad you have been able to stop smoking marijuana and that your symptoms have subsided. I knew you could do it! Soon, you will notice getting less winded with activity as your lungs start their healing process, and your memory and motivation levels  may even improve! As for cigarettes, well, don't be surprised if it takes a little, ok, a LOT more effort! There are many over the counter aids you can try, gum, lozenges, just remember try very hard not to smoke while using these.  Some things people do while attempting to quite are: brushing their teeth a lot, the minty breath followed by a cigarette, well just does't taste right! Also, try to stay busy to keep your mind off of cravings. Slow deep cleansing breaths several times a day, and if you have a hobby that occupies your hands, well, DO IT!  Rememeber, sometimes you may think, "Oh, I'll just have one.... it'll be ok". DON"T FALL INTO THAT TRAP!  Where is your dream vacation spot? Think about it, that just may come true with all the money you are going to save by not purchasing cigarettes! Just don't buy them, if they aren't around it will make it a little easier.  Don't get disappointed if at first you don't succeed. It takes some people 2 or 3 times before they quit for good.  I KNOW you can do this! Good luck!

content: It started several weeks ago with noticing that I was tossing and turning a lot at night, waking up not as rested and with a sore lower back.  I thought it was just the mattress.  In the last week, things have changed.  Three days ago, the fatigue, that I wake up with, was noticably more significant.  I am now waking up with my eyes scratchy and burning, whole body aches and muscle soreness, primarily in the back shoulder and neck, minor sinus and throat scratchiness and soreness, and minor lymph node swelling under the jaw.  As the day progresses the fatigue progresses to minor lethargy in the evening.  I am now running a low-grade fever in the evenings and experience a splitting headache that radiates into my neck and upper shoulder muscles.  This has been getting progressively worse over the last three days.  Are these symptoms of a known disease?  Can you help me know what's going on?  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by MWallace » Sat Oct 16, 2004 11:50 am

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: A visit to your physician is warranted for white blood cell testing, iron testing, basically a full blood screening.  This could be anything from mono to the flu, or something not even related to these.

author: Nurse4you  Guest Posts: 22 Joined: Thu Oct 06, 2005 10:13 pm Location: USA
title: Help!
content: Dear NikkiIzALozer- You state the bump on the end of his penis doesnt hurt or itch. Does the bump appear crater like, with an indentation in the center? If so, it could be what is called a chancre, caused by syphyllis which are usually not painful. You also state that you have a history of HSV-type1, which causes cold sores on the mouth.  It is possible to spread this via oral sex.  Without being able to see this bump, it is very difficult to say for sure. I strongly recommend a trip to his physician. It could be nothing, or it could be something more serious. Either way, finding out for sure will bring you both peace of mind.  Good luck!

I've tried the usual, standing up, loosening my belt & clothes, not eating gassy foods, but it's been persistant over the last week and a half. author: Nurse4you  Guest Posts: 22 Joined: Thu Oct 06, 2005 10:13 pm Location: USA
title: Pretty painful...
content: Hi Ninja- What you are describing could be a few different things. It's hard to say for sure without being able to examine you or run some tests, but, here goes! Sme of the possibilities include Appendicitis, Cholecystitis (Gall Bladder-blocked bile duct?) or Pleurisy. Pleurisy is inflammation of the thin layers of tissue (pleura) covering the lungs and the chest cavityPleurisy is inflammation of the thin layers of tissue (pleura) covering the lungs and the chest cavity. PAin is worse with deep breaths. Have you experienced any nausea along with these symptoms? Another possibility, depending on the location of the pain is renal calculi (kidney stones).  I suggest a trip to your physician at your earliest convience.  Hope this helps and good luck!

author: scoobie  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Aug 16, 2003 1:20 am
title: STDs
content: Hi, I'm wondering about STD testing.  I'm embarrassed to admit, but I've been naive about testing and always assumed that those various tests were performed during an annual well-woman exam.  (Which I am faithful to do)  Hence, I've never specifically asked for STD testing, except for an HIV test once.  Also, I've given blood many times and I know they screen for Hep B & C, syphilis, HIV, and HTLV I&II.  Now, after a friend told me they don't do it unless you ask, I've been nervous.  I've been monogamous for 3 years with my husband of 1 year, and he has been too.  But we've never talked about (and won't) my or his previous sexual partners.  I have had a history of unprotected sex (something I'm not proud of) but I've never had any symptoms, other than a few (self-diagnosed) yeast infections.  Now I'm worried that somehow I have some undiagnosed sexually transmitted diseases that have been dormant for years.  I do have an appointment for a yearly next week, but my nerves have gotten the best of me!  I need to know what the chances are of my having a STD go unnoticed for so long?    Thanks, Scoobie
posted_time: Post  by scoobie » Sat Aug 16, 2003 1:30 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Stds
content: Dear Scoobie,  The std that can be dormant for so long is hiv/aids otherwise usually every other disease manifests itself in an acute way.   In women sometimes the primary lesion of syphyllis (the chancre) presents itself in the cervix so it is not apparent but this is followed few weeks later by the typical rash of syphyllis which is usually not missed. If you want to be sure, you can always ask for the syphyllis blood tests.  Reagrding the blood it is tested for hep. b, hep. c, hiv, and syphyllis and i think malaria also. It is tested and it has nothing to do with whether you ask or not.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Thu Aug 21, 2003 10:22 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ? MC or HPV
content: Without an examination and in the absence of close-up views of the lump, no diagnosis is possible. The possibilities are:  1. a solitary lesion of molluscum contagiosum (MC). The lesion has a dome shape with central  dimple. Incubation period of MC averages 2 to 3 months, ranging from 1 week to 6 months. 2. a papular wart (Human Papilloma Virus)  Both conditions are sexually transmitted if they are located on the genitalia. Get examined for a diagnosis - if any of the two conditions is confirmed, a full STD panel is mandatory.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Anthony Solomon » Mon Oct 03, 2005 5:52 pm

title: Penis Discoloration/Bruising?  Worried...
content: Hello.  Received oral sex last night from a new partner.  She has only been with two other people, one for a long time, no symptoms or anything at all.  I have had one partner, again, no symptoms of anything.  It has been a year between partners.  Now, I received oral sex last night, and for one portion of it the tip of my penis burned for a second, almost as if she maybe got saliva or something inside it (don't know if thats relevant).  Anyways, later on that night, about 3 hours later, I went to the bathroom for the first time.    Right on the very tip of the head of my penis I noticed three discolored spots right near the opening.  Two seem to be purple and one is just slightly red.  There is no irritation, no itching, no burning during urination, nothing.  I visited my college medical center and the doctor told me it just looked like bruising, possibly from teeth, and to give it 24 hours or so.  It has now been about 15-16 hours and it hasn't subsided any yet.  I am just looking for a second opinion as the on-campus medical center is terrible as far as diagnosing colds and such.  It has me very worried.  Again, two of the dots are purple, one is slightly red.  They all are about 2mm or less in size.  Thanks for any advice here!  Again, no testing has ever been done, but as positive as I can be that  both of us are clean.  I inquired with the doctor about getting testing done, but she said she felt that it was not needed in this situation.  Lastly, if this is just a bruise, could anyone explain why my penis tip may have "burned" for a second or two during this?

author: dlugose  Guest Posts: 38 Joined: Tue Feb 22, 2005 6:08 pm Gender: Male Location: Boulder, CO, USA
title: [no title]
content: Whatever happened is not related to an infection of any kind.  Infections take much too long to notice during or soon after contact.  So there was some kind of irritation, physical or less likely chemical, or a combination.  Teeth are likely.  The skin on your penis and inside your urethra is more sensitive than most skin.  Something she was eating or drinking or smoking could have burnt your urethra, or when the teeth (?) scraped your skin, it was then exposed to acids, etc. in her mouth.  I wouldn't worry at all for a few days.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi worried_nbama, All posts on this forum are important and are answered to the best of everyone's ability. My apologies for the delay in answering your post. With that being said, have you had an evaluation by a urologist or any diagnostic studies? Mondor's disease of the penis may present in acute, subacute or chronic phases. Mondor's disease is a  thrombophlebitis (blood clot) of the superficial dorsal vein of the penis. Some of the treatment for acute phases are with anti-inflammatory agents, anticoagulant drugs, and antibiotics. Some of the causes for this condition are prolonged intercourse, genital trauma, infection etc. Symptoms of pain on the dorsal surface is common. Keep in mind that I'm not saying that this is your particular problem but it is certainly something to be considered. If your concerns are lack of insurance, call your local hospital and inquire about assistance. Most hospitals have programs for people whom are uninsured/underinsured and they should be able to also provide you with information regarding a physician who would be able to offer services at possibly a lower cost. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Hi paul1234, Many conditions can cause white bumps on the throat, for example, viruses, strep. author: mayers05  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Tue Dec 28, 2004 3:21 pm Location: Arizona
title: Swollen Tonsil with White Spots, Ineffective Meds
content: One month ago, I started my 1st dose of Humira to help control Severe Ankylosing Spondylitis and a recent working diagnosis of IBS. Formerly on Enbrel. A couple days later I had a painful throat (more intense than sore throats I've had in the past), then coughing til it was painful to the chest, temp bounced between 96's up to 101.7, swollen tonsil with white spots-only 1 side, overheating; could only speak in a whisper; later I couldn't breath, so got a prescription for Advair & Prometh.DM/Decadron (put on breathing maching in dr office and diagnosed with a cold with wheezing; neg result for strep). Also, the white spots where mostly cleared up by dr visit, then completely gone, but returned 1 wk later. After the 2nd painful dose I had remaining 1/2 inch dark circles at shot area (took me a couple tries as the injecting of the Humira felt like acid squirting into my thigh); and a couple dark spots from the 2nd does as well. Rhem said from vit c preservative. Stopped Humira. Stopped cough syrup due to antihistamine causing rash and started Zithromax Z-Pak 5 doses. Sore throat gone, cough gone, but spots still visible and one side of tonsils swollen. Tried gargling salt water. GP prescribed Nystatin 100,000U; swish & spit 4ml daily. Noticed that I have blisters on top, front gum only. Blisters mostly gone after Nystatin, but white spots still on swollen tonsil and have spread to the other tonsil, although that tonsil has not gotten swollen. Due you have any suggestions on what this might be? I've never had any mouth/gum/throat issues before. Thanks for your help.

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: Definitely sounds like something other than neurologic to me.    Factors mentioned that stand out to me:  1.  Elevated white blood cell count. 2.  Yellowing skin.  Has your physician run any tests other than blood count such as for mono or strep?  Liver function should also be tested, including any factors that could be affecting the liver.    My suggestions come only from your typed symptoms.  More of a history is needed concerning medications you are on, previous medical history, etc...  A visit to a General Practicioner or Family Medicine physician would be a valid suggestion so they may review your entire history.  I would suggest doing this as soon as possible, as the yellowing skin is a symptom that points to the liver and should be checked.  I hope they are able to find the cause soon and you can begin feeling better.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi carol johns, Lymph nodes commonly become enlarged as a result of infection because the lymphatic system is the bodies filter for bacteria. Lymph nodes may not return to their pre-infectious size. This is one of the most common reasons for enlargement. However, they do become enlarged for other reasons as well. If you have not experienced a recent illness that would indicate this to be the reason for enlargement I would suggest an evaluation to which a breast exam should be included. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi DJW, There would not be a "cure" for lymph node enlargement and regression because this is the bodies defense system during infectious states. If you are being instructed to use an antibacterial soap then it's likely felt that your enlargement is do to an infection from bacteria. Lymph nodes that enlarge and continue doing so despite treatment are more disconcerting and may indicate a more serious condition. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: beta haemolytic streptococcus????
content: Please  help me to understand the test results that came from the lab:  +++Beta haemolytic streptococcus group D significance  What kind of streptococcus it is? Is it famous B streptococcus(which are very dangerous if you have them untreated during labour) or it is group D streptococcus?  I am currently pregnant and need a treatment for this. Thanks
posted_time: Post  by natali555 » Wed Sep 14, 2005 10:06 pm

author: Dr. N. Haider  Medical Doctor Posts: 57 Joined: Sun May 01, 2005 5:13 pm Location: Lahore, Pakistan
title: [no title]
content: thank you for the query.  Lancefield classification is a 'serologic'  classification of bacteria of haemolytic(blood cell breaking)  streptococci into groups based on their specific carbohydrate antigen on their wall. Based on this, types from A to O have been identified. Group A is the most common in causing infections to humans. Group D is quite uncommon in humans. S bovis and Streptococcus equinus are the 2 members of this class of streptococci. S equinus is almost never isolated from human specimens, leaving S. bovis.   You didnot mention what was the specimen used to get this report. was this blood? you might need a culture and sensitivity done.  any further enquiries are welcome.

title: 3 month long sore throat
content: On jun 16th I had the worst sore throat of my life.  I could see white things on my tonsils and went to urgent care. I should also mention a month before this sore throat came I had my nose broken in a sparring match at kickboxing.  Not sure if this would matter.  Finally I went to a ENT he looked at my tonsils and said they need to be removed but did not want to listen to any of my symptoms or anything.  only that I had sore throat for over 2 months. author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: The broken nose could have affected your sinuses, causing increased post-nasal drip, causing a sore throat.  When you say you saw "white things" on your tonsils, were they spots all over the tonsils or were they isolated to one cavity within the tonsil?  Were the white spots on the back of your throat also or only the tonsils?  If they were confined to the one area on each of the tonsils, this points more toward allergies rather than infection.  I'm curious why antibiotics continue to be prescribed for you when your tests continue to come back negative.  How does the inside of your nose feel?  Is it dry or runny?  You could always try the old standby's of breathing warm, humid air (the steam from a hot shower, bath or boiling water) could help your sinuses begin to clear if they are the culprits.  Give us some more information about the sightings in the back of your throat and we'll be able to get more of an idea.
posted_time: Post  by DeLWolcott » Tue Sep 13, 2005 11:31 am

author: kalucy  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Wed Mar 09, 2005 11:00 pm Location: midwest
title: sore throat
content: Am wondering if you are taking the antibiotics as prescribed?  Sometimes people only take part of a prescription until their symptoms subside and then they stop taking them.  This can cause a senerio where the germs causing an infection or inflamation are held at bay only to return with a vengence if an antibiotic is not taken for the prescribled length of time...  long enough to kill the offending germs.  It is a serious matter when your throat swells to almost closing off.  Why?  It can potentially affect your breathing.  Wisely consider getting this matter taken care of by following the learned advise of an ENT.

author: mama26  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 06, 2005 8:53 pm Location: Hawaii
title: Unknown Infection, lasted over 6 months.
content: Hi, I am a 26 year old, married, non-smoking,non-drinking, female who has had chronic monolike symptoms for over 6 months. I went to the emergency room about 6 mos. ago with a very sore throat and swollen glands and was given a rapid strep test and a throat culture and sent home with antibiotics that made me sick. After a few days a felt worse and called for my results from the step test and throat culture and was told they were negetive.  So I went back in and they ran a mono test that came back "faintly positve", the sent me home with a different antibiotic and told me to follow up with my doctor. When I followed up with my doctor she tested me for mono again and aslo ran a check for cmv and ebv all of which turned up negative.  I still felt worse but my doctor had gone on vacation and I went to see another doctor.  I should add that at each of these doctors visits I was running a low grade fever and had a fast heart rate and poor blood pressure.  This doctor told me after and examination that I was really sick and he didn't know why, but was determined to find out.  He had a super duper blood panel done that came back fine. I know that chronic mono like sypmtoms presented by a patient who seemingly has nothing wrong with them is suspected of being infected with HIV. On that note, I have to say that I am not a risk and that I have been tested repeatedly, all with negative results.  My first test was when I was 3mos pregnant three years ago.  My second test was a year ago when I first started to feel really run down a fatigued after I stopped nursing my son.  I dropped 15-20 pounds in 2 mos. and had no appetite. I also had sore joints, swelling in my fingers, and sore wrists. I also had unexplained red marks that would appear on my arms and hands. That time I was diagnosed with depression and given meds. After months of taking super expensive antidepressents that didn't really help, and just made me gain weight I went to a naturalpath who thought I might have a thyroid disorder. Her blood test came back "borderline" according to her standards which she said are much lower than the test I recieved while pregnant. She put me on The "Eat right for your type" diet for an O+ and I tried to follow it for 1 1/2 months and felt worse than ever.  And my 3rd test was with that "super duper" blood panel that my last doctor ordered.  I have not seen a doctor now for months because I got tired of no one being able to give me a diagnosis. I have seen five doctors and a dentist and no one can tell me what is wrong.  I still have a recurring sore throat, swollen glands and I have increasing pain under my tongue(so painful it brings tears to my eyes), down my neck and in my clavicle area. The area under my chin is constantly swollen.  I am also currently 12 weeks pregnant with our second child and I am terrified that this mystery illness could harm my fetus. In addition to the sore throat etc. I still have swollen fingers with pain in the joints, my wrists and my knees. I also still get red marks on my hands and arms that sometimes itch,and a red, painful rash on the back of my scalp and sometimes a red "rash" on my face that doesn't hurt or itch.  I currently have the face and scalp rash.My hands and feet are always ice cold even though I live in Hawaii  From time to time I where the tepmperature rarely falls below 70 degrees. I get migraine headaches once every month or two. And for the last three days that I have been monitering my temperature I have had a low grade fever  ranging from 99.4-100.4 degrees.  I am very tired and nauseous as well, but at 12 weeks pregnant that is to be expected. I hope I have provided enough information, I have tried to be as specific as possible with my symptoms. Any information anyone could give me would be extremelu helpful, I am scared that something serious may be going on and is getting worse as my doctors keep giving me the brush off.

author: friendly1  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Sep 12, 2005 2:19 pm Location: Bend OR
title: a lot like me
content: I have had a lot of the same type of symptoms and problems since a year and a half ago.  The rash is not really one of the symptoms that I have had, but the swollen lymphnodes all over that leave your hands feeling swollen and soar.  Painful underarms, low grade fever, etc.  My tongue would get swollen and soar, too. Some symptoms started to get a little better after the removal of a lymphnode that the doctor told me an infection might be festering in.  I really did not get much better and two days later ended up in the hospital with some other symptoms, including a massive infection that my body was in shock from.  This is a long story, so I will cut it short.  Even though they never discovered the cause, and do not agree with my original theory that my intestine ripped, I do believe all of the lymphnodes being swollen and infected had something to do with it.   Maybe the antibiotics and painkillers complicated things because I seemed to be having intestinal problems from them, but I remember reading that when all of your lymphnodes are swollen there was danger of some leaking into your blood stream.  I do not have a spleen and have been fighting infections all of my life.  I continued to have problems after I was released from the hospital and finished up the oral antibiotics.  A tooth that was suppose to rootcanaled had broken and needed to be removed.  The root canal did not kill the tooth, and they thought maybe a lingering infection in my tooth may have been the problem that I was having.  The tooth was removed in the hospital because it was a curved root and the oral surgeon had to go through the bone and take it out piece by piece. Also, I was having the surgery at the hospital because I did not have a spleen.  Anyways, After the removal of that tooth I was better more often.  I still had frequent infections, but not continiously and worstening when the antibiotics were finished.  Now I have been sick for two months, starting ten months after my surgery for my tooth.  Another tooth in a different area is bothering me and the area I had surgery on is bothering me.  My heart has been giving me problems since last May before my first hospitalization for infection.  I too am trying to get to the bottom of this chronic infection and hope that when the tooth gets taken care of that I will be better.  Also, if you have an infection in your heart valve, you can be sick for a long time and have your symptoms.  I have not pushed the doctors for the test that catches it, but I did have an EKG that showed an enlarged heart valve.  I read that there is only one test that takes several blood samples over a period of time and is kept at a certain temp. to truely diagnose this kind of infection.  Good luck.  I have been sick during my pregnancies, too.  After the birt h of my second baby I had an infection that the doctors couldn't diagnose or treat and it turned into a full blown sinus infection that they treated with six weeks of intervenious Unysin.  I did get better for quite a while.

title: Please help... MRSA infection...
content: I am a 28 y.o female, in relatively good health (although I have been on multiple antibiotics in recent months including Cipro (last year), Amoxicillin, Levaquin and Septra DS this year)  I was diagnosed with a MRSA infection in my belly button piercing approx. 10 days ago. The infection had been there for possibly a month prior due to misdiagnosis from one doctor.   As I was finally correctly diagnosed, I was put on Septra DS twice a day for 10 days. At approx. day 8 I began feeling pain in the bones of the back of my skull, slightly labored breathing, stiff neck, and a headache that had been there for 3 days prior.   Today I just finished my last dose of Septra and am feeling flu-like. I have a slight fever  of 99.8, chills and my breathing is labored. My neck is stiff and when I turn my head from side to side it aches, although I have no headache currently. The bones in the back of my skull are still very tender, although not as swollen and painful as 2 days ago.   How am I to know the MRSA is gone? My doctor never mentioned whether I should schedule a follow up appt. Is it possible I just have the flu? Or could this be the MRSA? Please help me. I'm scared.

author: don ross  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Aug 14, 2005 9:49 pm Location: al
title: mrsa questions
content: I broke both legs in dec. When I got the casts off I went to get a pedicure. They cut my big toe.It became infected and at physical therapy they told me i had to got to dr and get it checked. I did. he removed a third of toenail, cleaned it out and told me to use peroxide daily.It would not heal. I went back to dr several times. No culture was taken, no antibiotics given. I then developed a deep sore on my right breast and sores in nose. I had no idea they might be connected to toe. In April I became very ill and could not breathe. I went to dr twice and was given prednisone and a z-pack. In 4 days I was in hospital. I was in hospital for 15 days very ill. I was on solumeterol and levaquin in iv. I dropped the vitamin d,calcium and protein from my blood, my blood pressure went very low,I became too weak to chew,my blood sugar soared to over 400, my veins shut down. My nose began to bleed daily and I began to have sores all over. after i was released i kept mentioning the sores and was treated for yeast and drug reaction.  In June my hair began to fall out. I was sent to a dermatologist who diagnosed mrsa.I have been on clindamycin and bactriban for a month.sores are healed, but i keep getting new sores briefly and red hot spots on skin. My left breast has become sore and i have become very arthritic. no fever usually Questions-Do you think the illness in the hospital could have been the mrsa? Do you think the toe started it? I am worried I need an infectious disease doctor and vancomycin. Will I ever be cured? I have been off work for 5 months . Help!

author: nursie3205  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Mon Sep 05, 2005 11:23 am Location: Kentucky
title: to morgan with mrsa bumps in armpits
content: Regarding your follow up visit, the doctor will probably swab the inside of your nose for a culture.  If you are still MRSA positive he or she may prescribe another  round of antibiotics for you .  You may have to go back for a couple of follow-ups.  The MRSA may be eradicated or unfortantley you may be a lifetime carrier.  Either way the follow up visits are very important.  I suggest that you practice strict handwashing, keep any areas that may be draining covered, and complete all antibiotics prescribed unless otherwise indicated by a doctor.  REMEMBER , THOUROUGH HANDWASHING IS THE NUMBER ONE WAY TO PREVENT INFECTION.  ALCOHOL BASED HAND SANITIZERS SUCH AS GERM-X ARE ALSO VERY EFFECTIVE.  Hope I have helped.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: INFECTED NIPPLE AFTER PIERCING
content: Swelling, redness, tenderness  and pus formation  on any area of the skin that has been injured or traumatised, as in nipple piercing, are the diagnostic signs of an infection.  It is important to get it treated vigorously with an antibiotic to prevent complications. A doctor's examination is necessary to ensure that a breast abscess has not formed as this would require incision and drainage.  Naproxen is an anti-inflammatory drug, not an antibiotic and may only relieve pain.   I hope a sterile equipment was used and that your Tetanus and Hepatitis B immunisations are up to date.  Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: thisisnotmyname  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Aug 04, 2005 9:48 am Location: USA
title: Cold sores
content: Ninety percent of all people will have at least one cold sore, (herpes simplex outbreak) sometime in their life.  Some children who are affected with cold sores may become seriously ill. However, after the first cold sore infection, many people develop antibodies to the cold sore virus and never have another cold sore. About 40% of American adults, however, have repeated cold sores.   Cold sores are highly contagious when a flare up is present, and a cold sore can be transmitted even when there is no visible signs of a cold sore, this is called viral shedding. Children often become infected with the cold sore virus by contact with parents, siblings or other close relatives who have cold sores.    The cold sore virus is highly contagious. Anyone experiencing symptoms of a cold sore must be very cautious when being intimate with another person so as not to transmit the cold sore virus. Those who have symptoms of a cold sore should refrain from contact with another person to help avoid transmission of cold sores.  If the cold sore  virus has been transmitted, the infection is permanent.   Cold sores can be either a one time event or reoccur.  Possible causes of a cold sore reactivating may include stress, fever, menstruation, cold, fatigue and sunlight. Recurrent cold sores usually occur as lesions in or around the mouth.    Cold sores can be transmitted to the genitals by oral sex.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: HEPATITIS B IMMUNISATION
content: If the doctors said you had Hepatitis B, it meant that the test known as Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) was positive. If you have achieved immunity, your level of Hepatitis B surface antibodies (HBsAb) would show that, and your Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) would be negative.  It is better to investigate your immune status before embarking on another course of immunisations. For that, you will be subjected to a Hepatitis B profile.   For your information, the recommended schedule for the Hepatitis B vaccine is a course of 3 doses on Days 0, 1 month and 6 months. Alternatively, an accelerated schedule exists and comprises 4 doses administered on Days 0, 1 month, 2 months and 12 months. The schedule you mentioned is incorrect.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: MALARIA
content: On return from a malarial region, it is important to be aware that any illness that occurs within 1 year and especially within 3 months of return might be malaria even if all recommended precautions against malaria were taken. You must be aware of this and go to a doctor immediately if you develop any illness particularly within 3 months  and mention your exposure to malaria.  Do you know what strain of malaria is prevalent in the area you visited? What precautions did you take? Depending on the type of tests you were subjected to,  retesting is necessary,  especially if you were tested utilising thick and thin malaria films. There are more modern tests now which utilise the HRP II technology with results available in 10-20 minutes - while you are still with the doctor!  Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

After another week passed, I returned to the doctor because there was still no improvement. I was tested for mono, strep (even though I had no sore throat) and had a CBC. I was told negative for mono and negative for strep. The CBC showed that I had a viral infection and that my platelet count was increased. They sent me home and told me to take tylenol.   About 4 days after this, I began to feel sick, just the usual cold type symptoms and decided to go back in and get tested again. This time they did a chest X-ray, CBC, Mono test, Strep test, and since I go to school in the desert, tested me for Valley Fever. Everything came back normal except for my mono test was now positive, my chest x-ray showed a nodule on my lung, and my platelets were still increased at 460000, my SEGS was 47 and my Lymph was 48 (not sure what any of that means).   I was relieved to find out I had mono, and thought everything would be better. However when I returned home from school, my node was still large. It gradually started getting smaller, but still has not returned to normal and is still fairly large.   I am extremely tired, and recently felt like I had an ear infection. When I went into the doctors for the ear infection, I decided to have them test me for mono again since I showed 2 different results within a 4 day period when I was still in school. The results from my doctor at home were that I tested negative for mono and had no signs of antibodies for it or any sign of it at all. They said this was fine because mono can make you feel sick for months, but not show up in the blood again after testing positive for it before. My concern is that it has now been 3 months, and I still have an enlarged node. I never felt as though I had mono (i.e. I never had any kind of sore throat, no other glands were ever enlarged) being very tired has been the only serious symptom I have had other than nausea and low grade temps that are on and off. And now for the past week the right side of my neck, where my gland is enlarged, is very achy.   Basically, I'm not quite sure what I’m asking other than do you think that this is something more than mono or is this common to having mono. I feel like something is just not right with me, and I have repeatedly been on my doctors case, but I feel like they are just brushing me off as having mono because it is the easy diagnosis for a 19 year old, female college student. It worries me that I tested negative for mono, then positive 4 days later, then negative again 3 and a ½ weeks later.   If anyone has any ideas at all, or has been in a similar situation, I would greatly appreciate any thoughts at all you may have! Thank you!

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: MONO, TOXO or CMV ???
content: Many cases of infectious mononucleosis (mono) are asymptomatic, but in symptomatic patients, the main features are fever, headache, sore throat, lethargy, rash, enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, enlarged spleen and a mild hepatitis.    The blood tests you had have been contradictory, but diagnosis is usually confirmed by a positive Paul-Bunnell test and positive Epstein-Barr Virus IgM antibodies. Do you know if these were the tests conducted?  Your ESR is within normal range.   Infection with Toxoplasmosis or Cytomegalovirus may produce a similar clinical picture as mono, but of course the lab tests for mono would then be negative. With the persistence of an enlarged lymph node in the neck and other symptoms, you must be further evaluated for these other conditions producing a similar picture. The nodule in the lung detected by Xray and CT scan should also be rechecked to determine if there is a change in size.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Brown Recluse bite
content: Hello,  Pennsylvania has at least two spiders – the Yellow Sac spiders and a Brown Recluse spiders that can cause ulcers, it could be that you’ve been bitten by one of these. Until you find out, do not pick at the puss spot, keep the area clean and covered and report any changes in your body (fevers, chills, nausea, rash, etc.) to your doctor without hesitation.  The Brown Recluse spiders venom includes a neurotoxic component. About 7 hours after a bite, a small blister-like sore appears that will grow in size. Symptoms include chills, fever, bloody urine, fatigue, jaundice, pain in the joints, nausea, rash, and in extremely rare cases, convulsions and death.  The amount of damage depends on the amount of venom injected.  The damaged area may be the size of a dime or as large as 8 inches in diameter.  If the poison gets between the muscle fibers it can cause damage to the nerves and muscles as it goes.  Healing is slow and scar tissue results from the wound.  Healing may take 6-8 weeks or require up to a year if the wound is large. The health and age of a person will play a large role in recovery.

title: [no title]
content: Hello, If you do not have any other chest related symptoms then it would favour post-nasal discharge. Spitting blood is usually related to the nose or the mouth and pharynx in contrast to coughing blood which comes from the lungs. It may turn out to be a coagulation disorder. author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: There are several types of bacterial infections, namely paronychia and felon which are found in the mouth, and if there is any broken skin, i.e. hangnail being bitten, it can cause infection.  Herpetic viruses can cause them, if you have cold sores or genital herpes, you could infect yourself.  This is much less likely, though.  If your fingers swell and contain pus, it can become an infection called cellulitis that can be potentially very serious, even to the point of the area being amputated if not treated.  Squeezing pus out only introduces more bacteria into the affected area, and is generally not recommended.  Keep the infected area very clean with peroxide and/or betadine, use antibiotic ointment and see the doctor.  There may be some other reason you are so prone to these infections.    Worst case scenario, diabetics commonly get sores, blisters and infections in the extremities chronically and may have a more difficult time healing.  Ask your doctor if he thinks you should be checked for it just in case.

title: [no title]
content: I didn't mean to scare you, but you need to know there is the possibility of any infection developing into cellulitis and if it does, it is very dangerous.  No infection should go without very careful cleaning, antibiotic ointment and bandaging, if it doesn't improve at all in a day or two, should be seen by a doctor. title: Rabies- Not sure if this should be Neurology or not but....
content: Ok. Here's the deal. (this is for my mom.)  I work at a vet clinic. and today I was assisting the doctor to hold a dog who was a fear biter- replacing the girl who was currently holding him due to a phone call she needed to answer. the dog was coming in for its rabies vaccination, which it was only a week overdue for. As the doctor was going to muzzle the dog, the girl let go before I had the dog under my control and the dog bit me.   It wasn't a vicious bite, it didn't even break the skin, even the red mark it left went away after about 20 mintues. I washed my hands with anti-bacterial soap, double checked that It didn't break the skin, which it didn't, washed my hands again, then went back about my daily business.   When I talked to my mom later this evening and my mom asked how my day went, absent-mindedly, I told her. Big mistake. She wanted me to get the rabies vaccine since the dog's vaccine had lapsed by a week and the whole 9 yards.   I explained to my mom that for one, small breed domesticated dog to human rabies is extremely rare- you never hear of a pet giving rabies to someone in America. Its usually a racoon or bat or some other wild animal. Secondly- I tried to explain that not only does an animal's bite need to break skin, even then its rare, usually the bite has to be fairly deep to reach the tissue so the virus can hit the nerve endings and travel to your brain.   of course being the over-protective mom that she is, she's still kind of worried. So I told her I'd show her some resources. I was gathering up some online educational materials when I found this site. Any insightive words from a doctor for my mother?  (Besides tell your daughter to find a new less 'motherly stressful' career?) lol

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: The important thing is not whether it is type I or type II; do you have outbreaks on your genitials?  If so, you will need a swab and culture/microscophic exam to confirm that you have genital herpes.  Just because you have type I herpes does not mean you have type II as well.   Blood tests are less accurate than a swab test.  Only type I can be spread from oral to genitial and vice versa.  Type II can only be spread to and from genitals.  The main difference between the two is the area of nerves the virus resides in; type II in the lower back and type I near the ears.  I suggest if you have genital sores, you get a culture done asap.

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: It sounds like classic infuenza to me - although it's past flu season, it's not impossible.  Has anyone that you know of been sick lately?  The pain in the back and legs, also the very sudden onset of fever and  cold-like symptoms are key.  If you get to the doctor within 24 hours or so, he can prescribe some amantidine to lessen the severity and duration of the illness.   Unfortunately, there is no cure; it is a virus and doesn't respond to antibiotics.  It will go away, but may take several days, and you may feel fatigued for several days after.  Do not let your temp get too high - if it does, it is possible to have febrile seizures.  Take the Dayquil as directed, get plenty of fluids, fevers dehydrate.  Do not try to do anything you don't absolutely have to, definitely don't go to work!   You will be very contagious while the fever is present.  I hope you feel better soon.

author: Dr. L. Chu Go  Medical Doctor Posts: 41 Joined: Fri May 27, 2005 9:08 am Location: Philippines  Contact:   Contact Dr. L. Chu Go       Yahoo Messenger
title: Tonsillitis
content: Hello Arsalan,          having frequent attacks of tonsillitis sure can be very irritating, right? It is true that tonsillitis can have its complications, that of having valvular defects, most especially the mitral valve wherein these valves will have an abnormality in opening and closing. Strains of group A beta hemolytic streptococci are the ones responsible for causing such defects when tonsillitis is left untreated. Don't worry though because there is what we call a prophylaxis for frequent attacks of tonsillitis so that you can protect yourself from getting complications (the antibiotic that I know of that's being used as prophylaxis is Penicillin G or penicillin V which is given intramuscularly). Kindly ask your physician about it. I am sure your physician will know what's best for you.  Sincerely M.D.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: This means that you are suffering from acute or chronic Hepatitis B infection. In acute infection, HBsAg appears in the blood from about 6 weeks to 3 months and then disappears. In acute infection leading to chronic Hepatitis B, HBsAg persists and indicates a chronic infection (or carrier state). You must now undergo a Hepatitis B profile to determine your status.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

content: Hello there,  I'm afraid to tell you that there's no way in the world that anyone here could tell you what this red bump is.  Did you have protected sex, using a condom? author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: The mumps virus typically causes a swelling of the parotid gland on one or both sides of the face giving the patient an obvious facial swelling. The parotid gland is situated anterior to the ear, but the area you have described ( "right below my ear and right below the jaw bone") is known as the angle of the jaw where lymph nodes are located, not the parotid gland. If the lymph node is swollen and tender, you may require a physician's evaluation to determine the cause. Patients with mumps complain of pain and swelling over the parotid gland, and the pain and swelling are made worse by eating.  You should have received the MMR vaccine earlier in life at the age of 12-15 months and a booster dose again at 4-6 years. These two doses give a lifelong immunity. The vaccine is so efficacious that clinical disease is rare in immunized persons. The dose you received 4-5 years ago should totally exclude the possibility of mumps unless this was the first and only MMR vaccine administered on you. Please check your childhood immunisation records to confirm previous doses.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: BALANOPOSTHITIS
content: Hello Berlin,   Welcome to our forum. Is this rash acute or chronic? You may have had protected vaginal intercourse, but is there a history of unprotected orogenital contact (fellatio)? The condition you describe on the head of the penis (glans) and foreskin (prepuce) is known as balanoposthitis.  I will deal only with the acute condition and the non-venereal causes since you are emphatic that it is not sexually transmitted. Several factors are implicated in acute balanoposthitis and it is only by examination that a diagnosis is possible. This is unfortunately not possible over the internet.  Non-venereal causes of balanoposthitis include: minor trauma poor hygiene  topical medicaments/cosmetics/aphrodisiacs underlying inflammatory skin disease, eg eczema and psoriasis primary infections such as candida and certain bacteria  Candida infection is one of the most common causes of an itchy rash affecting the glans and foreskin of the penis. It most often stems from the vagina but orogenital contact has also been implicated. Diabetics and immuno-suppressed persons are more prone to develop genital candidiasis.  No, I am not aware that washing the genitalia regularly with soap and water can cause balanitis. An exception would be hypersensitivty to the soap used.  Get examined to determine the aetiology so that appropriate treatment can be administered.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

She continued to run a fever but it became low grade so they let us leave the hospital and sent her home with 10 days of augmentin. She continued to have diarreha but the doctor thought it could be from the meds. 4 days after being off the augmentin she started running a fever again and still had diarreha. The doctor prescribed Alinia for the diarehha which was to be taken for 3 days 2 x's daily. on the third day she developed a rash so the dr said to discontinue the meds. Her fever started again and diarrhea was still there. They ran the wbc again and they were normal he sent us home and said lets check her agian in another week. Sorry she also had stool culture and urine culture while in the hospital that were normal and then another stool culuture after the hospital that was also normal. There have been so many appointments I may be getting them a little confused but at the last appointment on May 18th she had lost a pound and is still running a intermitent fever and having diarreha. The doctor was already concerned about her weight because she has not gained any since she was 8months old and she is 16 months but know she has lost a pound. At 8 months she weighed 20.8 and now she weighs 19.0. She is 30in tall. He also checked for strip and that was normal. He also did a CHem 14 and her plattlets were high and her lymphocytes were 65% and ESR 28. He has even told us that he did not know what could be wrong with her and was not sure what to do next. He said he was not sure what kind of specialist to send her to but picked a pediatric GI but it will be at least a month before they can get her in. Her doctor is a general practioner. Because of our insurance we are at the mercy of our dr and the specialist. The only way I could get something done faster is to take her to the emergency room but I am afraid they would not realize the importance of her condition since she is stable at this point. The doctor made the comment that she does not look bad and she will smile a little and I am like I do not want to wait until she looks like she is dying before something is done. I am a mother of 3 kids aged 10, 8, and 16 months. So this is not me being a nervous first time mother her behavior and health is not normal. Also I know why she is not gaining weight she will not eat. I am still breastfeeding her, I stopped nursing her during the day to try to wean her per the doctors idea that maybe that would make her better but since she lost weight I started nursing her whenever she wants. Sometimes she does not even want to nurse. I do not know what to think but I am very worried please let me know what you think. Thank You!!!

author: Lisa K, RN  Nurse Posts: 36 Joined: Fri May 20, 2005 10:20 am Location: Canada
title: [no title]
content: Hello Allie, I'm really sorry that you're going through this.  I'm not a Mom and I don't have a lot of experience with ill babies but I just wanted to let you know that you and your little girl are in my thoughts and prayers.  I'm not sure how things work there in the U.S., but given the situation - do you know the name of the Pediatric GI specialist that she's been referred to?  If so, can you contact his office and explain the urgency of the situation....let them know you're aware it will be some time before she can be seen but you're very concerned, she hasn't gained wait in 8 months, in fact, has lost 1 lb.......and is there any way you could be put onto a "Cancellation List" ...so that if someone else cancels, you could be called ASAP and get in sooner?  Do you have a husband?  You could also try making an appt to see your current physician.....both you and husband go in together......be very frank and honest that you are extremely concerned for your daughter..........and is there any way he could please get your daughter seen by the specialist on a more URGENT basis.  As a Mom with other children, you have to trust your gut - and be an advocate for your little one............(which I know you are doing).  With the elevated platelets  and ESR ,she's definitely got some kind of inflammatory process going on.  Is she continuing to have diarrhea?  Fever?  Keep a log of everything....a daily log of her diarrhea (how many times a day, what color), her temperature, how often she nurses, etc.  That way, it provides a better "picture" to your doctor and the specialist you'll be seeing.  Are YOU on any medications?  Seeing how you're breast feeding, I'm just wondering if there's anything that you're consuming that's passing its way into your breast milk?    Was your baby on an IV when in the hospital, for fluids - to combat all the fluid loss from the diarrhea?  If your baby's diarrhea recurs, or if you feel she's not nursing enough (poor appetite), be sure you're aware of the signs of Dehydration - for you'd surely need to return to your doctor:  http://pediatrics.about.com/od/symptoms ... ehydtn.htm  Have your other children been ill at all?  What about yourself?

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jason, People with diabetes are more prone to developing certain conditions, jock itch being one of them. Have you tried any treatments when these symptoms occur? Alkaline phosphatase is an enzyme produced in the liver but can also be produced in the bone. A test that confirms if an elevated alkaline phosphatase level is due to abnormalities associated with the liver is a GGTP (gamma glutamyl transpeptidase ) An elevated level would indicate a disorder related to the liver, normal results would indicate that it is related to the bone. Elevations in GGTP are seen in conditions such as gallbladder and bile duct problems, cirrhosis, pancreatitis, liver injury, infectious mononucleosis, diabetes etc. etc. I would suggest an evaluation that would include this lab test as well. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: GENITAL HERPES
content: Most persons infected with genital herpes have not received a diagnosis of the disease. Such persons have mild or unrecognized infections that shed the virus intermittently in the genital tract. Some cases of first-episode genital herpes are manifested by severe disease, but many cases of the disease are transmitted by persons who are unaware that they have the infection, or are without symptoms when transmission occurs.  Unless your GIRL 1 was experiencing symptoms or requested a screening, I am doubtful if she would have been examined for STDs when she went for her contraceptive shots. In this sexual scenario, any one of the three parties could be the culprit.  The presence of one sexually transmitted disease raises  the possibility of another, so all parties in this scenario should first undergo a full STD screen, then be treated or counselled (as applicable) to halt the spread of any STD in the community. Genital herpes, however, is a recurrent, incurable viral disease.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: mariea  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Apr 30, 2005 6:49 am Location: Sarasota, Florida
title: MRSA
content: Hello:  I need some advice: I went to ER Walk in clinic with what I thought to have been a spider bite....a sample of the bacteria was drained and sent to the lab...I was put on Bactrin and sent home.  I assumed all was well I healed and went on with my daily life. 6 weeks later 3 so called Spider bites (biols appeared on stomach and buttocks after I shaved. I was very sick and very very tired, headaches ect...and these areas seemed very infected, draining ect... I called the ER wic where I was seen prev.... explained I needed a nurse due to a re-occurance and that I was never called with my lab results previously.  The woman who answered the phone stated she had my lab results in fron of her but was unable to interpret them. She would have a nurse call me (this was Saturday, I explained my urgency and concern. I left another message that day! No call. I cleaned and drained these areas my self and covered them, concerned for my nine year old daughter and all others. Monday I call this facility and was told they did not have my lab results I would have to call the hospital medical records dept to obtain them..... Called there and of course was sent back to the WIC. Spoke to a nurse finally who informed me I had  Community acquired MRSA and needed to come in and see them or see my GP well of coarse I would not go back to them....they never called me to tell me how serious this was...contageous or anything for that matter......shouldnt they have called? Well my GP saw me and immediately did lab work and set me to Infectious Disease. I am now on Zyvox and other meds to control this although I am very scared...I am very tired have a cough and headaches......My fiance who lives elsewhere is very angry at me since I wont let him see me and I am scared for my daughter..... My main concern was going 2 months with no proper treatment.  Is it common for a Dr. not to call you and tell you something is wrong and proper treatment and follow up is necessary???? People have died from this..... Can I see my Fiance? My daughter lives with me but I just take precautions the best I can..... Scared and confused     Marie
posted_time: Post  by mariea » Sat Apr 30, 2005 7:08 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mariea, It is quite unusual for a patient not to be notified of an abnormal result such as yours. I can't give you any explaination except that whomever was responsible for reviewing the lab tests didn't alert the physician to the results. You can certainly see your fiancee (please don't isolate yourself from family, friends and loved ones). Some precautions that you should take are practicing good hygiene, handwashing etc. Keep draining or open areas covered until healed. Don't share personal items, towels, wash cloths, razors, etc.etc. Here is a web link that has some information regarding community aquired MRSA (If you have had no hospitalizations recently and it's not hospital aquired. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/HIP/aresist/ca_mrsa.htm I hope you find this information somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Scabies v Folliculitis
content: Hello,  I have experienced itching skin, which later became red bumps for at least the past 2 months.  I was initially treated for scabies by my primary care doctor about 6 wks ago.  When the itch didn't go away for about 7 days, and the itching increased, I was sent to see a dermatologist as there were some itching on my face.  My dermatologist thought it was also scabies but did a biopsy.  The result came back with folliculities.  I'm currently under treatment for about 2 days not and the itching hasn't gone away yet.   When I was initially diagosed with scabies, I stayed away from my family and b/f.  To date, no one else has experienced an itch.  My nurse told me that folliculities was not contagious so I had oral sex with my b/f last night and began to resume my activities with my family.  Was this a mistake?  Pls. advise.  Also, I'm not convinced that I have folliculitis as my bumps don't have pus and not in zig-zag line.  Instead, they either appear as 2-3 bumps with spaces in between in a straight line or just all scattered as dots.  I'm clear between the fingers, and the "dried up" red spots are not brown spots.  Could I  have both folliculitis and scabies or do I really just have folliculitis?  Is the biopsy result really accurate?  Pls. advise.    Your professional expertise in this matter would be greatly appreciated!!!
posted_time: Post  by pooh_bear » Mon Apr 25, 2005 2:12 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pooh_bear, Here is a past post regarding scabies. Scabies doesn't usually affect the face. If during your treatment for scabies, you followed all the precautions, including washing all your clothing items etc. it is unlikely that this is the cause. A biopsy is usually definitive and if the results were folliculitis this is treated with antibiotic therapy. http://www.doctorslounge.com/forums/vie ... highlight= Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ? NASOPHARYNGITIS
content: Your symptoms are suggestive of an upper respiratory tract infection known as nasopharyngitis. This is caused by a virus or bacteria, but more commonly by a virus.  It is advisable to consult a doctor to determine if it is of viral or bacterial aetiology and also to check if it has spread to the lower respiratory tract. Antibiotics are not indicated for upper respiratory viral infections but your doctor will plan your management after examination.  I note from your profile that you are on the medication ACTIFED. Is this a short-term or long-term therapy and is it doctor-prescribed?  Thank you for a sample of your artistic impression on our notice board - the medical crew admired it.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: LONG-TERM USE OF ACTIFED
content: I have to advise against the long-term use of Actifed preparations for allergies because it is a systemic decongestant, and not recommended as an anti-allergic drug. Actifed contains two drugs, one of which is pseudoephedrine.  Pseudoephedrine must be used with caution due to its side-effects and potential to cause problems with some pre-existing medical conditions.  Dr Anthony Solomon

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi wjk3, The head and face in adults are usually spared by scabies. Scabies are treated with a scabicide applied from the chin to toes and you shower about 12 hours later and repeat this in 1 week. Clothing items and other personal contacts should also be treated. If you have any lesions on your head or face these are not likely to be a result of scabies. The appearance of scabies:    It is very unlikely that treatment fails, the appearance of scabies again is by reinfestation. If you have had appropriate treatment and are still having the problem it is unlikely that it is scabies (providing you have not been reinfested) I would suggest that you ask your dermatologist to do a scraping because scabies, fungal infections etc. can be indentified under a microscope. Prednisone and benadryl are used to treat inflammation and itching but the problem certainly needs identified for the apropriate form of treatment. Has there been any lab work, biopsies etc. done? You may also want to inquire about these things as since it is a long standing problem. I hope this is somewhat helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi wjk3, To me, this looks different than the cases of scabies I have seen, however, I will bring this to the attention of one of the fine doctors of the forum for their opinion. In my opinion you do need a scraping at the very least and if it is not definative then also a biopsy. You have to remember to insist, it is your body after all. Now as for the medication, call the dermatology office, talk to the doctor, explain to him/her that you are out of your prescription medication and can't afford to have it re-filled. They usually carry sufficient samples and provide them to patients as trials prior to getting the prescriptions filled or when they can't afford the particular drug.  Call the office.   Also there are free clinics to assist people whom are uninsured etc. that provide health care if you have a chance to check them out. Here is a link for the NC area. http://www.ncfreeclinics.org/  I hope this helps. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: FLAKY LESION ON PENIS
content: Dermatological lesions are difficult to diagnose without a visual examination. Over the net, a detailed description and close-up photographs may be helpful. You have not stated if you are circumcised, if the lesion is situated on the glans, prepuce or shaft of the penis.   A circumscribed lesion with flaky grey or silvery scales on a red or pinkish base  is suggestive of psoriasis. It is not a sexually transmitted disease. It can also affect the margin of the hairline, if that is what you have described as "bottom ring of my head". Psoriasis of the genitalia may present some months before psoriasis elsewhere.  For definitive diagnosis, please consult a dermatologist.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine      .

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi queentraci, Generally speaking, the symptoms that accompany "pink eye" are redness, swelling, itching, drainage etc. One may experience dry eyes related to certain medications, environmental irritants, decreased tear production due to a variety of medical illnesses. I would suggest that to start with you have an evaluation done by an opthamologist to rule out any eye disorders. In my opinion dependency upon eye drops is highly unlikely. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Wondering  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Thu Mar 03, 2005 6:24 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Gigi!  I have suffered from sinus infections for several years.  It is not uncommon to start to wheeze with a sinus infection because, when you are reclining or sleeping, sometimes the post nasal drip will drip into your trachea instead of down your esophagus.  There is also a well known triad that consists of nasal polyps, aspirin sensitivity and asthma.  Sometimes the aspirin sensitivity can also include the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications like ibuprofen, naproxen, etc.  So, you may want to take note if you get that feeling after you have taken such a medication even if you never had a problem with them before or have never had asthma.  I hope this information helps!

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Tracy, First of all, you honestly need'nt worry so much! I'll try here to explain things for you, and if you still have questions, please don't hesitate to ask. Staphylococcus Aureus (SA) are a group of bacteria which are very commonly found on the skin and cause infections. But there are many different types and the particular type known as MRSA (methicillin resistant Staph aureus) is causing increasing problems because, as the name suggests, it is very resistant to treatment with antibiotics. Even some of our most powerful antibiotics, such as methicillin, can't stop it in its tracks. Around 30% of people carry the germ SA in their nose or on their skin (this is often referred to as being 'colonised' with the germ). SA and MRSA are not normally a risk to healthy people and the majority of people 'colonised' with SA do not have any symptoms and aren’t aware they are carrying the germ. If colonised, one becomes 'infected' with SA if the bacteria get into the body through a break in the skin. In case of 'colonisation', a special antibiotic called mupirocin is usually applied to the skin or the inside of the nose to remove the bacteria. Skin and hair may be washed with special disinfectants. As for specific treatment of 'infection', antibiotics aren’t completely powerless against MRSA. The 'infection' may simply require a much higher dose over a much longer period, or the use of an alternative antibiotic to which the germ has less resistance. The long-term risk of SA is the chance that it may become resistant to all antibiotic drugs. For this reason it is important that antibiotics are only used when necessary and the full course of a drug is taken when it has been prescribed. It is also very important to take basic hygiene precautions. This includes covering cuts and broken skin with waterproof plasters and washing hands frequently and thoroughly.

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Hepatitis C
content: Hello,  Hepatitis C is a bloodborne virus that attacks the liver causing acute hepatitis and chronic liver disease and can include cirrhosis and liver cancer. It is spread through direct exposure to blood or body fluids that contain the HCV. Exposure can be via illegal drug injections, unscreened blood or blood product transfusions, organ or tissue transfusion (prior to 1992), clotting factor concentrates (prior to 1987),  multiple sexual partners, exposure through work such as health care provider, public safety worker, doctor, nurse to HCV positive blood (accidental needle pokes, blood incidents, etc), and children born to HCV positive women.  OSHA – Occupational Safety & Health Administration (USA) have requirement standards for Enforcement Procedures for the Occupational Exposure to Bloodborne Pathogens in the work place. Perhaps your husband’s work place has this policy or the local Health Departments can give you more information on bloodborne pathogens and testing locations in your area.

From the lesion on the foreskin, it first started out looking like one patch the size of a vegetable pea. Within this patch, small tiny pencil lead tip size bumps are forming with no discoloration, no bleeding or pus discharge at all. The only symptom I was experiencing is slight itching on or around the lesion. I didn't experience painful urination. So, with this in mind I thought that my lesion was just an abrasion on the foreskin and decided to let it heal over time.   Three months past and the lesion on my foreskin started to have differnt looks now. It grew from a pea size to the size of a quarter. There is discoloration now. The color of the lesion went from normal foreskin color to a white color and very often small dark red patches inside this quarter size lesion. Sometimes there was a pimple like dot in the middle or center which look like a pus or fluid of some kind. This pimple never bleed or pus never drain. Again it just itch and wasn't painful. When I urinate, no pain or discomfort was experience. So this is what made me see a doctor.   The Doctor examine the lesion and wasn't sure what it was. Doctor said it might be syphilis but again wasn't sure. So she said I will be tested for all STDs. A blood culture and slide impression of the lesion was taken. Doctor tolded me to check back by the end of the week. The end of week came and I went back to see my test results. Doctor stated that all my results are negative. Nothing came back postive. So, the doctor just referred me to the deparment of health where another doctor who was a STD specialist seen me.  The STD specialist said it could be syphilis but again it could be something else. This doctor who has been practicing this for years had no clue. In the end, he decided to also do another blood culture and slide impression of my foreskin lesion. He informed me to check later by the end of the week for results. I went back and again my results were all negative. STD specialist conducted this second STD test because he said that the first one could have been a false test. STD specialist just recommended that I should thoroughly clean under the foreskin of my penis since I was not circumsized. He said give it about a month and if nothing happens check back.   I took his advice and clean my penis foreskin thoroughly for two months. After these months the lesion is still there and remains the size of a quarter. I went back to the first doctor that seen me and he referred me to another doctor at the same hospital. This third doctor conducted another blood culture just for the record or to close the book on STD he said. Results came back negative again. So he said it might be chancroid so he had me take dose of Azithromycin. he said lets see how this medications does for a month and check back. Its almost been a month now and its seem to be growing. I now have a hemorrhoid like bump near my anus. So what do you think? I really worried about this. I wonder if it is something relating to cancer or possibly a STD that is durment. Help.

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: HPV question
content: You may be seeing sebaceous glands which are associated with hair follicles or th apocrine glands, also associated with hair follicles  Sebaceous glands produce a white oily substance called sebum and if squeezed this material can be pushed out but don't squeeze them, this could cause them to become infected or injured. As you shave this could be irritating either of these types of glands or make them more noticeable to you.  Now, about HPV - There is no “cure” for HPV infection, although in most women the "flare up" goes away on its own.  Most women are diagnosed with HPV on the basis of abnormal Pap tests and cervical cancer has been related to HPV. No HPV tests are available for men at this time.  http://www.niaid.nih.gov/factsheets/stdhpv.htm

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: law suit and MRSA
content: This is a very good link that explains in clear terms what this infections is; http://www.health.state.ny.us/nysdoh/co ... n/mrsa.htm  This is a very informative conversation about MRSA with Dr. Yasser Mokhtars from The Doctor’s Lounge.He talks about medication, how contagious MRSA is, where it is found on our bodies, etc. MRSA has claimed the husband of the woman he is talking with incase you do not want to read it. http://www.doctorslounge.com/infectionl ... -1102.html  MRSA stands for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It is a type of bacterium commonly found on the skin and/or in the noses of healthy people. Although it is usually harmless at these sites, it may occasionally get into the body (eg through breaks in the skin such as abrasions, cuts, wounds, surgical incisions or indwelling catheters) and cause infections. These infections may be mild (eg pimples or boils) or serious (eg infection of the bloodstream, bones or joints).  In order to sue for negligence or damages you must first prove they were negligent and because of their negligence, damages or harm have been done that are permanent and/or irreversable and it is directly caused from the negligence. If you feel you can do that, than you should try. It's a very expensive process and hard to win.
