author: Kathy C, RN  Nurse Posts: 84 Joined: Tue Jan 25, 2005 5:57 am Location: Titusville Florida
title: [no title]
content: Hi Pennylane, I am sorry to hear about your miscarriage. I know that it is a hard thing to deal with. I would definitly tell your physician about your underarm pain and other complaints. It may have nothing at all to do with what you are dealing with but sometimes you can get swollen lymph nodes in your arm pit area from infections.  You mentioned you had a viral infection and now since you are on a antibiotic I am assuming it is bacterial. Bacterial infections may develop after a viral illness, such as a cold or influenza, and are less common than viral illnesses. Bacterial infections may affect the upper or lower respiratory system. Symptoms tend to localize to one area. In the upper respiratory system, the most common sites of bacterial infections are the ears, sinuses, and throat. In the lower respiratory system, the most common sites are the bronchial tubes (bronchitis) and the lungs (pneumonia).  Bacterial infections are more common in smokers, people exposed to secondhand smoke, and people with chronic lung disease (such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and other chronic medical problems. Antibiotics can effectively treat most bacterial infections.  There are a few steps you can take to reduce your risk of catching a cold or influenza. They include the following:   Wash Your Hands Often   Hand washing is the most neglected, yet most effective, method of disease containment. The primary means of spreading both colds and influenza is person-to-person contact. Effective ways to prevent respiratory infections include: 1) washing your hands thoroughly and often, and 2) avoiding hand-to-hand passage of germs and droplet sprays from sneezing and coughing.   Avoid Crowds During Influenza Season   This may not be a very practical suggestion for everyone. However, if you are at high risk of catching a cold or influenza, or at risk for developing complications from these infections, try to avoid crowded areas or people who are obviously sick during the winter influenza season.   Get a "Flu Shot"   Each year, the World Health Organization tries to determine which strains of the influenza virus will be most dangerous in the upcoming influenza season. Vaccines are developed for these strains.   Anyone may benefit from a flu shot, but vaccination is strongly recommended every fall for several groups of people people who are at the highest risk for complications. These include:   People over age 50 Infants aged 6-23 months Residents of chronic care facilities and nursing homes  Those with chronic illnesses, especially of the heart, lungs, blood, and kidneys  People with a weakened immune system Women more than three months pregnant during flu season Health care workers who come in contact with sick patients  Caregivers or household members of persons in high risk groups  Flu shots are available at doctors' offices, hospitals, local public health offices, and at some workplaces, stores or shopping malls. A possible side effect is a mild "flu-like" reaction including fever, aching, and fatigue. Up to 5% of people experience these symptoms after having the influenza vaccine.   Please strongly consider stoping smoking which can exacerbate any respiratory problem. Take care of yourself, vitamins espically zinc and vit c are important. Follow up with your physician about your other complaints. I hope this helps you and I wish you well.

Other than this, our genitals have never touched and i did not do oral sex to him.  I have no symptoms of disease.  I believe he has herpes simplex I on his mouth, but at the time of the incident he was not having any outbreaks and hasn't had on in a while.  As i understand it, viral shedding can make it possible for the infection to be spread.  The oral sex incident was unplanned and now I am worrying out of my mind that something may have been transmitted this way.    I know you can't tell me for sure that I am okay or that Probably I am okay, but I am wondering precisely how risky is what i have done?  I mean, is there a 1% chance I have contracted something?  a 50% chance?  Can you give me a ball park guess?    Like i said, i have never done anything with anyone else in the history of my life at all like this and I am so afraid that because of my irresponsibility with my first sexual experience i will have gotten something and then ruin the rest of my sexual life when I haven't even really had one.  I am sorry I sound crazy; I am just so worried.  Please tell me your thoughts...

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: sexual herpes
content: If you have had cold sores before or canker sores, you may have an immunity built up to HSV-1. I have put a website link on here for you  if you're interested in it.  http://www.herpes.com/hsv1-2.html  By the time we are teenagers or young adults, about 50% of Americans have HSV-1 antibodies in their blood. By the time they are over age 50, some 80-90% of Americans have HSV-1 antibodies.  A prior infection with oral HSV-1 lowers the risk of acquiring genital HSV-1 even further. Studies show that genital HSV-1 infections almost always occur in people who have no prior infection with HSV of either type (Corey, Annals of Internal Medicine, 1983).  In the absence of prior oral infection, however, HSV-1 spreads easily to the genital area, usually through oral sex. In some countries, such as Japan and parts of Great Britain, genital HSV-1 is as common as genital HSV- 2, or more common.

author: Kathy C, RN  Nurse Posts: 84 Joined: Tue Jan 25, 2005 5:57 am Location: Titusville Florida
title: [no title]
content: Dear Jessss,  You may be palpating lymph nodes. I found a lump as you described years ago before I was a nurse just to the side of my breast. certain I had cancer. The Doctor let me know I had done such a great job at my breast exam that I had found a lymph node. Look at this site, is shows where they are located.  http://training.seer.cancer.gov/ss_modu ... hains.html  All of us have hundreds of lymph nodes scattered throughout our bodies as a critical part of our immune systems. This network of nodes functions as a powerful, intelligent filtration system to keep the insides of our bodies clean and healthy.  Tiny vessels called lymph vessels carry germs, foreign particles, and unhealthy or malignant cells to the lymph nodes, where they are trapped. Active lymph nodes enlarge as they attempt to destroy the unwelcome material.  The lymph nodes also function as schools. Lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, study the foreign material so that they can produce antibodies, killer cells, and other substances to protect the body from the threat.  Sometimes the lymph nodes are overwhelmed in the process. Our defenders can be taken over by a infection. These enlarged nodes can become a refuge where the invaders can hide and proliferate.  Please take care and follow up with your physician.

author: jennykert  Guest Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 11:28 am Location: North East US
title: antibiotic trouble/bronchitis
content: I was diagnosed with bronchitis 3 1/2 weeks ago and give Ceftin to take for 10 days.  After 6 days, I developed colitis and was advised to stop the antibiotics.  I stopped and the colitis resolved itself within a week.  I developed sinus pressure and went back to the doctor on Friday.  He could still hear some gurgling in my lungs and said I had a sinus infection.  He gave me 7 - 500mg samples of Levaquin.  Took everyday with lots of water.  Had mild side effects:  nausea, bad taste in mouth, dizziness, increased eye pressure.  All of these were at their worst 1-2 hours after taking pill.  On day 3, 1 hour after taking pill, I had vision problems (seeing spots) sensitivity to light, and got a migraine (had 1 migraine in my life 15 years ago)  It was frightening.  Called doctor and he said this was not related to the drug.  He told me to take again and I did with the same side effect--migraine.  I stopped taking it.  I am willing to accept side effects, but this was frightening.  I have taken amox. eryth in the past with no problems  I know it is not good to stop taking antibiotics.  Do I have to be concerned about getting really sick.  My symptoms have improved greatly.  Although my cough is loose, I still feel a little rumble in my back, at the bottom of my left lung. Should I call my doctor again--he was a bit dismissive last time--but I don't want to get really sick.  Thanks Jenny
posted_time: Post  by jennykert » Wed Mar 16, 2005 12:01 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jennykert, Headache or lightheadedness, increased sensitivity of the skin to sunlight are a couple of the less serious side effects of Levaquin. So in answer to your question, yes, the headaches may be caused by this particular medication. I would suggest you call your physician back, tell him/her that due to this side effect you feel you can't take the drug and also inquire (especially since you have taken amoxicillin and erythromycin in the past) why either wasn't prescribed for the bronchitis in place of the others. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Help!  Could this still be mono?
content: My 13 year old daughter has not been feeling well since last Saturday, 3/5/05 ~ sore throat, fever (low 99-100) that is on and off, extreme fatigue, headache, upset stomach, and constantly complaining of feeling dizzy.  She stayed home from school on Monday the 7th, went to school on the 8th but had to come home early.  I took her to the dr. that day and they thought she had mono.  They did labs and sent us home with Zithromax.  She did not go to school the rest of the week and continued to be ill over the weekend with the same complaints as above with the exception of the fever seemed to be more “on” than “off”.  I took her back to the doctor on Monday the 14th and was told that her labs were positive for a past mono infection within the last 2-3 months but nothing current.  They indicated her labs were also positive for allergies.  They said that she should be fine and with the exception of her allergies “acting up” i.e. ears looked fine, throat looked ok, etc..  They gave her Singular, Rhinocort, another round of Zithromax and gave her a shot of something.  I’m guessing a steroid but they didn’t say.  I should have asked.    I guess my question is……could she have the mono now even though the labs reported a past positive?  She has been feeling great up until last week…..hasn’t been sick at all!  Which is uncommon for her because she, historically, seems to have a weakened system (pneumonia x2, scarlet fever x2, numerous ear infections, etc).  Now she can hardly get off the couch, is still running a fever and is constantly crying about not feeling good.    Pleas help!
posted_time: Post  by amyswag1 » Tue Mar 15, 2005 8:57 am

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear amyswag1, Infectious mononucleosis (often called "mono") is a common viral infection that causes fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. Mono is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, in more than 90% of cases, but other viruses, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), can also cause mono. Once infected with one virus, a person develops lifelong immunity to future infections by the same virus, but not to other types of viruses causing mono. Mono can also be mixed up with other serious conditions, but that can usually be excluded by simple lab tests as a blood count and an ESR. If you haven't had them done, please discuss this with your doctor. If the condition proves to be mono, I'd like to assure you that it generally goes away without medical help. However, it may last from weeks to months. Treatment is mainly to ease symptoms, usually at home, with plenty of rest and fluids, acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever and pain control. Schedule routine visits with your doctor, so he/she can monitor the course of the illness and detect possible complications. If her condition worsens at any time, do not hesitate to take her immediately to the hospital. Please keep us informed with what's going on.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Heba Ismail » Wed Mar 16, 2005 11:03 am

content: Thank you so much for your reply!  My daughter did have labs done for mono and they came back positive for a past infection 2-3 months prior.  However, she has not been ill in the past six months so I was wondering if she could be experiencing the symptoms of mono now even though the lab results say she currently does not have mono.  Does that make any sense?
posted_time: Post  by amyswag1 » Wed Mar 16, 2005 11:18 am

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear amyswag1, I apologise for not making myself clear.  A previous infection with mono may sometimes pass unnoticed clinically, and would only appear a few months later in lab results. Since the Epstein-Barr virus is the common cause for mono, it is the virus usually tested for, while other viruses are not, and the test is usually referred to as the test for mono, which is of course a misnomer! It could be misleading, as in your daughter's case, where she has a picture of mono now, but negative labs for a current infection. However, I need to know if also a blood picture and ESR were done or not? The picture of mono could sometimes be mistaken with other serious problems and we need to rule them out!

author: christophe.claude  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Tue Mar 08, 2005 3:37 pm Location: Munich
title: question on a thrombosis probably caused by a mastoiditis
content: Hi,  In february this year (2005) my 5 years old son had the following: otitis, mastoiditis, meningitis and a thrombosis of the sinus sigmoideus (up to the jugular vein) It is highly probable that the menigitis was caused by the mastoiditis which in turn was caused by the otitis, this seems to be a typical causal chain. The thrombosis was also probably caused by the "infection", although it is  unclear to me if the main reason was the mastoiditis or the meningitis (I hope that this is irrelevant)   the mastoiditis was chirurgically treated, the meningitis was treated with antibiotics (and I guess the otitis disappeared alltogether, I never hearder about it again!!).  Now we are left with this annoying  thrombosis. The medical team was unsure on how to handle it, they first decided to do nothing and after a while decided to give him Heparin in injection (called fragmin in germany)  every day. The cause of a thrombosis is typically a blood problem, but for my son the reason was the infection. This single fact seems to be  embarrasing because there is apparently only little medical literature on "children"  thrombosis with this cause.   I do not expect you to "magically" solve that problem.  I would appreciate if you could tell me where I can learn more about all that, or where do I have a chance to find a "similar" case.
posted_time: Post  by christophe.claude » Tue Mar 08, 2005 4:25 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi christophe.claude, Infective causes of the middle ear, head trauma, severe infections, etc. do cause this condition but the condition is relatively uncommon. However, generally speaking, this type of thrombis is usually resolved following rehydration and the administration of systemic antibiotics. Steroids and systemic anticoagulation may be beneficial. Probably the reason you never heard about the otitis again is the antibiotics took care of this problem. Your right about available literature since this is relatively an uncommon condition. Here is a link that has other references that might be of use to you. I certainly hope that a neurologist has been included in on your childs care. http://qjmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/full/95/3/137 Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Anima_Sola  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Mar 10, 2005 3:23 am Location: Minneapolis  Contact:   Contact Anima_Sola       Yahoo Messenger   AOL
title: Sore throat for two months, tonsils huge... doctor shrugged.
content: Okay.  Let's go back two months.  My grandma was dying of cancer, and I was one of her main caregivers.  Stress? Yes, much.  So I got sick, about a week before she died I caught a cold, with a slight sore throat.  A week and a half later, sore throat got more severe, severe enough to send me in for a strep test the day of her funeral.  Went to Minute Clinic (that's a joke, took 4 hours). Both rapid and culture were negative.  Shrug.  Okay.  I can live with that.    Three weeks later, it's not any better, but I'd buried my grandma and started a full time job.  Had no time to be sick or to worry about it.  Finally, I woke up one morning with my uvula looking about twice the size of my thumb, and twice as long as normal... literally choking on it in the morning.  Went to call in to work, couldnt speak.  Laryngitis is not unusual for me.  Doctor says I have cellulitis in my throat, and to go home and rest.  Gave me prednisone (thank god... that stuff rocks), and keflex.  I take both as prescribed, the uvula swelling went down that night, but my sore throat never went away.  So.. a week of debating, and it's back to the doctor.  He claims that I caught another virus on top of the first, because the cellulitis is gone, but my tonsils are huge.  Mmmkay... so... we do nothing for this? sigh.  Figures.  He also decides at this point that I may have sleep apnea and I tell him I've known for years that I do.  I don't have insurance right now, and can definitely not afford a sleep study.  Woo. Nope.  Anyways.    So I go home and suck it up.  Already being out the full cost of two doctors visits and two prescriptions.  Now, I went out the other day.  Had a drink.  Literally, immediately afterwards, my tonsils swell up horribly, enough to make me panic that my throat is closing up.  I drank water for a bit, and thought maybe it was the type of alcohol... so I try another.  (heh, persistant, yes?) The swelling didnt go away, but it didnt get worse... I took two ibuprofen.  I know, bad idea with alcohol but was desperate.  Swelling goes away.  Yay.   Now, tonight.  I take one sip of one beer and automatically it swells up again.  'Grr.'    So, after ALL of that... my question I suppose is a chicken or egg sort.  Having never had a negative reaction to alcohol of any sort (well, obviously other than the blessed hangover...), am i having some sort of allergic reaction to the alcohol? Or is it this dang persistant virus that is the main culprit, and the alcohol just makes it worse?  And what the heck kind of virus lasts two months?  I disagree with my doctor in his theory that it was a new virus after the first, it never let up at all and I feel its the same one.  I did have 48 hours of over 103 degree fever and flu-ish symptoms last weekend... Other than that, I've been a pretty consistent 99.5 ish.    I am at a loss of what to do as far as home care... I also have a barking type cough.  Ooh, and some fun headaches and dizziness thrown in.  Lovin it.    Couldn't be mono, could it?    So, I'll be staying away from alcohol.  ( obviously... fool be once, shame on you... twice, shame on me. )   Tonsilitis?  Shrug.    Ayudame, por favor.

author: Kathy C, RN  Nurse Posts: 84 Joined: Tue Jan 25, 2005 5:57 am Location: Titusville Florida
title: [no title]
content: Dear blastoff,  I am going to be honest with you as best as I can. At age 13 you are taking big risks with your health and your life by having unprotected sex. Not only can you aquire sexually transmiited diseases some of which can kill you (AIDS) but you are also at risk of getting pregnant. I urge you to see your physician and get an exam. Please think about the rest of your life. You are worth saying NO and waiting to have SEX with anyone. You have the rest of your life ahead of you.   Your body is precious and you need to treat it with respect meaning that you wait to have relations with someone untill you are older and you can make better decisions. ONE form of birth control is condoms which give you a better chance of protection but still not 100%. Please speak to someone that you trust and let them know your concerns. I will give you some info on HERPES but as I said only your physician can give you a definitive diagnosis.    Genital herpes is an infection caused by the herpes simplex virus or HSV. There are two types of HSV, and both can cause genital herpes. HSV type 1 most commonly infects the lips, causing sores known as fever blisters or cold sores, but it also can infect the genital area and produce sores. HSV type 2 is the usual cause of genital herpes, but it also can infect the mouth. A person who has genital herpes infection can easily pass or transmit the virus to an uninfected person during sex.  Both HSV 1 and 2 can produce sores (also called lesions) in and around the vaginal area, on the penis, around the anal opening, and on the buttocks or thighs. Occasionally, sores also appear on other parts of the body where the virus has entered through broken skin.  What are the symptoms? Unfortunately, most people who have genital herpes don't know it because they never have any symptoms, or they do not recognize any symptoms they might have. When there are symptoms, they can be different in each person. Most often, when a person becomes infected with herpes for the first time, the symptoms will appear within 2 to 10 days. These first episodes of symptoms usually last 2 to 3 weeks.  Early symptoms of a genital herpes outbreak include  Itching or burning feeling in the genital or anal area  Pain in the legs, buttocks, or genital area  Discharge of fluid from the vagina  Feeling of pressure in the abdomen  Within a few days, sores appear near where the virus has entered the body, such as on the mouth, penis, or vagina. They also can occur inside the vagina and on the cervix in women, or in the urinary passage of women and men. Small red bumps appear first, develop into blisters, and then become painful open sores. Over several days, the sores become crusty and then heal without leaving a scar.  Other symptoms that may go with the first episode of genital herpes are fever, headache, muscle aches, painful or difficult urination, vaginal discharge, and swollen glands in the groin area.

content: All STDs are treatable, but they are not all curable.  Try not to make yourself crazy in the meantime - I know it is easier said than done. Keep in mind that it may not be an STD at all. title: [no title]
content: Hi Juggie, Since the culture was negative for the bacteria strep, the white patches on the tonsils and sore throat may have been related to tonsillitis or a viral infection, both which cause similar appearances. If your condition was related to tonsillitis that's why the antibiotic made you feel better. However, antibiotics have no affect on viral conditions and they just have to run their course. In my opinion, your physician provided appropriate treatment. If you are dissatisfied with your current provider and you feel the way that you do then I encourage you to find a provider in which you are more comfortable. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: joannag wrote:please help - my twelve year old has an open sore on her labia.  She has the flu also, and I seem to remember her having this sore once before.  She HAS NOT had any sexual contact ..I thought herpes but without sexual contact how could it be??  Sorry but this sounds like classic Herpes.  The first and some subsequent attacks are accompanied by flu-like symptoms.  I have had it for 14 years and know it well.  I don't mean to doubt you, but are you sure about the sexual contact?  I got mine from a facial cold sore of my partner during oral sex, not regular sex.  Also Herpes is HIGHLY contagious and can survive outside the body for a looooong time, ie. if she was at someone's house and used their towel...  if she has a facial sore and has scratched that, and then somewhere else... even though they are different strains of the virus, it still happens.  Also HSV can be on other parts of the body other than face or genitals.  My mother has it on her thigh.  You never know.  Take her to a doctor and get a test done to be sure.  I can see no other explaination for an open genital sore.

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello: Here are some facts about Molluscum Contagiosum.  It is a skin disease caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) usually causing one or more small lesions/bumps. MCV is generally a benign infection and symptoms may self-resolve. It is believed to be a member of the pox virus family.   Molluscum contagiosum may be sexually transmitted by skin-to-skin contact (does not have to be mucous membranes) and/or lesions. Transmission through sexual contact is the most common form of transmission for adults.   MCV may be transmitted from inanimate objects such as towels and clothing that come in contact with the lesions. MCV transmission has been associated with swimming pools and sharing baths with an infected person.  MCV also may be transmitted by autoinoculation, such as touching a lesion and touching another part of the body.   Lesions are usually present on the thighs, buttocks, groin and lower abdomen of adults, and may occasionally appear on the external genital and anal region. The lesions may begin as small bumps which can develop over a period of several weeks into larger sores/bumps. The lesions can be flesh colored, gray-white, yellow or pink. They can cause itching or tenderness in the area, but in most cases the lesions cause few problems. Lesions can last from 2 weeks to 4 years -- the average is 2 years.   The incubation period averages 2 to 3 months and may range from 1 week to 6 months.  How long one is infectious is not known for certain,  but researchers assume that if the virus is present it may be transmitted.   Most symptoms are self-resolving, but generally lesions are removed. Lesions may recur, but it is not clear whether this is due to reinfection, exacerbation of subclinical infection, or reactivation of latent infection.   Because transmission through sexual contact is the most common form of transmission for adults, preventing skin-to-skin contact with an infected partner will be most effective in preventing MCV.  Unfortunately, unless you used in vitro fertilization, there is no way to get pregnant without risking contracting the disease, until the lesions are gone. Regards, CArolyn

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM
content: In immunocompetent children, mollusca lesions resolve spontaneously and aggressive therapy is not indicated.  However, in view of the fact that eradication of these lesions is delayed with the topical treatment given, and the condition is cosmetically unpleasant and may cause concern among parents of other children at school, I think you should opt for a clinician-directed office therapy which I have used with great success in adults and children.  This method is known as curettage, and involves removal of the lesions with a small curette causing little discomfort or no pain. Other clinician-directed therapies exist and you should discuss the options with your physician or dermatologist.   I hope this information is helpful.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM

title: Side effects of Levaquin  please help.
content: Yesterday (2-7-05) I went to the ER because my hands were numb and I could not stop trembling.  Earlier in the morning when it started I thought I was just having a panic attack, because  lately I seem to get about 2 a month.  But I never had the trembles like that for a few hours or numbness in my hands.  I always have rapid heartbeat and pain in my arm that goes away usually within 30 minutes.  EKG was ok, my heartbeat was a little high aruond 100.  Turns out is was a panic attack...I think.  They are still waiting on my thyroid test to come back.  They did a CBC blood test which did come back OK, no infections or anything else abnormal.  I was prescribed 0.5 mg of xanax.  I had an appointment with my regular physican that afternoon anyway because I had a sinus infection that would not completely go away.  So when I went to that appointment I was prescribed levaquin 500mg.  Amazingly the xanax worked and I felt fine this morning.  I was told I could take them when needed and did not have to take them daily.  I started the levaquin this morning and after reading about it online, I completely put myself into another panic attack and had to take a xanax.  Is levaquin really safe to take?  I've heard of all these horror stories from people who take them.  I'm a 28 year old female I've never had an allergic reaction to any medicine before,  (lets pray not now) I've been keeping my water bottle by me all day, trying to flush this drug out of me.    How long would it take to see an allergic reaction from this?  An hour? 10 hours? 24 hours?  I'm on 4 hours since I took it.  Are my odds less of a side effect because I only took one?  Why would I get this antibiotic if my CBC showed no infections?  Was my hear rate up because of the panic attack?  Also, since I'm prone to panic, if anyone knows how to tell a normal ache and pain to something serious, even if its just an opinion I'd appreciate it.  I think that sometimes I suffer for no reason, because I focus too much on small things.
posted_time: Post  by alwaysscared » Tue Feb 08, 2005 1:49 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Side effects of Levaquin please help
content: Dear Alwaysscared,  Any medication has potential side effects that occur in only a portion of the patients who take this medication and levaquin is not different.  There is no need to fear the side effect as long as it is recognized early on and the medication stopped.  i am not sure what are the horror stories that you read about levaquin online but i have seen way too many people take it with no side effects whatsoever. You have to take a look at both faces of the coin not just one.  Most probably you have a chronic sinus infection and with chronic infections, the white count does not have to be high.  Panic attacks causes increase in the heart rate.  Pain is a totally subjective sensation. i don't think that there is a way to tell if the pain that any patient is suffering from is actually there or not (meaning that there is no objective way to determine whether or not pain is present and hence it can not be quantified).  When assessing a patient, all of the symptoms that the patient suffers from are taken into consideration including the pain if present.  If you think you have a problem in regards to pain, you have to talk to your doctor about that and let him/her decide what is this pain related to and whether or not it has a serious cause and how to treat it.  i think the only way to differentiate between serious pain and non-serious pain is to be evaluated by a health care provider.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Kathy C, RN  Nurse Posts: 84 Joined: Tue Jan 25, 2005 5:57 am Location: Titusville Florida
title: [no title]
content: Hives are a totally different thing. Here is some info on it. I would suggest that you go to your physician and find out the cause of them. Good luck..  Hives are a sign that the whole body is experiencing a hypersensitivity reaction. Hives occur when the body's capillaries and tiny veins get leaky. Fluid escaping from some of these blood vessels becomes trapped in parts of the skin and lining membranes of the body, causing localized swelling.   This leakiness can be caused by classic allergic reactions in which histamine triggers an inflammatory response. It can also be caused by a number of other regulatory systems in the body in response to different types of triggers.  The most common allergic triggers are drugs, especially antibiotics; foods, especially fish, shellfish, nuts, peanuts, eggs, berries, and food additives; infections (which we'll discuss below); insect bites or stings; inhalants such as animal danders, pollens, and molds; and contact allergens like plant substances, skin creams, cat scratches, moth scales, or animal saliva. In college I had a pet tarantula for a while and some of my friends got hives from petting her hairy abdomen.   There are also a number of distinct physical causes of hives (known as urticaria in doctor-speak):    Cold urticaria – the most common of the physical causes. These hives are triggered by exposure to cold water or air. This would be a good excuse to avoid swimming in cold pools (something my kids love for me to do).   Dermatographia -- hives that appear where the skin is firmly stroked. (Named because you can write on someone's skin by raising welts where your finger traced). This occurs in about 5% of people (and many more if you repeatedly stroke hard enough).    Pressure urticaria -- hives that appear under tightly fitting clothing or jewelry. Unlike dermatographia, which occurs in seconds, this can appear many hours later, obscuring the cause.    Cholinergic urticaria -- hives that occur in response to heat, exercise, or emotional stress. This usually doesn't begin before adolescence.    Aquagenic urticaria -- hives that are triggered by contact with sweat or with water. In these people, exercise itself is not a trigger, and they can drink water without a problem.    Solar urticaria -- a rare disorder in which sun exposure results in hives. Sunscreen can help!  I mentioned earlier that infections could trigger hives. We know that some parasites can be responsible for hives (including giardia and pinworms, which are common in day care settings). We also know that bacterial infections, most notably Strep, can be the culprit. Viruses of many types can trigger hives as well.  Over 70 percent of the time no specific cause is found when children have hives. They were hypersensitive to something, but no one discovers what, and the hives go away. Doctors think that most of these unidentified cases may be from viruses, which would make them the most common cause of hives. This is particularly likely when there is a cluster of cases (although molds, animals, foods, parasites, etc. could also be responsible for clusters).  Who gets it? About 20 percent of people will experience hives at some point in their lives. Those who have known allergies or a family history of allergies are more likely to get hives. All other things being equal, girls are more likely to get them than boys.  What are the symptoms? Wheals or welts come and go on the skin or mucous membranes. These may itch intensely, itch only a little, or not itch at all.   Each typically has a whitish, raised patch of skin surrounded by a reddish halo. The welts may be tiny or large, and may be all over the body or confined to one area.  Is it contagious? Hives themselves are not contagious, but the triggers of hives, especially viruses, bacteria, and parasites, may be contagious.  How long does it last? The individual welts often disappear quickly and are usually gone within 48 hours, although new ones may continue to appear for days or weeks. If new hives keep occurring for six weeks, this is called chronic Urticaria.  How is it diagnosed? Usually hives can be diagnosed based on the history and physical examination. Sometimes specific allergy testing or testing for infection is needed to look for the underlying cause.  Chronic urticaria is usually not serious, but can be a sign of an underlying disease process. Children with chronic hives should have a thorough physical exam and lab work just to be sure there are no underlying illnesses.  How is it treated? Hives are usually treated with an antihistamine, such as Benadryl or the prescription Atarax. If drowsiness is a problem, one of the newer, non-sedating antihistamines may be a better choice. Sometimes antihistamines are coupled with a histamine H2 blocker, such as cimetidine, for a more powerful effect.  A variety of stronger treatments are available, but are usually unnecessary. If there are other allergic symptoms, such as wheezing or tightening of the throat, then a shot of epinephrine may be needed.  How can it be prevented? The best way to prevent another bout of hives is to identify your triggers and avoid them. If you know in advance that you will be exposed to a trigger, a preventive dose of antihistamine can prevent or minimize the
posted_time: Post  by Kathy C, RN » Thu Feb 10, 2005 6:47 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Various types of sores can appear anywhere within the mouth, including tongue. Mouth sores are most often mechanical irritations, cold sores (also called fever blisters), or canker sores. Cold sores are caused by herpes simplex virus and are very contagious. Usually, you have tenderness, tingling, or burning before the actual lesion appears.  If this is a recurring condition that you do not think is related to mechanical irritation then you should consult your physician. There could be an underlying decreased immunity.

title: [no title]
content: Hi mickeymouse123, How deep was the cut and what were you cut on? How long has it been since you have had a tetanus vaccination? Current recommendations are for everyone to receive a Tetanus-diphtheria vaccination at least every 10 years to maintain your immunity. If you get a tetanus prone wound,  then recommendation is  that you receive the shot at least every five years. Contrary to most beliefs of the general population it's not only when you become injured by a "rusty nail" that vaccination is necessary. If it is a minor cut, that didn't require stitches, cleanse the area with an antibacterial product, and apply the antibacterial ointment. There should be an improvement in a couple of days. If not, have an evaluation completed. However, if you are showing any signs of a systemic infection, fever, chills, etc. and the redness/pain continues to increase have an evaluation done immediately. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ? NSU
content: The triad of unprotected sexual intercourse + urethral pain/discomfort + scrotal pain is very suggestive of non-specific urethritis complicated by epididymitis. Please get examined by a genitourinary physician or venereologist.  In non-specific urethrits (NSU), there may be no urethral discharge, no burning on urination and no itching at the end of the urethra. High rates of NSU without urethral discharge or with no symptoms at all have been documented.  When a sexually transmitted disease is suspected, but a discharge is not detected, it is best to be examined in the morning, after not voiding urine overnight,  to enhance the likelihood of reaching a diagnosis.   For your information, NSU is termed NGU (non-gonococcal urethritis) in some countries.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Please have your blood pressure checked with your doctor. That is the basic screening test if you experience dizziness or lightheadedness. New guidelines stipulate that the ideal blood pressure should be below 120/80 and never above 140/90, irrespective of age.  A reading of 140/90 is now considered pre-hypertensive.  Fever is an elevation of body temperature above the customary set point. Temperature in healthy adults is tightly controlled at a mean of 37 degrees Centigrade with a diurnal variation of 0.5 degree (plus or minus). It is important to obtain objective evidence of fever by recording your oral or rectal temperature. Patients who complain of feeling “hot” or “feverish” do not necessarily have fever.   If a fever is confirmed and persistent, your doctor will investigate the cause.  The cause may be linked to your symptoms of dizziness or lightheadedness, assuming that your blood pressure is within the normal range.  Thank you for contacting this website.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Destiny  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Jan 10, 2005 11:47 am
title: Penis discharge ?
content: Hello, I have a question. My friends husband has noticed that he when he has an ejaculation after not having sex for a long period of time his seman has a light brown color to it at first then a normal whitish color, any idea what this could be? He has no other symptoms at all. if he has sex more often the brown color doesnt show up. its only if he hasnt ejaculated for a couple of weeks.
posted_time: Post  by Destiny » Mon Jan 10, 2005 11:55 am

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi,  A brownish or reddish ejaculate indicates blood in the semen and can cause concern to the men who experience it. The condition is common, and many episodes go unnoticed because ejaculation is usually intravaginally. It may be benign or the first indicator of a urologic disease.  It can occur in persons of any age. Most men with this condition are young (average age less than 40 y) and have symptoms ranging in duration from 1-24 months. Blood in the ejaculate that persists for more than 10 ejaculations or 2 months requires further evaluation by a urologist or genitourinary physician. Often, the condition is self-limiting within 2 months.  The patient's blood pressure should be checked because severe hypertension is associated with this condition, and may have a similar basis to the association of hypertension with nosebleeds. Other conditions that could cause blood in the ejaculate include: *Lesions of the urethra that bleed and contribute to the ejaculate, such as polyps, warts and strictures. *Infections of the urethra (urethritis) which may be sexually or non-sexually transmitted. Urethritis has long been recognised as a cause of bloody semen, especially in younger men. *Inflammations of the prostate, such as prostatitis.   *Other conditions of the prostate such as bleeding after a prostate biopsy (which resolves on its own), prostate cancer, prostatic varices, prostatic stones. Blood in the ejaculate of men older than 50 y is occasionally a harbinger of prostate cancer. *Cysts, infections and malignancy of the seminal vesicles (a pair of male accessory sex glands that secrete most of the liquid component of semen). *Systemic diseases, most important of which is severe hypertension as previously mentioned. Others in this category include bleeding disorders, chronic liver disease and lymphoma.  Quite often, the cause is benign,  remains unknown and resolves on its own.  I hope this information will prove helpful for your friend and her husband. Thank you for contacting this website.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine       .

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: I am sorry to hear that your father is seriously ill in hospital.  Tuberculosis and pneumonia are life-threatening diseases and ideally, the patient should be in an Infectious Diseases Unit with facilities for intensive care. Doctors are expected to give patients or their next of kin the information they ask for about their condition, its treatment and prognosis. If the doctor is making himself unavailable for this purpose, you may wish to follow the hospital's procedure for complaints. You have a right to expect a prompt and appropriate response.  If you feel that your father is not getting good and adequate treatment in the present hospital, you have the choice of transferring him to a better unit if one exists in your locality. Please ensure that it is safe to move him if you take the decision.  You complain that the nurses are giving him all kinds of medication. Tuberculosis is a serious and chronic disease that requires multi-drug therapy for six or more months. These drugs have possible adverse effects. Your father may also be having complications, which would require additional medications. I would expect that the doctors and nurses know their jobs and would not give medications if not indicated.  It is of great importance to have family and social contacts investigated for infection with the disease. Please arrange this with your physician.  Thank you for contacting this website.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi,  From your update, it seems that the doctor is optimistic that your father will get better. In fact, I think the medical personnel are doing their best, taking into account the severity of your father's illness, its complications, his age and his loss in weight. Treatment of tuberculosis requires specialized knowledge, particularly where the disease involves resistant organisms or non-respiratory organs.   Although your father is not eating, he is getting all the nutrients his body requires in the intravenous infusions (which he must be having). Antituberculous drugs are frequently associated with liver toxicity as adverse affects and this may be one cause of your father’s loss of appetite. Is there a history of pre-existing liver disease or alcohol dependence?  Please do not forget that your father is elderly, and therefore, his response to severe infections may not be as expected of a healthy, younger adult.  I cannot advise you of  Boston Hospital because I am not domiciled in the US and cannot compare facilities. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Fever is frequently defined as the elevation of body temperature in response to an infection or other disease process. Using the upper limit of normal as 99.9 degrees Fahrenheit, fever would be defined as 100 degrees Fahrenheit (37.7 degrees Celsius) or higher. This is the definition I typically use. Some physicians define fever as 100.4 or 101 degrees Fahrenheit (38 or 38.3 Celsius), however, and I do not believe there is just one correct answer.  A person's normal temperature also varies throughout the day, with the lowest temperature being in the morning and the highest in the late afternoon and early evening.  Women who are ovulating will have a monthly rise of temperature at the time of ovulation. So tinker, as you see you are still within the normal range. And fever is defined not by temperature values but by the presence of infection or a disease process in addition to the temperature change. I don't think there is a reason to worry about the values you mentioned. Best regards,

title: This is me, too..............plus...............
content: I just had to type a response to this because this sounds like me also.  I, however, may have experienced trauma to my hypothalamus or adrenals.  It first started with a hysterectomy in '99 that left me with insomnia such that I woke up every single morning after 4 hours sleep in a sweat and panic.  I was put on sleeping pills (a benzodiazepine) for 2 years and about 3 months into it's usage, I developed between dosage withdrawals that caused me such stress that my thyroid numbers were thrown off and I started to develop numerous allergies and acid reflux and throat gripping anxiety.  I finally tapered off this medication after I started to experience swollen and painful hands and feet and elevated ANA.  I remember earlier that my DHEA was very high as was my cortisol and my anion gap was low (low electrolytes).  As soon as I figured out that the benzo was the cause of all this grief, I weaned myself off of it and many of the symptoms disappeared excluding the painful hands and feet (paresthesia).  It seemed however that after that I could not handle stress at all.  I would shake inside whenever I encountered stress.  On one particular occassion, I was having to deal with my ex-husband and the stress was so bad that I then developed TMJD so very severely that I had to be fitted with a night gard and be put on antiinflammatories, but nothing was helping.  So low estrogen was thought to be the cause because no doctor would investicate beyond this and I was put on estrogen for about 6 months and it caused me anxiety on the second day after application (patch), so I changed the patch.  The day that the new patch was affixed, I would have no anxiety until about 8:00 a.m. the next morning at which time the anxiety would return, so I changed the patch again.  I changed a patch every day that was intended to be changed every 3rd or 4th day.  My doctor for whatever reason allowed this to go on for 6 months.  I started to get weaker and weaker and weaker.  So, I decided one day to put up with the anxiety and leave the patch in place for the whole 4 days.  Well, I started to get really tired and felt pressure in my thyroid.  I did this for about a month.  I really started to exhibit major hypothyroid symptoms.  Finally, my doctor ran a test on my thyroid and it came back as hypothryoid.  She wouldn't check my adrenals nor my estrogen levels.  She put me on Synthroid and then Armour.  I started to experience some really devasting symptoms on that....extreme anxiety and horrific pain in the back right flank area.  I stopped the thyroid hormones and the pain greatly subsided.  So, I went to another doctor who would and did check a lot, but this doctor was hours and hours away and I knew that I couldn't afford him or manage the trip again, but decided to go to him this one time.  My blood work came back as having extremely elevated estrogen and extremely low progesterone and thyroid.  I was deathly ill by this time.  So, I stopped the estrogen and was put on thyroid hormones about 4 weeks later (very small dose of 25 mcg.).  Well, then I started to experience hyperthyroidism symptoms and lost 13 lbs. in one week.  So, the doctor who had checked my adrenals along with everything else stated that my adrenals had been extremely stressed and that my cortisol levels were very low as was my seratonine.  My epinephrine, norepinephrine and dopamine were elevated as was my DHEA which was 3 times the top of the range.  He told me to stop the thyroid hormone and start on low dose hydrocortisone (10 mg. daily).  Well, I started to experience extreme weakness with this after a while.  Was my system allowing this medication to build to toxic levels or was my body just rebelling from all the medications it has been on?  Perhaps I only need miniscule amounts of medication.  I don't know.  So, I stopped that.  I decided that I didn't want anymore drugs put into my body until someone found out for sure what was wrong with me, but I can't get a doctor to run a whole gammet of tests on me to get to the bottom of it.  These days, I am very, very sick and should possibly even be in the hospital for an array of tests.  I do know that 4 years ago my 8:00 a.m. cortisol was 23.8 and nearly 2 years ago it was 13 and now it is 10.  My doctor said that these are normal fluctuations.  These are my symptoms.  I can't tolerate the heat without getting very weak and dehydrated, I'm fatigued most of the time but unable to sleep, my night time sleep is very broken up with about 2 - 4 hours immediately and perhaps after waking 1 more hour or so, my body temperature while I sleep can be as low as 96.8 and has risen over the course of the day to as high as 100.2 with fluctuations up and down (high temps in the heat or low temps in colder temperatures, but also when I am weakened by overexerting myself (a kind of weakening that I can feel to the core of me...in my chest and legs) by something as easy as pulling weeks in my garden then my temperature will take a drop), I have dips of depression, too, and can't tolerate any refined carbohydrates, sugar, alcohol, or medications (i.e. otc sleep aids, benadryl or hormones), my hands and feet swell as does the flesh around my eyes, my right flank pain increases in relation to my other symptom increases and most days I feel like I am merely existing.  I am miserable and scared and was just wondering what my doctor should be investigating and if he doesn't then perhaps I should find another doctor who will investigate my symptoms.  Please tell me what tests should be done to rule out hypothalamus, adrenal, central nervous system or liver problems and do you suggest any other causes for my problems and if so, what tests in general should be run.  Thank you very much in advance, McMarsha P.S.  I'm sorry this post is so long, but as you see there is a lot of vital information that shouldn't be left out.  My problems are definitely a result of compounded events over the course of 4 years.  This much I know.  [img]%20%20[/img]

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lauraxyz, Generally speaking, a tooth abcess (infection) causes throbbing tooth pain, facial swelling and redness etc. However, with an advanced infection, you can suffer nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, and diarrhea. A tooth abcess needs prompt treatment because of the complications they can cause. For example, loss of the tooth, spead of the infection to soft tissue or jaw bone, or spread of the infection to other parts of the body, brain, heart and lungs. I would again suggest prompt treatment. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: dfmastin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Dec 27, 2004 7:44 pm Location: AR
title: "isolated" chills
content: I have experienced sudden onset of chills about once every several months for the last five years. My wife and I refer to it as my spells of "temperature deregulation". I feel as if I may be coming down with the flu for ten minutes (I feel a bit achy and under the weather) and then I experience racking chills for about twenty minutes. I immediately jump into a hot bath and so I'm not sure how long they would persist under other conditions. I feel somewhat nauseas as I'm experiencing these chills, but have never vomited and have no other symptoms (no focus problems, or cognitive changes). Blood dramatically drains from my hands and feet and my shaking is pretty severe. Afterwards, I may feel a bit hot and usually go to bed as I'm a bit exhausted after the chills, but otherwise I feel okay. These episodes of "dysautonomia" have always occurred in the evening and as far as I can remember, in the winter, but I never am particularly cold before onset of these chills. Also, as I've not had very many, the time of day or season consistency may be a statistical fluke. Only five to eight total episodes and I took notes the last two times as to what I'd eaten or been doing, but haven't generated interesting clues. I don't believe I have any other unusual autonomic symptoms. I'm wondering if anyone has any leads or ideas as to causes of "isolated chills"?

author: FLAEMT  Guest Posts: 10 Joined: Thu Dec 23, 2004 11:30 am Location: Florida
title: Hypotension or Mono?
content: Hi, I have been experiencing some shortness of breath and strong rapid heart rate lasting 30 seconds when sitting up after laying down for a while.  These symptoms don't seem to arise after physical exertion.  I check my blood pressure regularly and it is always in the 100/70 range ( I am 20 y/o and 135 lb. and workout 5 days a week).   I also feel my ears clog when this happens and everytime I workout.  I have no medical hx besdies mono (2 years ago) and acne but my mother tells me that she experiences the same type of feeling when she sits up.   No cardiac hx in my famly.  I am also easily fatigued during the day and have a lack of energy at times.   Could hypotension  possibly be the cause or could this be a reoccurance of mono?  Thanks for any replies.
posted_time: Post  by FLAEMT » Wed Dec 29, 2004 5:13 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Normal blood pressure lies within a range - it is not one set of numbers. Optimal blood pressure is now clearly defined as a reading below 120 / 80. If your blood pressure is always in the 100/70 range, you do not suffer from hypotension.  You state that you experience shortness of breath and rapid heart rate when changing from a supine to a sitting position and it is of very short duration (30 seconds), and not sustained. There is a rare condition known as platypnea which is characterized by shortness of breath that worsens in the upright position. It is unlikely that you have this problem because your shortness of breath lasts only 30 seconds and you do not experience it during or after exertional workouts. Several pathophysiologic processes contribute to shortness of breath and it would be out of place to list them here. If symptoms persist, both cardiac and pulmonary evaluations are recommended under the respective specialists.  Your other complaints of easy fatigability and lack of energy are suggestive of  chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS). Unfortunately, you do not state duration of these complaints.  CFS is characterized by a minimum of 6 months of severe physical and mental fatigue and fatigability made worse by minor exertion. Apart from profound fatigue, there are no other symptoms or physical signs which distinguish the illness. Anxiety and depression are commonly associated with the syndrome but are not part of it. No laboratory tests can confirm the diagnosis, but it is advisable to consult your doctor who may wish to conduct the following laboratory tests to exclude other causes of fatigue:  Full Blood Count, ESR, CRP and CK; Renal, liver and thyroid function tests.   I hope this information has been helpful.   Dr Anthony Solomon  MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: The condition you describe is suggestive of phimosis, which may be present from birth or may follow contraction resulting from trauma, infection or balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO).  Clearly, this is not congenital in your husband's case because it is of recent occurrence. As you have excluded STDs, it is most likely due to the trauma of frequent masturbation or BXO.  BXO is a common condition which frequently begins in childhood but may remain asymptomatic for a long time. In uncircumcised patients, the margin of the prepuce (which you describe as “around the foreskin by the tip”) is pale in colour, thickened and sometimes fissured and sore.  Treatment of BXO is by circumcision. If the condition is due to trauma, abstinence from masturbation will help. A genitourinary physician or urologist should be consulted for diagnosis and management. If urine flow is restricted, he should go to ER.  Thank you for contacting our website.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Dave: It is possible that your girlfriend has a yeast infection which is causing her burning pain. The problem with yeast infections is that unless both partners are treated they keep reinfecting each other. You might ask your girlfriend to get a prescription for her yeast infection that includes a medicated cream for both of you to use.  The reason that you are only having symptoms under the forskin is that yeast thrives in warm moist areas such as under the foreskin, under skin folds and in the vagina.  Only when the yeast has been cleared up on both of you should you engage in sex again.  Otherwise this infection will just continue on. Regards, Carolyn

title: Sepsis risk?
content: Hi. My mother (78 yowf, hx of diabetes-non ins. dep, CHF, emphysema) worries a lot. She recently read an article about sepsis and is worried about getting it now.  She has a small infection on her thumb.  No signs of spreading infection, her Dr. did not seemed concerned. Can you provide me with some information to alleviate her concerns? Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by tsanders38 » Wed Dec 22, 2004 11:14 am

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi,   Thank you for assisting your elderly mother to contact this website.  Although the term sepsis is used to describe the destruction of tissue by disease-causing bacteria or their toxins, I believe your question is directed at skin infections generally because your diabetic mother is now experiencing one on her thumb.  Since diabetes is a lifelong disorder, education of the patient and the family is the most important obligation of the physician who provides care. The disease is affected by daily fluctuations in environmental stress, exercise, diet and infections. The best person to manage it is the patient and the patient’s family and you are doing the correct thing by assisting your mother.  The physician or nurse has a duty to explain to a diabetic patient how to recognize, prevent or treat some of the hazards of the disease. It is important for her to have regular tests for blood glucose to ensure good control of diabetes. She should be provided with a home glucometer and taught how to operate and record results. If mother is a smoker, she should give up smoking. I will expect that she is on medication for CHF.   Prompt and proper first aid treatment is of the utmost importance in apparently minor injuries and infections of the skin, especially if located on the feet. The “small infection” on her thumb should be treated with a mild antiseptic and a physician consulted if redness, blistering, pain or swelling develops. Any break in the skin of the feet may become ulcerous or gangrenous unless treated properly by a physician. As soon as possible after any injury or abrasion of the skin of the feet, the area should be cleaned with mild soap and lukewarm water and covered with sterile gauze. The physician should be consulted for advice and treatment as soon as possible after any foot injury or infection.  I hope this information has helped you and your mother.  On behalf of the crew at this website, I would like to send seasonal greetings to your 78-year old mother.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

posted_time: Post  by roxy » Fri Dec 17, 2004 9:39 am

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: RARE INFECTIOUS VIRUS
content: Hi,  Apart from HIV which is a retrovirus, there are two other retroviruses, HTLV 1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus Type 1)  and HTLV 2 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic  Virus Type 2).  Both are associated with disease in humans.  HTLV 1 is endemic in Japan, the Caribbean and certain parts of West Africa. Transmission is by blood transfusion, drug users sharing needles and from mother to child, principally through breastfeeding. It can also be transmitted by sexual intercourse, especially from male to female.  HTLV 1 is associated with adult T-cell leukaemia / lymphoma and with a degenerative neurological disease.  HTLV 2 is a much more rarely isolated virus than HTLV 1 which has been isolated from Native Americans and in Africa, and also from intravenous drug users in the USA. Its role in human disease is uncertain but it is infrequently associated with hairy cell leukaemia.  Naturally, if you are generally in good health and full physical and blood examinations (numbering over a hundred times, according to you) have shown no abnormalities, it is unlikely that you have any of the diseases associated with the virus at the present time.  Thank you for contacting this website.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM

content: Hi gurly83, The term "inactive Hepatitis B" is usually used when a person whom is termed positive for Hepatitis B but has normal liver enzymes, a normal physical exam, and shows no symptoms. author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: 2 PROBLEMS: NIPPLE AND VAGINAL DISCHARGE
content: Hi,  First, let us look into the complaints you have about the left and right breasts:  i)  a bloody and purulent (yellowish) discharge from the nipple of your RIGHT breast  ii) a sharp pain in the LEFT breast which is associated with a lump the size of an acorn. The pain is getting worse and more frequent. There is no nipple discharge.   You do not state if you are lactating, if you are on contraceptive pills  and if the yellowish/bloody discharge is spontaneous or expressible. “Spontaneous” means that the discharge comes out on its own, without trying to force it out by manual expression. “Expressible” means that you have to manually express the discharge if it is to be visible.   You have consulted your doctor and it was dismissed as “nothing”. Is that the doctor’s word or your own interpretation? The symptoms you are experiencing in both breasts warrant a specialist examination by a breast surgeon. I am personally surprised that you have not been referred to one.  In the non-lactating breast, the commonest causes of nipple discharge (in decreasing frequency) are duct ectasia, intraductal papilloma and malignancy.   Spontaneous, bloody discharge from a nipple is suggestive of a benign papilloma in the duct or a malignant lesion. At your age, it is more likely the former (women over 50 are more likely to have a malignant cause).  Purulent discharge from a nipple may be caused by a sub-areolar abscess.  Milky discharge in the non-lactating female occurs in certain endocrine disorders A painful lump in the left breast may have several causes.   At your age, I am presuming that the causes of your breast lesions are benign, but further examination and investigations are mandatory to confirm the diagnosis. Please ask your doctor to refer you to the appropriate specialist.  In respect of your final complaint, a vaginal discharge that has a fishy odour and causes no vulvar itching or burning is very suggestive of Bacterial Vaginosis (BV). However, the discharge in BV is usually off-white or greyish-white in colour, not yellow.  Was a sample of the vaginal fluid subjected to tests? The tests that could have been done at the time of your visit are simple and diagnostic: acidity (pH) test of the vaginal fluid; amine test (development of a fishy odour after mixing a sample of vaginal fluid with a particular chemical); and a sample to identify “clue cells” by  microscopic analysis. Bacterial Vaginosis does not cause an inflammation in the vagina, so you would not expect any swelling there.   What medicine was prescribed?   Thank you for contacting our website.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM  Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: ben  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Dec 08, 2004 1:47 pm Location: new york
title: [no title]
content: Relapsing fever The disease is caused by Borrelia species (spirochetes). There are two distinct forms of this disease:  Louse borne relapsing fever (LBRF): Body lice (Pediculus humanus) become infected with B. recurrentis by feeding on spirochetemic humans, the only reservoirs of infection. Humans become infected when an infected louce is crushed and their body fluids contaminate mucous membranes or breaks in the skin.  Tick borne relapsing fever (TBRF): The ticks become infected by feeding on spirochetemic hosts (rats, mice, chipmunks, squirrels, rabbits, hares and humans). The spirochetes are transmitted by ticks to humans and animals via saliva and excretory fluids when the tick feeds.    i found that by searching for spirochetes but its part of this website!! so could his infection be borrelia/relapsing fever?

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: SKIN LESIONS
content: Hi,  What was the doctor’s diagnosis when he inspected the lesions 8-9 months ago? You mentioned “bacterial infection” in your last sentence: was this the diagnosis or your own interpretation?  Possible bacterial infections could be  impetigo contagiosa or furunculosis.  Your description of the lesions is very unclear. Perhaps my questions will assist you to give a clearer picture.  Have the lesions recurred at the same site? Do they occur singly or as grouped lesions which begin as itchy, red spots that evolve to papules, vesicles or pustules and later painful ulcers? According to you, the lesions first appeared on the skin in the lower abdomen, disappeared (without treatment?) and recurred in the lower abdomen and additionally on the penile shaft. By lower abdomen, I assume that you are referring to the pubic skin and adjacent region. At the same time, there was a pimple-like lesion on the lower lip, which keeps recurring. Are you sexually active, and was there a sexual contact within 2 to 20 days of the first episode?   You ask if this could be herpes, if not a bacterial infection.  Genital herpes is acquired sexually through contact with a person shedding the virus and could be due to Herpes simplex Type 1 or Type 2. Incubation period varies from 2-20 days. Type 2 usually results from sexual intercourse, while Type 1 can result from intercourse, fellatio or cunnilingus. Common symptoms are itching, burning, and redness prior to the eruption of the vesicles. The lesions usually recur at the same sites and start as itchy red spots, progressing to papules, vesicles or pustules, and finally painful ulcers.   An accurate diagnosis can only be made by a good history followed by visual examination of the lesions when they occur. This, as you know, is impossible on the net. Therefore, a visit to a dermatologist is necessary when the lesions appear again.   Thank you for contacting our website.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H  DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello: I advise strongly that you go to the doctor and have it checked.  My main concern is not Rabies, but rather an infection called "cat-scratch" disease.  Cat-scratch disease is an infection caused by bacteria (germs) carried in cat saliva. The bacteria can be passed from a cat to a human.  You can get cat-scratch disease from a cat bite or cat scratch. You can get the infection after a cat scratches you if the cat's paws have the bacteria on them. (A cat can get the bacteria on its paws when it licks itself.) With a cat bite, the cat can pass the bacteria to you in its saliva. You can also get the bacteria in your eyes if you pet a cat that has the bacteria on its fur and then rub your eyes. Many people who get cat-scratch disease do not remember being scratched or bitten by a cat.  Cat-scratch disease is not a severe illness in people who are healthy. But it can be a problem in people with weak immune systems.  Some warnings signs to look out for would be: A cat scratch or bite that does not heal in the usual length of time.  An area of redness around a cat scratch or bite that continues to get bigger for more than 2 days after the injury.  Fever that lasts for several days after a cat scratch or bite.  Painful and swollen lymph nodes for more than 2 or 3 weeks.  Bone or joint pain, abdominal pain (without fever, vomiting or diarrhea) or an unusual degree of tiredness for more than 2 or 3 weeks.   Hopefully, this will go away and will only be an unpleasant memory. Regards, Carolyn

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: You have not stated if you have been treated for your genital warts and if they are now cleared. It is also useful to know if your partner was examined.  Most genital warts are caused by HPV 6, and to a lesser extent HPV 11 and other HPV types.  Transmission of HPV by orogenital sex is CLEARLY POSSIBLE. There are four morphologic types of genital warts, one of which is known as CONDYLOMA  ACCUMINATUM and has a cauliflower appearance.   Condyloma accuminatum appearing on the lips, tongue or palate is a RARE manifestation of infection by genital warts acquired through orogenital sex.  Some patients with oral condyloma accuminatum will have concomitant genital or anal warts and most give a history of oral sex.  I would advise you to read my response (dated 16 November 2004) to the topic HPV authored by livvie0987. This will give you more information about genital warts and HPV.  Thank you for contacting our website.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Ashley,   Please state what your complaints were when you saw your family doctor on those two occasions.   Was the urine sample you provided a mid-stream specimen or a first catch sample? First catch samples usually produce false-positive results. What bacteria was isolated on culture and what was the result of sensitivity tests? What was the dosage of each of the Metronidazole pills? This drug is usually prescribed for the treatment of  trichomonas vaginalis infection (TV) which is nearly always sexually acquired. It is also the drug of choice for bacterial vaginosis (BV). Both TV and BV produce an offensive vaginal discharge. Do you have a discharge? If your doctor confirms TV infection, it is important to examine sexual partners and prescribe the same treatment even if the organism is not found. This avoids the risk of re-infection.     The doctor must have informed you that vomiting is a well-known side effect of Metronidazole and that you should abstain from alcohol while on it.  Blood in the urine: did you discover this yourself or was it after another urine test? There are several causes of blood in the urine (haematuria), the commonest of which are diseases of the kidneys and urinary bladder which are too numerous to mention here. Haematuria warrants more detailed investigations such as blood, urine and ultrasound studies.   Please supply us with some answers and we will advise you further.    Thank you for contacting The Doctor's Lounge.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

posted_time: Post  by docc » Tue Oct 19, 2004 6:24 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi docc, You are probably already aware that hepatitis c is a liver disease where the liver becomes swollen and stops working properly. It is a serious disease because your liver removes toxins that build up in the blood. It is a sneaky disease because some people can have no symptoms at all (approx 80%) and their liver only shows a small amount of damage. About 15% of people infected with the virus may develop cirrhosis after having the infection for many years. Some of the symptoms are: Feeling tired Feeling sick to your stomach Poor appetite Stomach pain Diarrhea Muscle and joint pain Dark yellow urine Yellowish eyes and skin  One of the treatments that I'm aware of is with a  drug called interferon. Treatment can prevent further liver damage and cirrhosis. My suggestion is that if your doctor wants to discuss treatment options with you that you should hear him/her out and then make your decision especially since you lab values already appear out of range. I hope this helps. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: 900.000 is the virus load in your blood. This is done using a technique known as quantitative PCR which is able to quantify minute amounts of viral DNA and RNA. The viral RNA is used to identify and count the viruses in your blood.  900,000 is high which means the disease as you say is active and requires therapy.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: 900.000
content: Dear Docc,  The 900.000 is the hepatitis c virus count in your blood. The number of viruses. Yes, 900.000 is really high. You should not even have one virus in your blood. Most probably you will be treated.  Abdominal pain is somtimes difficult to figure out without examination. There are many causes for right sided abdominal pain including liver disease (and you have active hepatitis c), gall bladder disease, ulcers in the stomach and first part of intestines, gall bladder, kidney disease including stones, colon disease, others such as back diseases and hernias. Many of these have to be looked for specifically such as kidney stones (having urine analysis and ultrasounds and having ct scans looking specifically for them with a certain protocol).  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: one of the last times i was "struck" i did go to the emergency room. i was so scared that something was terribly wrong with me. however, even though when i got there i had a fever over 103, they made me sit out in the waiting room for 5 or 6 hours. when the doctor saw me he told me i had a sinus infection even though he didn't check me over or run any tests. i've never had any tests run, never really had the money to do so. it does seem that it always occurs when moments are most stressful, but usually it would be days i wouldn't be doing anything in particular. i've had it a total of four times so far. the fever usually lasts for a better part of 24 hours, along with the rest of the symptoms. yes, there were heart palpitations, and yes i did feel cold all over-but i think from the chills. they were so bad my teeth would chatter and i would lay in the floor with a blanket over the heating vent (this was in winter) and still i was cold.  i never developed any kind of a rash or anything, except for the shingles i developed around the same time. as for the disorientation, it was almost like i was underwater, likewise with impaired hearing. i've always had strange medical problems but this one worried me particularly. any ideas?
