author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: When you have a high fever, and 103 is high for an adult, it is common to feel cold chills, disorientation, fast heart rate and shallow breathing.  I assume that the doctor diagnosed sinus infection because you had some tenderness either around the orbits of the eyes on across the forehead or had a discharge from the nose.  Once the fever goes down the symptoms should go away.  When people are under unusual stress, their immune system(part of the body that fights off infection) does not work as well and they are more prone to infection, colds, sinusitis, etc.  I would recommend you try to find ways to reduce your stress, perhaps by taking frequent breaks from whatever it is that stresses you, make sure your diet is high in foods that are natural antioxidants (fruits/vegetables), drink plenty of water and take mega does of Vitamin C.  All these things will help to build up your immune system to aid in warding off infection. Good Health To You, Carolyn

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello: You stated,"I am not anymore stressed out then any other working mother with 4 small children." As a mother of 5 grown  children, I remember well the days of working and raising kids.  Is it possible you don't realize how much stress you are experiencing?  Do you have any help at home?  How stressful is your job?  Stress can affect every fibre of our being, from our skin and hair to our cardiovascular system, and every effect is negative.  Have you been tested for arthritis, since you mention the joint pain? Also your  symptoms of joint pain are similiar to the symptoms of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS). CFS is usually diagnosed by doing labs to rule out other causes and when everything has been ruled out the name for the fatigue and joint pain is CFS.  Do you find that your symptoms subside on your days off or on vacation?  If so, then that would certainly indicate stress is a main component of your illness.  Sorry, I cant be of more help to you. Regards, Carolyn

title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Advil (ibuprofen) is an anti-inflammatory medicine, which relieves the signs of inflammation including redness, pain, swelling, etc. One cannot cure when the disease is not known. content: i just found out how much hepatits c virus is in my body. the nurse said that they would like it to be below 50, mine is over 800.000, is that bad? and how bad is it ? does anyone know?  ty   docc
posted_time: Post  by docc » Tue Oct 12, 2004 1:53 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Is this high???
content: Dear Docc,  Thank you very much for the update.  You having 800,000 copies of the virus means that the hepatitis c infection that you have is active and most probably needs treatment. The type of virus should be determined and then treatment started.  The treatment consists of pegylated interferon and ribavarin. Treatment is usually of long duration up to a year.  Interferon treatment has potential side effects that should be discussed with the treating physician fully before starting as sometimes they are severe enough that some people chose not to continue treatment after they start treatment.  Hepatitis c infection might be severe and progress to liver cirrhosis liver failure and there is a percentage that progresses to liver cancer.  You have to discuss all your options with your doctor and then decide which way you want to go. A liver biopsy might be needed before treatment.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

posted_time: Post  by neel24 » Sun Sep 26, 2004 12:59 am

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Folliculitis is the name given to a group of skin conditions in which there are inflamed hair follicles. The result is a tender red spot, often with a surface pustule. Folliculitis can be due to infection, occlusion, irritation and specific skin diseases. There are a number of bacterial infections associated with folliculitis including staph.  While the hair follicles themselves are not contagious, the staphylococci bacteria infecting them is. Therefore, no one should come in contact with the infected area.  Since the infection has reoccurred you may need to go back to the doctor and have a culture taken in order to determine which bacteria is the cause and which antibiotic will be effective. Regards, Carolyn

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Hepatitis c
content: Dear Docc,  Active hepatitis c infection means that the virus is replicating and increasing and destroying liver cells as it does that and this is what it is meant by increase in the liver enzymes.  Treatment should be given for an active case of hepatitis c, the specialist who does that should have adequate experience with the treatments for hepatitis c as they have lots of potential side effects. The specialist is either a gastroenterologist/hepatologist or an infectious disease specialist.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D

title: West Nile Virus
content: Hi: Would anyone know if the symptoms for WNV can include headache, muscular aches & a loss of appetite, but without a fever (or a very low-grade, barely detectable one at best)?  I live in San Jose, California, where cases of WNV have been reported.  Last week, I had these symptoms for a day or two before it started tapering off.  There were no other symptoms such as rash, vomiting, diarrhea, etc.  I was particularly struck by the fact that I had flu-like achiness but without any real fever, which I don't recall ever having had before.  Very odd, hence my posting.  I suppose it could be any number of things, but considering the timing (not quite flu season yet) & the unusual (at least for me) nature of the symptoms & with all of the hoopla lately about WNV, it made me wonder   .  Any thoughts would be appreciated. - Scott
posted_time: Post  by scotte1 » Sat Sep 18, 2004 8:23 am

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Scot: According to the Center for Disease Control: The symptoms of severe disease (also called neuroinvasive disease, such as West Nile encephalitis or meningitis or West Nile poliomyelitis) include headache, high fever, neck stiffness, stupor, disorientation, coma, tremors, convulsions, muscle weakness, and paralysis. It is estimated that approximately 1 in 150 persons infected with the West Nile virus will develop a more severe form of disease. Serious illness can occur in people of any age, however people over age 50 and some immunocompromised persons (for example, transplant patients) are at the highest risk for getting severely ill when infected with WNV.  Most people (about 4 out of 5) who are infected with West Nile virus will not develop any type of illness (an asymptomatic infection), however you cannot know ahead of time if you'll get sick or not when infected.   The incubation period in humans (i.e., time from infection to onset of disease symptoms) for West Nile disease is 2-15 days.  The symptoms last a few days, although even some healthy people report having the illness last for several weeks. The symptoms of severe disease (encephalitis or meningitis) may last several weeks, although neurological effects may be permanent.  You are right in saying it could be a number of things, because your symptoms fit so many illness that I could not begin to guess what it is without seeing some lab tests done.  Here's hoping you are feeling better now. Thanks for using The Doctor's Lounge, Carolyn
posted_time: Post  by Carolyn Merritt, LPN » Sat Sep 25, 2004 6:35 pm

title: Pimples after unprotected sex!!!!
content: One week a go I had unprotected sex with a girl rumored to not shower often. I am uncircumsized.  The day after sex I noticed some small red spots on the underside of my foreskin and and a few on the head of my penis.  The next day more were on the head of my penis, but the spots dissapeared after 3-4 days.  I diagnosed myself with a mild case of balinitis (sp?).  Also the day after sex I developed 3 pimples (hopefully) on the shaft of my penis.  I think they were infected hair folicules because each pimple had a hair coming out of it.  The pimples behaved exactly like normal pimples, they developed a white head, i poped it, white puss came out followed by a tiny bit of blood, then the next day the whitehead was  back.  I took a bath to soften my skin, and pulled the hairs out of the follicule.  More white puss.  The pimples reduced in size, but today (1 week after sex) they are still there and all three have a small whitehead. I have diagnosed myself with folliculitis. I have applied salycylic acid like i do to pimples on my face.  I am very worried and if they do not go away in the next 3-4 days i will somehow go see a doctor.  Could these symptoms be from my partners possibly-unclean vaginal secreations?  I did not shower or clean up after sex, and i read somewhere that vaginal secreations (especially unclean) if left on the penis can cause mild infection ie; balinitis and folliculitis.  Please tell me what you think, as i am naturally worried about an STD.

I wasn't depressed before but now with the fact that I cannot even provide for my children as a result of this, I am beginning to get that way.  They are out of town this weekend and I have come down to the fact that I have 2 options.  I can either somehow find my old psychiatrist who since left his practice or push up a few daisies.  I cannot take this anymore!    People around me just cannot understand what I am faced with now.  I have called other psychiatrists who all tell me that it's almost 2 months until the next appointment.  Alot of good that does me!  Please help if you can.  No one else seems to want to or care.  I am now at my wits end.  I have no more fight... Susan

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re:What the heck? Do you know?
content: Dear Michelle,  From your description, this sure sounds like either an infection or an inflammation.   The function of the lymph nodes is basically defence against spread of infection. This is done by draining areas of the body that are affected by infection and/or inflammation. Each group of lymph nodes in the body drains a specific area. When a lymph node enlarges, this means that there is either:  1. An intrinsic lymphatic disease in the lymph nodes and this will most probably affect more than one group of lymph nodes.  2. An infection or an inflammation in the area drained by this group of lymph nodes.  The groin lymph nodes drain lower limb, external genitalia and the lower anterior abdominal wall.  If your lower extremity joint problem is still going on, this might be the culprit. Sometimes, infection in the joint is difficult to treat and becomes chronic giving you all these symptoms of feeling tired and fatigued all the time. Your joints have to be looked at as well. Your anterior abdominal wall also has to be looked at for any infection even it looks so trivial.  i would recommend that you see the doctor once more to have a look at your lower limbs including your joints and your abdominal wall.  An examination of the lymph nodes all over the body should also be done to make sure that this is not a case of generalized lymphadenopathy which means that the causes will be totally different.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, There is definitely no replacing a direct physical examination in this situation and what I am about to say here would be purely speculative.  In medical dilemmas such as the one your girlfriend is facing, some symptoms stand out more than others as possible clues to a diagnosis. Protein in urine is a very significant finding. There are well established protocols for diagnosis of diseases that cause proteinuria. At first glance it seems the most sensible approach. What exactly do you mean by proteins in urine? Was this a simple urine test or did she have a 24 hour urine evaluation?  Next comes the low grade fever. Again there are protocols for management of cases known as fever of unknown origin. I would take that approach if the proteinuria seemed like a dead end or seemed to be part of a disease process thats larger than itself.  Multisystem involvement in females usually point to the possibility of autoimmune and connective tissue disorders such as systemic lupus erythematosis.

author: MirandaH20  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jul 15, 2004 8:12 am Location: Mississippi
title: Please Help!!
content: Let me tell you my story, back in December 2003, I was a thriving student in college, I was changing careers from a Network Engineer. I had a boyfriend that came down with a terrible illness that put him in bed for a week. We thought it was the flu. After he felt better, we engaged in kissing, etc. A few days later he told me it was strep throat.  I shortly after began having a bad bad sore throat, and began having fever. Myself being in school, and being a single parent I had no insurance so I did not go to the doctor. I treated and dealt with it the best I could. This lasted about 2-3 weeks. Once I felt better I continued with my daily activites. A few weeks later I got so sick I thought I was going to die. My fever was so high, I sweated and 2 seconds later I got bad chills. My joints hurt like a pain I had never felt before in my life, the worst part was the base of the back of my head hurt so bad I could barely move my head. I thought it was the flu, so I waited a few days to try and let it run it's course. 3-4 days went by and still with no medical insurance, I knew I had to foot a doctor bill, because I hurt so bad. I went into the doctors office, and he did a flu test which came up negative, he sent me home with some antibiotics, and I later recovered.  Here's my problems, I had a very high IQ and prided myself on being intelligent. Now ever since my illness of unknown origion, I am contanstly confused, I can't make a decision on anything to save my life, even as simple as whether to make a turn or go straight. I forget things as soon as they were told to me, my short term memory is rediculous, and my attention span switches like a childs. I used to ahve a 4.0 grade average, now I have dropped out of school. I want to go abck to my networking job, but I can't seem to retain any information after studying. PLEASE HELP ME, what do I do? Why is this happening to me?????? HELP ME PLEASE, I feel like I'm going crazy and I am only 26 years old.
posted_time: Post  by MirandaH20 » Thu Jul 15, 2004 8:27 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, It seems that you just recovered from a serious infection. I am glad that your doing fine and your decision to go the doctor was a smart one. Its normal after such a serious illness to be a bit 'out of shape' in many aspects. Its common to be confused during and after a febrile illness. For someone of your intelligence that would be a very scary thing. I understand that its been some time now since you were ill; however, it seems that you carried the fear with you. Human intelligence is a very vulnerable thing and can easily be affected by lack of confidence, fear etc.. I think you need to be more confident in your intelectual abilities and pass this phase.  What did your doctor say his diagnosis was? It seems unlikely that he gave you an antibiotic without reaching a diagnosis. The pain at the back of your neck could have been an attack of meningitis. What antibiotic was perscribed? I think you should also give your doctor a call and ask him if he thought it could have been an attack of meningitis?  Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello James, Blood in the semen may be caused by inflammation, infection, blockage, or injury anywhere along the male reproductive tract. It may indicate a problem within the urethra, testicles, epididymis, or prostate.  Blood in the semen is usually the result of inflammation of the seminal vesicles. If your ejaculate is persistently stained with blood, the following tests should be done: urinalysis and culture, semen analysis and culture, and ultrasound of the seminal vesicles.  James, why were you put on Doryx? You should call your doctor as soon as possible.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Alice, Thanks for dropping by! Vaginal candidiasis as far as I know cannot be transmitted by swimming. It can be transmitted by sexual intercourse. The chlorine in swimming pools could lead to vaginal irritation encouraging the development of candida infection. Infections that can be acquired by swimming include: trichomonas, cryptosporidum and some forms of tinea among others.  About 5 percent of women with vaginal yeast infections develop recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis (RVVC), which is defined as four or more vaginal yeast infections in a one-year period. Although RVVC is more common in women who have diabetes or weakened immune systems, most women with RVVC have no underlying medical illness that would predispose them to recurrent Candida infections. Medical experts still are trying to determine the most effective way to treat RVVC. Currently, most doctors treat this problem with two weeks of oral medication (fluconazole), followed by up to six months of a lower maintenance dose.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Alice, I understand your concern for others and that in is admirable and rare to find these days. I disagree with you that you are correct not to swim.  Let me first concentrate on what you can do for your tinea:  Preventive measures      Good personal hygiene helps to prevent and treat athlete's foot.      Anti-fungal powders may be used as a preventive measure if a person is susceptible to athlete's foot.    Drying the feet thoroughly after bathing or swimming has been shown to be the best means to    prevent the disorder.    Avoid socks made of synthetic materials, because they can retain moisture against the skin.      Change the socks as frequently as needed to keep the feet dry on a daily basis. Shoes should be well    ventilated and preferably of natural material such as leather, if feet perspire greatly.     Dry your toes thoroughly after bath and try to spend time with bare feet when you can.      Wear sandals or shoes when walking on moist or wet floors.      Don't share shoes or personal care items such as towels.   Second: It's commonly believed that tinea is highly contagious -- that it is easily contracted by walking barefoot in a locker room, for example. This is not true. Medical experiments, in which the objective has been to infect healthy skin with tinea, have failed; often one may have it without infecting others in the same living space.  Third: Here's a very practical solution that will allow you to swim without in the least bit being worried about infecting others:  - After cleaning and drying your feet thoroughly, place antifungal powder on your toes.  - Get yourself a pair of aqua socks or aqua shoes (also known as water shoes) like the ones used in snorkelling and wear them on. They are probably more protective than the shoes you are wearing everyday walking around your own house etc..  Have a look at them here: Aqua socks  Please note that we are in no way affiliated with this website and do not recommend you buy their product in particular.  - After you finish swimming take them off, wash and dry your feet then apply antifungal powder again.  Happy swimming!

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Common causes of acute tonsillitis may include: · bacteria, such as streptoccal or hemophilus bacteria · viruses such as adenovirus or Epstein-Barr virus, which also causes mononucleosis · diphtheria, a serious disease that produces a false membrane in the throat. Diphtheria can be prevented by the DPT vaccine.  Subacute tonsillitis is most commonly caused by actinomyces, a normal mouth bacterium that can cause infection.   In chronic tonsillitis, there is a long-standing infection that is almost always bacterial.   Usually, no significant long-term effects result from any of the three forms of tonsillitis. However, difficulty swallowing or breathing during sleep can result if the chronic infection causes enlargement of the tonsils. The healthcare provider may recommend a tonsillectomy, or removal of the tonsils, if there are recurrent infections or difficulties with swallowing and breathing.  In cases of chronic tonsillitis, antibiotics combined with oral steroids may resolve the infection. If not, the tonsils should be removed.   Tonsillectomy may be recommended by the healthcare provider if the person has had:   · 3 to 5 bacterial infections of the tonsils within 3 to 5 years  · more than 6 episodes of tonsillitis in one year  · chronic tonsillitis, or infection of the tonsils, that does not respond to antibiotics  · enlargement of the tonsils that causes sleep apnea, a breathing disorder that occurs during sleep  · enlargement of the tonsils that causes difficulty swallowing, especially in children

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Ear infection?
content: Dear anj128,  If you take the temperature through the ear and it comes out high, this does not mean that the ear temperature is high and thus the patient has an ear infection, it means that the whole body temperature is high which could be because of the cold that your son has.  If this was not your question then i misunderstood you.   How fast can an ear infection develop? Infections are usually fast to develop, may be over one or two days, so, to develop an ear infection over a couple of hours is difficult. Could the doctor have missed it? i guess he could.   The symptom that usually point to ear infections in infants or children is the child pulling at his/her ear and if knows how to express pain by a word, he/she would do so because it is very painful as this infection is under pressure in a closed small space (the ear).  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: calcified granulomas
content: i have been seeking answers to some complex problems for the last 3-4 years. could someone tell me how important it is to investagate a calcified granuloma? all of the info i have been getting on-line says that at least a cat scan or mri be done, maybe a biopsy of my lung. the problem is my doctors say its nothing to worry about, nothing can be done, or its not important. they have only seen it on xray. it is 7cm in my lower right lung. this is on top of many other problems.blood work showed a poorly defined band of restricted protein mobility of the gamma globulins- ruled out monoclonal proteins. biopsy of skin nodules show possible sarcoidosis, lobular panniculitis or erythema induratum. any info would be great, thanks
posted_time: Post  by moomom » Mon Mar 15, 2004 10:28 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Calcified granulomas
content: Dear Moomom,  If this calcified granuloma has not grown bigger over the last 3-4 years as evidenced on the regular follow-up chest x-rays (that i assume you have been having), then, personally, i think that there is no need to worry and there is no need for a ct scan, mri or lung biopsy. Regarding the possibilty of this being a malignant nodule, to reach a size of 7 cm and left untreated for 3-4 years, it would have caused lots of symptoms and problems if it was malignant, so most probably, this is just a benign granuloma.  Regarding your skin lesions and the lung nodule, as i mentioned earlier in one of the replies to one of your messages, that this is suspicious for sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is usually diagnosed by clinical picture and confirmed by biopsy, sometimes a biopsy is not even needed if the clinical picture is typical. There are blood tests that could be done and may help in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis if this is suspected from your clinical presentation.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Cold?
content: Dear Jennifer,  If you have a cold that has caused an inflammation in the membrane surrounding the lungs (a condition called pleurisy) or the membrane surrounding the heart (a condition called pericarditis), this could be the reason behind your symptoms. But also if the air that you are breathing is really cold and i would assume it is at -5, this could also give rise to this symptom. Do you have any other symptom of cold like fever, runny nose, cough, etc... or just this symptom?  If you are having other cold symptoms, this could be a cold. If not then i would assume that this most probably related to breathing cold air.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Re: Cold?
content: Dear Jennifer,   Treatment of the inflammation of the membrane surrounding the lungs (pleurisy) or the membrane surrounding the heart (pericarditis) is just regular over the counter anti-inflammatories such as aleve or advil and the like. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Cold?
content: Dear Jennifer,  Inflammation of the membranes surrounding the lungs or the heart is not caused by infections all the time. Sometimes it is unknown why such membranes get inflammed but the majority of these cases are thought to be caused by viral infections.  Ibuprofen is an anti-inflammaotory which should take care of the inflammation and help the pain, it is not a treatment of the cause, it is a symptomatic treatment.   Regarding your dizziness, if the cold virus affects the ear sometimes dizziness can be a part of the symptoms.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Renea  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Dec 02, 2003 5:42 pm Location: South Carolina
title: Cytomegalovirus CMV
content: I would greatly appreciate any answers that may be provided.   My sister died in 1983.  She had guillian barre.  While in the hospital she came down with meningitis and CMV.  I was told then (20 yrs ago) that CMV is a rare virus that attacks the brain of fetuses (excuse my spelling)?  The hospital told us that they suspected that my sister contracted the virus  in the pediatric ICU unit.  Tho she was 18 yrs. at the time because of space at the hospital she stayed over night in the unit.  Now Im reading that CMV is not all that rare and  that it can lay dormant in the body for years?  Has this just been discovered in the last 20 years or was I misinformed?  In 1981 my sister gave birth to a little girl who suffers from seizure disorders and mental retardation.  Ive read so much lately, Im just wondering if there could be a link?  And almost every article I read mentions the aids virus that my sister did not have.  Ive also read that it can be an std?   They told us that she would be put in medical journals because of her brain scans and other oddeties that went along with her 7 month stay in ICU.    I have recently discovered that the majority of patients with Guillain barre survive.   Looking back it seemed like we were the only people in the world going thru all of this and it all was illnesses that we had never heard of except for the meningitits.
posted_time: Post  by Renea » Tue Dec 02, 2003 6:12 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear Renea, CMV is indeed a life-long virus that can stay dormant for years. It can cause affection of the fetal brain if infection occurs during intrauterine life. In healthy individuals infection is usually asymptomatic but in some cases it may cause an illness similar to infectious mononucleosis with glandular fever (fever and lymph gland enlargement) & atypical lymphocytes in the blood picture. In immunocompromised patients (transplant patients, AIDS patients), it produces widespread visceral involvement with fever, interstitial pneumonitis (diagnosed by transbronchial biopsy), hepatitis, hemorrhage, gastroenteritis, choroidoretinitis (inflammation of the eye). Guillain Barre is also known as post-infectious polyneuropathy. Was she daignosed to have CMV based on serological testing? As the name indicates the disease usually follows infection. Several viruses are commonly associated with Guillain Barre, HIV being the commonest. Epstein Barr (infectious mononucleosis) is also associated with polyneuropathy.  Use our search box to search for more info on Guillain Barre and CMV.   Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Thu Jan 08, 2004 4:34 pm

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Have you tried steroid or any other creams on your face before? There are different causes for Perioral Dermatitis [POD], and steroid use is one of them. Cosmetics, including fluorinated toothpaste, petrolactum or paraffin based skin applications, yeast, bacteria, and fungi have been implicated. Young women are more prone.  As with all inflammatory skin conditions, substances that dilate skin blood vessels should be avoided. Examples include alcohol and hot foods.  Perioral dermatitis can be treated by antibiotics taken orally. If topical (on top of skin) application is preferred, avoid ointments, and use gel, lotion, or cream forms.  Zero-therapy is a treatment based on the idea that, by ceasing all topical medications and cosmetics, the underlying causative factor for POD is eliminated. If one has used steroids before, an initial worsening of symptoms may occur with this stop of steroids, which is only to be anticipated.  Hope this helps.  Warm regards,  -Bill

posted_time: Post  by KrissyCat7 » Tue Dec 09, 2003 9:10 pm

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi,  Dryness of vagina usually occurs after menopause. Otherwise, It can occur due to hormonal imbalances, infection of the vagina (vaginitis),  as well as part of an STD, but I do not believe it could be due to any contraceptive usage. If the vaginal dryness is felt particularly before having sex, then lack of a foreplay is to be blamed.  As a self-help guide, you might want to try a sitz bath in slightly salty water with half a cup of vinegar added. Yoghurt douching to vagina helps some.   The best insurance against infection is to wash vulva daily with plain water - no soap or bath salts - and avoid vaginal deodorants and medicated douches. Underwear should be changed daily, and sanitary towels and tampons every 6 hours at least.  A pap smear is a screening test for the early diagnosis of cervical cancer. It will not help to diagnose the cause of vaginal dryness. If there is vaginal discharge, a smear examination might clinch the cause.  Hope this helps.  Warm regards,  - Bill

After some research, I located information that there has indeed been cases reported in my very rural county of WNF in animals (vet report - 7) and one human.  Yes, we have mosquitoes here,  there is a slow moving creek behind my property - and yes, I have been bitten on more than one occaision.  My animals (horses and donkey) have all been vaccinated, my dogs and goose are okay, and I have not seen any dead birds, or if there were any, the stray cats and or coyotes in the area have eaten them.   I need something to tell my employer, as I have missed 4 work days now - other than saying I have a 'mild flu' I have nothing else to go on. content: Catrina, Its a pleasure having you on the site. I appologize for the delayed response.  I don't know if you have already read an article we have that addresses WNV. What your physician is doing is giving you an emperic antibiotic in case you have a bacterial infection.  Its good that you have had your samples taken. The question is what samples were taken? Are they just testing for the presence of WNV or is this a full bacterial culture as well?  I would also like you to take a look at this page which analyses the possible causes of fever. title: What is it?
content: My 20 year old son is in college 5 hours away.  On Friday 10/24 he called in the evening and said that he really felt bad.  Had chills, fever and headache with vomiting in the evening also muscle aches and pain in knee and elbows.  Went to class on Saturday morning with same symptoms.  Had to excuse himself from class twice to vomit.  Teacher sent him back to dorm.  He continued with the above symptoms all day Saturday.  He took Aleve and Tylenol for the fever.  Slept restlessly, drank fluids but no food.  Sunday he got up with same symptoms minus the vomiting.  Went to class and made it through the 3 hours.  Back to dorm.  Felt better till evening when rash started appearing on hands, feet, up arm.  Fever comes and goes.  No vomiting.  Made it through day on Monday with fever coming and going, rash not spreading, pain in knees and elbows still there.  Drinking fluids, ate lightly.  No vomiting but now has sore throat.  Tuesday, same symptoms till Tuesday evening when he calls at 6:30PM and he can't walk because of testicular pain on one side.  Rash is now covering bottom of feet and moving up arm.  Rash is small dots a little larger than a pin head.  Went to emergency room.  Doctors test for everything, UTC, Lyme, Strep you name it.  Nothing found.  Leaves emergency room at 11:00 PM with no answer and pain in testicle unbearable.  Mom leaves at 11:00PM for 5 hour drive.  He goes back to dorm and can't stand pain so girlfriend drives him 45 minutes to large VT hospital emergency room.  They do ultrasound of testicle and find nothing.  Out of emergency room at 5:45am Wed morning with a prescription for Vicadin.  No answers.  Eats first meal - breakfast since Friday.  He goes back to dorm and takes Vicadin, vomits and has chills and fever.  Rash has white spots on top of red dots.  Pain still there can't walk.  Comfortable only when lying still on bed.  Thursday - chills, pain in testicle, vomits, white spots breaking.  HELP

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Rabies vaccine
content: Dear Feather, There are two WHO approved vaccination schedules: - Classical 5 dose intramuscular regime (“ Essen” regimen): one dose of the vaccine should be administered on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28 in deltoid region or, in small children, into the antero- lateral area of the thigh muscle; - As an alternative, the 2- 1- 1 regimen may be used. Two doses are given on day 0 in the deltoid muscle, right and left arm. In addition one dose in the deltoid muscle on day 7 and one on day 21.  As regards RIG, you should receive it if your bites are classified as category 3:  Category III: Single or multiple transdermal bites, scratches or contamination of mucous membrane with saliva (i. e. licks) use immunoglobulin plus vaccine.  Please refer to the rabies page on The Doctor's Lounge:  Rabies  What is predisposing you to this kind of exposure?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Re:
content: Dear Pamnub, I have reviewed the pictures you have sent. Your sister has a severe form of cellulitis by the looks of things. There maybe also multiple subcutaneous abscesses. You say her blood sugar is normal? Has she done a complete blood count? Regardless of the underlying cause the infection your sister has should be treated immediately. First a pus sample needs to be taken and cultured to know which is the most appropriate antibiotic. Once the antibiotic is given and the symptoms start to reside, a search for a cause should be sought. A battery of investigations will be ordered depending on the causative organisms but will probably include a search for diseases that cause a decrease in the immunity, taking into account that she has rheumatoid arthritis. Lymphedema if present as well should prompt a search for a cause as well. Lymphedema is not treated by exercise.  So to recap, lets start with a culture and sensitivity test for the pus, her consultant may like to start her on an emperic antibiotic while the results of the C&S come in from the lab.   Methadone is an analgesic it should not be related to her condition.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: Zoster sans varicella?
content: Can Herpes zoster occur in someone who has never had chicken pox?  -Bill
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Russell M » Mon Jun 16, 2003 11:17 am

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Herpes zoster, also known as shingles or zoster, is a viral infection caused by the same virus that causes chicken pox (varicella-zoster virus). In general anyone who's had chicken pox can develop herpes zoster. The virus remains dormant (latent) in certain nerve root ganglions and under any circumstances that weaken the immune system the virus reactivates, multiplies and moves along nerve fibers towards the skin leading to the typical picture of herpes zoster (tingling, burning pain, vesicles, etc) Actually, we can say that yes herpes zoster can occur in people who have never had a history of a typical attack of chicken pox. Meaning that after the development of chickenpox (varicella) vaccine which is life attenuated vaccine, almost 90% of those who have received the vaccine develop long term immunity and are protected. In some cases, however, the vaccine may only weaken the disease. Therefore, it's possible to develop chickenpox even if you've received the vaccine however, the infection is usually mild, atypical and passed undiagnosed. Children, or those receiving the vaccine may only develop a few pox sores at the site of the vaccination. Although these people are protected from the severe form of chicken box they can still get this mild form. This is a possible explanation how someone with no history of typical attack of chicken pox develop zoster later in life when the immune system is compromised.  The virus that causes zoster (if blisters are broken) can only be passed on to others who have not had chicken pox and then they will develop chicken pox, not zoster. Zoster is much less contagious than chicken pox.   Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Mon Jun 16, 2003 6:17 pm

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Thank you for the response. Apart from subclinical chickenpox having occured unnoticed in the vaccinated usually, my doubt still remains if zoster can occur in someone who has NEVER had chickenpox clinical or otherwise...?
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Russell M » Tue Jun 17, 2003 11:57 am

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear bill, To my knowledge, only those who had chicken pox can develop herpes zoster later in life. Once the immune system is weakened,  the dormant virus reactivates causing herpes zoster. The virus that infects the body causes chicken pox. The dormant virus that stays latent in the ganglion (nerve roots) causes  herpes zoster in immunocompromized people.  Thank you

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: cjd
content: BSE (BOVINE SPONGIFORM ENCEPHALOPATHY) belongs to a family of diseases known as transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs). TSEs characteristically have prolonged incubation periods and are always fatal. Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (vCJD) is the TSE that affects humans and has been linked to BSE.  So humans get infected with vCJD, BSE is affects animals.   To answer your question:   The incubation time of the disease is dependent upon the type of CJD. For people with sporadic and familial CJD the incubation time is believed to be as long as 20 years. The incubation period for acquired CJD varies depending on the portal of entry of the infectious prion protein. Intracerebral infection may have an incubation period as short as a couple of months, whereas peripheral infection may have an incubation time that ranges from a few years to decades.   The initial symptoms are subtle with ambiguous symptoms of insomnia, depression, confusion, and strange physical sensations. Some problems with memory, coordination, and sight also begin to develop but are ignored as a sign of increasing age.  As the disease progresses, the initial symptoms worsen quickly and the patient develops a rapidly, progressive dementia. Involuntary and irregular jerking movements, known as myoclonus, also develop.  During the final stage of the disease, the patient may go blind, lose the ability to speak, and lapses into a coma. The bedridden patient usually succumbs to death through a secondary infection such as pneumonia. The duration of the illness can last from as short as several months to as long as two or more years.  Several symptoms of CJD can be compared to those of other neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s or Huntington’s disease. In fact as many as 13% of Alzheimer patients were found upon autopsy to have actually had CJD.  Again this means you can't eat meat and get sick in the next couple of days. It seems to be only anxiety if your check up turned out fine.

author: Dr. A. Rajput  Medical Doctor Posts: 74 Joined: Fri Apr 11, 2003 10:16 pm Gender: Male Location: India  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Rajput       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: i m really not sure which blood tests are u talking about.right now i can recollect the following blood tests:  *Complete blood count (CBC) may show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC), a nonspecific sign of infection.  *Rise in antibody to the virus.   if its some other,please mention it.but none of the above tests are specific for varicella virus.   Chickenpox and shingles are caused by the same virus — varicella-zoster. When a person, usually a child, is first exposed to the varicella-zoster virus, he or she develops chickenpox, a highly contagious disease. Most of us catch it during childhood because the virus can be spread through air as well as through contact with the rash. The infection begins in the upper respiratory tract where the virus reproduces over a period of 15 days or more (the incubation period). The virus then spreads to the bloodstream and migrates to the skin, giving rise to the familiar rash.    in some cases some of the virus particles leave the skin blisters and move into the nervous system. There the viruses settle down in an inactive (latent) form inside specific nerve cells.When the chickenpox virus reactivates, the virus moves down the long nerve fibers that extend from the sensory cell bodies to the skin. The viruses multiply, the telltale rash erupts, and the person now has herpes zoster, or shingles.  Contact with a person with shingles may cause chickenpox (but not shingles) in someone who has never had chickenpox before.    forget about blood tests for a moment.fact is u havent had chicken pox till now.so u are a risk.this is not to scare u but u should always be on the safer side,right?though it is not contagious,try avoiding direct or indirect contact with the lesions of ur relative who is having shingles till the disease subsides.  regards Dr Amit Rajput

author: Dr. A. Rajput  Medical Doctor Posts: 74 Joined: Fri Apr 11, 2003 10:16 pm Gender: Male Location: India  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Rajput       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: dear merilyn,               i would try to explain few things which might be of help to u.HPV is a type of virus (Human papillomavirus) that causes warts. A few types cause warts on hands and feet but many other types cause warts on the genitals (sex organs or private parts).u didnt specify where exactly u have warts.      anyway,the most common way to get it is by having sex or touching the genitals of someone who already has the infection. Rarely, people can be born with the infection or children can get it while being bathed or changed. Sometimes people become infected with HPV and the warts will not develop for many years.      Condoms (rubbers) may help to slow its spread. If you have had sex with another person many times, they are probably already infected.       If you are a woman with genital warts, you should have a Pap smear every year to rule out cervical cancer which is found related to HPV.            well to b frank  i havent treated a wart patient yet but i can comment on treatment modalities which are commonly used:            One way is putting chemicals such as Podophyllin, Condylox, or trichloroacetic acid on the wart to kill and dissolve it. Another is to freeze them off. The warts can also be cut off using electric loops, lasers, or surgery. The medicine Aldara can activate your immune system to kill the wart cells. You should never use over the counter cures for warts near the sex organs because they can cause severe irritation. These treatments will get rid of the warts but you may not ever get rid of HPV itself. The virus may still be inside and may cause more warts in the future. This is why it may take a long time to cure genital warts. Always talk to your doctor about your treatment and make sure you understand what to do and when to come back.       i hope that answers most of your questions.if any queries,feel fre to comment.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Pain in vagina
content: Dear Bellabellina, Pain and tenderness in the area of the vagina could be a vaginitis or inflammation of any of the structures related to the vagina (e.g. Bartholin's glands). I cannot help you diagnose the condition online but it is highly recommended that your friend get a proper physical exam, whether the cause is due to an STD or not. Vaginitis is caused by:   infections  lack of the hormone estrogen  irritants  allergies.   Infections causing vaginitis are: candidiasis (can-di-DYE-a-sis)  bacterial vaginosis (back-TEER-ee-al VA-ji-NO-sis)  trichomoniasis (trick-oh-mo-NEYE-ah-sis).
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Fri Jan 17, 2003 4:02 am
